revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Adam Mada | image = Adam Mada.jpg | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = 1979 | birth_place = Canberra, Australia | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = Australian | other_names = | occupation = Australian magician, entertainer, director, producer MC, speaker and [[magic consultant]] | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }}
{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} '''Adam Mada''', known professionally as '''The Wizard Of Oz''', is an Australian magician, entertainer, director, producer, MC, speaker and [[magic consultant]]. He is the resident magician for [[Studio 3 (TV series)]] on [[ABC3]], and the famed weekly live cabaret El Circo (41 oxford st darlinghurst nsw 2000) in Sydney Australia, he was the inspiration for 2 characters in the Novel Siren by [[Tara Moss]], Adam was cast in Band Of Magicians, supergroup in 2015. Born in Canberra, Australia in 1979 he is based in [[Bellevue Hill, New South Wales]], Sydney with his partner [[Susie Rugg]] and their two children.<ref>[http://www.theaussieword.com/2013/06/special-interview-adam-mada.html "Special Interview"], ''[[The Aussie Word]]''</ref>
== Early life ==
Mada became interested in magic in his youth performing for family, friends and private functions before deciding to pursue magic full-time when he was 21. He attended the Jeff McBride Magic Masterclass in Las Vegas, USA with Eugene Burger and has studied [[conjuring]] theory with mentors from South Africa, Venezuela, France, Singapore and Australia.<ref name="canberratimes">Cerabona, Ron. [http://www.canberratimes.com.au/entertainment/movies/double-effect-of-a-split-personality-20121102-28pt7.html "Double Effect of a Split Personality"], ''[[The Canberra Times]]'', Canberra, 3 November 2012. Retrieved on 2013-01-29.</ref> Mada is a scholar of magic interested in the social dynamics of performance magic, often advising academics and artists on magic theory and practice<ref name="timeout">[http://www.au.timeout.com/sydney/clubs/features/4328/adam-mada-interview "Mada's Touch"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130727143155/http://www.au.timeout.com/sydney/clubs/features/4328/adam-mada-interview# |date=27 July 2013 }}, ''[[Time Out Sydney]]'', Sydney, 3 April 2009. Retrieved on 2013-01-29.</ref>
== Fooling David Copperfield == 2016 - Australian radio network [[Austereo Radio Network]] invited Adam to create a special trick that could be taught to [[2Day FM]] [[Hit 30]] radio personality Angus O'laughlin who then performed to [[David Copperfield (illusionist)]] successfully fooling him back stage in the Copperfield theatre. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.2dayfm.com.au/shows/hit30/blog/angus-learns-magic-for-david-copperfield/|title=Angus Learns Magic For David Copperfield!|last=Boy|first=Social|access-date=2016-07-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.2dayfm.com.au/shows/hit30/billboard-music-awards-2016/david-copperfield-the-master-magician-and-illusionist/|title=David Copperfield, The Master Magician AND Illusionist|last=Boy|first=Social|access-date=2016-07-15}}</ref>
== Live Performance / Tours == 2016 - Mada along with his protege's Lucas Itrawan and Ash Hodgkinson (Cardistry) were invited to perform at the [[Royal Bombay Yacht Club]] to celebrate the life of India's famous radio broadcaster the late Hamid Sayani brother of [[Ameen Sayani]]. Mada's show Mada's Marvels toured India funded by The Australian High Commission, The Australia India Council and Mumbai Lit Fest. Author and researcher John Zubrzycki toured with Mada's Marvels, presenting a lecture on the Australian - Indian connection through conjuring and magic as part of the performance.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://india.highcommission.gov.au/ndli/pa3016.html|title=Australian High Commission in|last=Trade|first=corporateName= Department of Foreign Affairs and|website=india.highcommission.gov.au|access-date=2017-01-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/delhi/A-magical-evening-with-Adam-Mada/articleshow/55838030.cms|title=Australian magician Adam Mada performs in Delhi - Times of India|newspaper=The Times of India|access-date=2017-01-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Delhi/Adam-Mada-casts-a-spell-on-Delhi-Gurugram/article16696580.ece|title=Adam Mada casts a spell on Delhi, Gurugram|last=Singh|first=Shivani|newspaper=The Hindu|language=en|access-date=2017-01-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ani/australia-s-famed-mada-s-marvels-magicians-to-perform-in-delhi-116111500410_1.html|title=Australia's famed Mada's Marvels' magicians to perform in Delhi|last=ANI|date=2016-11-15|newspaper=Business Standard India|access-date=2017-01-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thegenxtimes.com/trends/australian-magician-adam-mada-to-perform-in-delhi/|title=Australian magician, Adam Mada to perform in Delhi|newspaper=The GenX Times|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/life/travel/tying-down-the-indian-rope-trick-in-mumbais-shivaji-park/news-story/d473494839f42b3000290578307b710f|title=tying-down-the-indian-rope-trick-in-mumbais-shivaji-park|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
Adam produced the first ever [[Short and Sweet (festival)]] Magic and Comedy festival in 2016. <ref name="Short+Sweet">[http://www.sydneyartsguide.com.au/short-and-sweet-comedymagic-2016-week-1-new-theatre/ "Short+Sweet"]</ref> 2014 Junior Australian Magic Champions "CARDISTRY" also coached and created by Adam Mada took out the Judges and Peoples vote. <ref name="CARDISTRY WIN">[http://www.hillsnews.com.au/story/3702722/magic-duos-sweet-success/ "CARDISTRY WIN"]</ref>
In 2015 Adam was cast in the second version of the production [[Band of Magicians]], joining [[James Galea]], [[Ben Hanlin]] and Brett Loudermilk. Previous magicians included [[Justin Willman]], [[Justin Flom]] and [[Nate Staniforth]].<ref name="Band Of Magicians">[http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/CU1505/S00366/band-of-magicians-tours-nz.htm "Band Of Magicians"]</ref>
Mada was invited to headline the 2014 Hoopla festival with his Mada's Marvels show in Darling Harbour.<ref name="Mada's Marvels">[http://www.shfa.nsw.gov.au/content/library/documents/76223E2E-5056-A83C-FCCC6819485BDF8F.pdf "Mada's Marvels"]</ref><ref name="Becoming a Magician">[http://www.darlingharbourhoopla.com/the-day-i-quit-my-job-to-become-a-magician/ "Becoming a Magician"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502013510/http://www.darlingharbourhoopla.com/the-day-i-quit-my-job-to-become-a-magician/ |date=2 May 2014 }}</ref><ref name="Marvels">[http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/newslocal/city-east/darling-harbour-to-become-a-giant-sideshow-alley-this-long-weekend-as-hoopla-comes-to-town/story-fngr8h22-1226886776359 "Marvels"]</ref> He is a founding artist of the long running El Circo Cabaret show running weekly at Sydney cabaret venue Slide now in its 7th year.<ref name="Adam Mada Illusionist">[http://issuu.com/weekenderpenrith/docs/fyidec13/4 "Adam Mada Illusionist"], ''[[The Western Weekender]]'', Sydney, 2013-13-12</ref> He has also maintained long residencies at Sydney nightspots De Nom, IVY, Tharens, The Chamber of Secrets<ref name="timeout" /> and is magician in residence at experimental cabaret show El Circo.<ref>{{cite web|last=Casben |first=Brett |title=El Circo |url=http://www.australianstage.com.au/201003283338/reviews/sydney/el-circo.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100329010101/http://www.australianstage.com.au/201003283338/reviews/sydney/el-circo.html |publisher=Australian Stage |accessdate=30 April 2013 |archivedate=29 March 2010 |dead-url=yes }}</ref><ref name="samesame">[http://www.samesame.com.au/reviews/2194/Live--El-Circo--Slide.htm "Live – El Circo"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116091413/http://www.samesame.com.au/reviews/2194/Live--El-Circo--Slide.htm |date=16 January 2014 }}, ''[[Samesame.com.au]]'', Sydney, 1 April 2008. Retrieved on 2013-04-30.</ref> Mada has written, directed and performed a number of stage shows including "Mada vs. Vegas – the Duelling Magicians" at the Melbourne Magic Festival and Adelaide Fringe.,<ref>Noonan, Amy. [http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/mada-vs-vegas-the-duelling-magicians/story-fn489zz9-1225833828842 "Mada vs. Vegas – the Duelling Magicians"], ''[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|Adelaide Now]]'', Adelaide, 24 February 2010. Retrieved on 2013-01-29.</ref> He has also toured with Australian variety productions, most recently playing the character Two-Face in "The Batman Follies of 1929.",<ref name="canberratimes" /> is a Headline act for the 2013 national Gangsters ball tour.,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gangstersball.com.au |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-07-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130811041642/http://www.gangstersball.com.au/ |archivedate=11 August 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> Mada is playing the character Rasputin in Slides 2013 production of El circo Blanc.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://slide.com.au/shows/elcircoblanc/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-07-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130516214057/http://slide.com.au/shows/elcircoblanc/ |archivedate=16 May 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
== Television ==
Mada is the current resident magician on Studio 3 for ABC 3 television Australia.<ref>http://www.abc.net.au/abc3/watchnow/studio3/abc3/?s=3793560#e1139304</ref>
Adam starred in the [[Network Ten]] 2014 Christmas special on [[Studio 10]] with his famous magic drink routine.<ref>{{cite web|title= Studio 10 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eRQdnPerzcs|accessdate=20 Jan 2015|date=25 December 2014}}</ref>
Mada appeared alongside magicians Nicholas J. Johnson and Clare Werbeloff in the 2010 series ''[[The Real Hustle]]'' for Channel 9.<ref>{{cite web|last=Knox|first=David|title=Airdate: The Real Hustle|url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2010/09/aird'ate-the-real-hustle.html|publisher=TV Tonight|accessdate=8 April 2013|date=6 September 2010}}</ref> He consulted on ''[[Sleeping Beauty (2011 film)|Sleeping Beauty]]'', creating an illusion for the film's opening sequence.<ref>[http://itricks.com/news/2012/01/a-gag-worthy-illusion/ "A Gag-Worthy Illusion"], ''[[iTricks Magic News]]'', 17 January 2012. Retrieved on 2013-02-04.</ref> In "Binge", an episode of ABC Television documentary ''Whatever! The Science of Teens'', he worked with Neuroscientist John Currie Prof. John Currie to illustrate the effects of binge drinking in teenagers by applying magic techniques to memory tests.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mada|first=Adam|title=Whatever!|url=http://vimeo.com/33692800|publisher=Vimeo|accessdate=30 April 2013|date=13 December 2011}}</ref> During the 2012 season of reality television competition [[Australia's Got Talent]], Mada collaborated with choreographer Sarah Boulter on a levitation routine for her dance group Ev & Bow.<ref>{{cite web|author=iTricks|title=Standing Ovation After Illusionist Adds Levitation to Australia's Got Talent Dance Routine|url=http://itricks.com/news/2012/05/standing-ovation-after-illusionist-adds-levitation-to-australias-got-talent-dance-routine/|accessdate=4 February 2013}}</ref>
==Speaking==
In 2013 Journalist [[Joe Hildebrand]] invited Mada to speak about invisibility on a panel at the [[Museum of Contemporary Art Australia]] including other speakers [[Brian Schmidt]] and [[Ron McCallum]].<ref>http://www.mca.com.au/events/mca-rocks-20-jun/6611/</ref>
== Radio ==
Mada hosted weekly radio segment 'Wonder Thunder' for [[FBi Radio|FBi radio station]] in 2009, presenting the history of magic and performing effects live on air.<ref>Ellis, Tim. [http://magicunlimited.typepad.com/magic_unlimited_with_elli/2009/05/adam-madas-weekly-radio-show.html "Adam Mada's Weekly Radio Show"], ''Magic Unlimited'', 19 May 2009. Retrieved on 2013-02-04.</ref>
== Fiction ==
Mada has collaborated with author [[Tara Moss]], for her crime thriller Siren.<ref>{{cite web|last=Purcell|first=John|title=Ten Terrifying Questions|url=http://blog.booktopia.com.au/2010/03/15/tara-moss-answers-ten-terrifying-questions/|work=Booktopia|accessdate=4 February 2013}}</ref>
==Charity Work==
Mada has contributed to several charity organisations with performances, workshops and fund raising. Notably Mada headlined the [[World Aids Day]] Gala in 2013, for the [[Aids Trust of Australia]]<ref name="Adam Mada Illusionist"/><ref>[http://www.adammada.com/news/headline-artist-for-world-aids-day-gala/ "Adam Mada with NSW Governor"], ''[[adammada.com]]'', Sydney, 2013-17-12</ref> in 2012 Adam was WWF Earth Hour ambassador,<ref>{{cite web|title=Earth Hour 2012 – Earth Hour Ambassador Adam Mada|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HPeBd0TOXpA|publisher=WWF Australia|accessdate=30 April 2013}}</ref> prompting criticism from journalist [[Andrew Bolt]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Bolt|first=Andrew|title=Earth Hour: I won’t buy what such people sell|url=http://blogs.news.com.au/heraldsun/andrewbolt/index.php/heraldsun/comments/earth_hour_i_wont_buy_what_such_people_sell/|accessdate=30 April 2013}}</ref> In 2013 Mada became an ambassador for the [[Starlight Children's Foundation]]<ref>http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/top-10-must-do-melbourne-events-this-weekend/story-fni0fiyv-1226675010987</ref> He is a coach for the starlight captains <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creammagazine.com/2013/06/the-conundrum-and-palindrome-that-is-adam-mada/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-07-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130628005531/http://www.creammagazine.com/2013/06/the-conundrum-and-palindrome-that-is-adam-mada/ |archivedate=28 June 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> as well as raising funds form his public shows as part of the Melbourne Magic Festival Mada's Marvels <ref>http://melbournemagicfestival.com/speaker-lineup/madas-marvels/{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>https://www.facebook.com/StarlightAustralia?hc_location=timeline</ref>
== Collaborations ==
Off stage, Mada has sought to broaden the appeal for magic in Australia through collaborations on film, television, radio, and literature. He has spoken publicly about the need for better support for small business, especially in the arts and entertainment sector.<ref>Darnell, Elva. [http://www.abc.net.au/news/2010-08-13/adam-mada/948124 "Adam Mada"], ''[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]'', 18 August 2010. Retrieved on 8 April 2013</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Making a Full-time Living in the Performing Arts|url=http://www.stagewhispers.com.au/news/making-a-full-time-living-performing-arts|publisher=Stage Whispers|accessdate=8 April 2013}}</ref>
In 2012, Mada worked with choreographer Farhan Hassan and costume designer Glenna Ng to create 'The Chamber of Secrets Magic Show' at the National Drama Center in Singapore.<ref>{{cite web|last=Allan |first=Ruby |title=Adam Mada: The Chamber of Secrets Magic Show |url=http://www.therashow.net/2012/07/24/adammada-the-chamber-of-secrets-magic-show/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130703111406/http://www.therashow.net/2012/07/24/adammada-the-chamber-of-secrets-magic-show/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=3 July 2013 |publisher=The RA Show |accessdate=8 April 2013 |date=24 July 2012 }}</ref>
=== Other Collaborations ===
* 2012: Character in Carol Barroso's short film "The Diamond Sea".<ref>{{cite web|last=Barroso |first=Carol |title=The Diamond Sea |url=http://thediamondsea.org/The-Diamond-Sea-Film |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130705083414/http://thediamondsea.org/The-Diamond-Sea-Film |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 July 2013 |accessdate=4 February 2013 }}</ref> * 2012: Special guest for the Alex Davies mixed reality installation.<ref>{{cite web|title=New Art now in creative development |url=http://artery.australiacouncil.gov.au/2012/03/new-art-now-in-creative-development/ |publisher=Artery |accessdate=8 April 2013 |date=13 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130505140824/http://artery.australiacouncil.gov.au/2012/03/new-art-now-in-creative-development/ |archivedate=5 May 2013 }}</ref> * 2011: Guest lecturer for the Creative Accounting series at the University of Technology Sydney Gallery.<ref>{{cite web|title=UTS:Gallery Events and Programs|url=http://www.art.uts.edu.au/gallery/Events/Events.html|publisher=[[University of Technology, Sydney|University of Technology Sydney]]|accessdate=8 April 2013}}</ref> * 2009: Subject of contemporary artist's Kathryn Grays work "Contingency Plan".<ref>{{cite web|last=Gray|first=Kathryn|title=Contingency Plan|url=http://kathryngray.wordpress.com/2009/08/02/contingency-plan/|accessdate=4 February 2013}}</ref>
== References ==

{{Infobox organization |name = Australian Film Institute |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = AFI |motto = |formation = November 1958 |extinction = |type = Film and television organisation |status = |purpose = |headquarters = [[Melbourne, Victoria]] |location = 236 Dorcas Street, South Melbourne, Victoria 3205 |region_served = [[Australia]] |membership = |language = |leader_title = CEO |leader_name = Damian Trewhella |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = {{URL|www.afi.org.au}} |remarks = }}
The '''Australian Film Institute''' ('''AFI''') was founded in 1958 as a [[non-profit]] organisation devoted to developing an active film culture in Australia and fostering engagement between the general public and the [[Cinema of Australia|Australian film industry]]. It is responsible for producing Australia's premier annual film and television awards, as of 2011 known as [[AACTA Awards]] (previously the AFI Awards).<ref name=afiabout>[http://www.afi.org.au/AM/ContentManagerNet/HTMLDisplay.aspx?ContentID=4593&Section=History_of_AFI "The Australian Film Institute – Celebrating 50 Years of Pride and Passion"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090521000000/http://www.afi.org.au/AM/ContentManagerNet/HTMLDisplay.aspx?ContentID=4593&Section=History_of_AFI |date=May 21, 2009 }}</ref>
The work of the institute is supported by government funding, corporate sponsors and approximately 10,000 members nationally. As Australia's foremost motion picture industry association, AFI promotes the Australian film and television industry and plays a central role in the way in which the Australian film industry is known and understood, both locally and internationally.<ref name=afiabout />
In the 1970s, the AFI played a prominent part in reviving the Australian film industry and in convincing the government to invest in the creation of the Experimental Film Fund, a film school, and a corporation for advancing feature film production. The year 1976 marked the first time that the AFI Awards, which had been given since 1958, were televised. Ten years later, television categories were added to the awards.
A recent focus of the organisation has been on helping to develop the careers of Australian film artists, through the AFI Fellowship and AFI Documentary Trailbrazer programs, as well as with the AFI Young Film Actor Award.<ref name="afiabout" />
The AFI is affiliated with the [[LAAFTA|Los Angeles Australian Film & Television Association]]. In August 2011, AFI formed a subsidiary professional organisation, the [[Australian Academy of Cinema and Television Arts]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/movies/afi-is-recast-with-new-academy-taking-a-bow-20110818-1izyb.html|title=AFI is recast with new academy taking a bow|publisher=Sydney Morning Herald|date=19 August 2011}}</ref>
==AFI Research Collection== The [http://www.afiresearch.rmit.edu.au AFI Research Collection] is a significant non-lending, specialist film and television industry resource. The collection operates under the auspices of [[RMIT University|Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology]]'s [[RMIT School of Media and Communication|School of Media and Communication]] in conjunction with the Australian Film Institute. The Collection has particular strengths in screen history and theory and in Australian cinema, and features a diverse range of books, journals, film scripts, film directories, reports and film festival catalogues.<ref name=afiresearch>[http://www.afi.org.au/AM/ContentManagerNet/ContentDisplay.aspx?ContentID=4815&Section=Research_Collection1 "AFI Research Collection"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091112040934/http://www.afi.org.au/AM/ContentManagerNet/ContentDisplay.aspx?ContentID=4815&Section=Research_Collection1 |date=November 12, 2009 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Cinema of Australia]] *[[Culture of Australia]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.aacta.org/ AFI website] *[http://www.mediasearch.com.au/film/spotlights/afiawards_2010 AFI Awards 2010 coverage] @ Mediasearch *[http://www.shiningalight.net AFI History]

{{Unreferenced|date=October 2009}} {{Infobox film |name = Bloodsport 4: The Dark Kumite |image = |caption = |director = Elvis Restaino |producer = Alan Mehrez |writer = George Saunders |narrator = |starring = [[Daniel Bernhardt]]
Stefanos Miltsakakis
Michael Krawic
[[Derek McGrath]]
Lisa Stothard |music = [[Alex Wurman]] |cinematography = George Mooradian |editing = Frank Sacco |distributor = [[Avalanche Home Entertainment]]
[[Lions Gate Entertainment]] ([[DVD]]) |released = February 15, 1999 |runtime = 100 mins |country = United States |language = English |budget = }} '''''Bloodsport 4: The Dark Kumite''''' is the fourth and final film in the [[Bloodsport (film)|Bloodsport]] [[Media franchise|franchise]]. It was released [[direct-to-video]] in 1999 and stars [[Daniel Bernhardt]] as [[police officer]] John Keller. ==Plot== Agent John Keller ([[Daniel Bernhardt]]) goes undercover into the tough [[prison]] known as Fuego Penal to find out about the corpses of prisoners disappearing without a trace. There he gets involved in a dangerous [[tournament]] arranged by a man named Justin Caesar (Ivan Ivanov), where the prisoners are forced to fight to the death. The tournament has only one rule: There are no rules. ==Cast== *[[Daniel Bernhardt]] – Agent John Keller * Ivan Ivanov - Justin Caesar * Lisa Stothard – Blaire * Stefanos Miltsakakis – Schrek * Michael Krawic – Winston *[[Derek McGrath]] – Warden Preston * David Rowe – Billings * Elvis Restaino – Dr. Rosenbloom * Dennis LaValle – Files * Christine Marais – Regina * Jeff Moldovan – Captain Anderson * Mike Kirton – Prison Guard * Mitko Kiskimov – Tongo * Linda Kouleva – Rita *[[Stefan Valdobrev]] – Gills ==Production== The [[prison]] [[Sequence (film)|sequences]] were shot at a real prison in [[Bulgaria]] and actual prisoners were [[Extra (actor)|extras]] in the [[Scene (film)|scenes]]. Although the film was shot in Bulgaria, ''Bloodsport 4'' is set in the United States. This not only makes it the only ''Bloodsport'' [[movie]] set there, but the only ''Bloodsport'' movie to not be set where it was shot. Though [[Daniel Bernhardt]] stars in all ''Bloodsport'' films except [[Bloodsport (film)|the first]], his [[Fictional character|character]] is not Alex Cardo from ''[[Bloodsport III]]'' but it is now John Keller in this film. ==Reception== The film was panned by critics. Robert Pardi of TvGuide gave the film one star and said: "The good news is that you needn't bother watching the first three BLOODSPORT flicks in order to make sense of this sequel. The bad news is that it's pure Grade-Z schlock." http://www.tvguide.com/movies/bloodsport-4-dark-kumite/review/134613/ ==International titles== *[[Argentina]]: ''Bloodsport: Matar O Morir'' (Bloodsport: Kill Or Die) *[[Brazil]]: ''O Grande Dragāo Branco 4: O Capítulo Final'' (The Great White Dragon 4: The Last Chapter) *[[Lithuania]]: ''Кровавый Спорт IV: Цвет Тьмы'' *[[Portugal]]: ''Bloodsport IV: Condenado À Morte'' (Bloodsport IV: Condemned To Death) *Spain: ''Contacto Sangriento 4: El Kumite Oscuro'' (Bloody Contact 4: The Dark Kumite) *UK: ''The Final Chapter: Bloodsport 4'' ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0172184}} *[http://s112269266.websitehome.co.uk/bernhardt/bloodsport4.htm film review] {{Bloodsport (film)}} [[Category:1999 films]] [[Category:1999 direct-to-video films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Bloodsport films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films shot in Bulgaria]] [[Category:Karate films]] [[Category:Martial arts tournament films]] [[Category:Underground fighting films]] [[Category:Sequel films]] [[Category:Direct-to-video sequel films]] {{Martialart-film-stub}}

{{primary sources|date=February 2009}}<!-- Need sources that show notability --> '''Cleversticks''' is a plastic [[Construction set|construction toy]] manufactured in the UK.
== The "Cleversticks Construction System" == {{references|section|date=April 2015}} The original design manufactured in [[polypropylene]] used sticks with pairs of jaws on each end and rings, the jaws connect onto the body of the sticks or rings, The jaws also connected the sticks end to end. The resulting toy was best suited to young children; with these few components a wide range of models could be assembled. Squares, triangles, rectangles and hexagon shapes were later added to allow the toy to be used for sorting into sets; the toy could now be used in primary education. Technical shapes were added to increase the complexity of the toy and appeal to older children. The most recent additions utilise the new patented design manufactured in [[Acrylonitrile butadiene styrene]] (ABS) including wheels with tyres manufactured in [[Santoprene]], a synthetic rubber.
== Patent, registered design, and trademark == The first patent in the UK GB 8313507 has a priority date of May 17, 1983, a [[United States patent law|US patent]] No 4548590 [http://www.wikipatents.com/4548590.html]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} was granted in October 1985. The most recent UK patent GB2417434 [http://www.wikipatents.com/gb/2417434.html]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} was granted on February 24, 2009. The following registered designs have also been obtained: UK No 2066049, UK No 2106334, Ger No 40204339.1, Aus 1447/2002 and UK No 3019498. The name CLEVERSTICKS was registered under the No 1557320 [http://www.ipo.gov.uk/types/tm/t-os/t-find/t-find-number?detailsrequested=C&trademark=1557320] as a GB trade mark in December 1993.
== External links == * [http://www.cleversticks.com Cleversticks] official site
[[Category:Construction toys]] [[Category:Toy brands]] [[Category:Toy companies of the United Kingdom]] {{Toy-stub}}

{{Multiple issues| {{primary sources|date=July 2010}} {{orphan|date=July 2010}} {{notability|Organizations|date=July 2010}} }} The '''Comic Book Collecting Association''', or CBCA, is an organization dedicated to promoting the hobby of comic book collecting. Its membership is composed of collectors, dealers, and other comic book enthusiasts. It is modeled after other hobbyist organizations such as the [[American Philatelic Society]] and the [[Universal Autograph Collectors Club]]."Comic Book Collecting Association Launched", ''Scoop'', February 24, 2010, "[http://scoop.diamondgalleries.com/public/default.asp?t=1&m=1&c=34&s=259&ai=92141]", March 24, 2010 The CBCA is a not-for-profit corporation registered in the State of California. ==History== The Comic Book Collecting Association was created in December 2009 by the members of another organization, now defunct, the [[Network of Disclosure]] (NOD). The Network of Disclosure was a group whose members pledged to disclose any restoration or enhancement on comic books that they sold. The members of NOD voted on December 12, 2009 to change the name and mission statement of the organization to reflect the much broader goal of promoting education, fellowship, and ethics within the hobby. As a result, the Network of Disclosure ceased to exist and the Comic Book Collecting Association was created."Comic Book Collecting Association Launched", ''Scoop'', February 24, 2010, "[http://scoop.diamondgalleries.com/public/default.asp?t=1&m=1&c=34&s=259&ai=92141]", March 24, 2010 The CBCA was publicly announced on February 22, 2010 on several comic book-related websites and publications. The organization has members in the United States and in several other countries. ==Aims== The Comic Book Collecting Association is a non-profit international organization made up of comic book enthusiasts who share an appreciation for the history, artistic merit, and significance of the comic book medium as an important element of popular culture. The aim of the CBCA is to promote the comic book art form and hobby of comic book collecting for people of all ages by encouraging fellowship among comic book enthusiasts, providing information and education to the public, and helping to facilitate the buying, selling, and trading of comic books and related material.Mission Statement, ''Comic Book Collecting Association'', "[http://www.comiccollecting.org]", March 24, 2010 ==Current and past Directors and Officers== '''Directors:''' * Patrick Beam (2009–present) * Mike Greenwood (2009–present) * Michael McMurray (2009–present) * Brent Moeshlin (2009–present) * Michael Naiman (2009–2010) * Steve Zarelli (2010–present) '''President:''' * Marnin Rosenberg (2009–2010) * Jeffrey Shanks (2010–present) '''Vice President:''' * Jeffrey Shanks (2009–2010) '''Secretary:''' * Mitch Jordan (2009–2010) '''Treasurer:''' * Rob Kruezer (2009–2010) '''Marketing Director''' * Mark Zaid (2010–Present) '''Legal Counsel''' * Josh Entin (2009–2010) ==Events== On July 25, 2009, the NOD was one of the sponsors of a presentation made at the San Diego Comic-Con called "From Cave Art To Superheroes: Comic Books & Social Commentary". This presentation was made by Mark Zaid."From Cave Art To Superheroes: Comic Books & Social Commentary","http://vimeo.com/6690892",September 21, 2009 On June 2, 2010, Chris A. Tsuda of San Francisco, California was the Grand Prize winner of the first CBCA Amateur Art Contest.[http://www.comiccollecting.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=26&t=1238 The CBCA Amateur Art Contest - And the winners are...] On August 27, 2010, the CBCA coordinated a trip to view the original artwork of [[Amazing Fantasy]] #15 and some of the comics housed in the collection of the Library of Congress."CBCA Visits Library of Congress, Sees Ditko Art","http://scoop.diamondgalleries.com/public/default.asp?t=1&m=1&c=34&s=259&ai=99726",September 10, 2010 ==Publications== The CBCA publishes a newsletter, ''Comic Book Quarterly'', four times a year. It contains updates on the organization, articles, market reports, and material related to the hobby of comic book collecting.''Comic Book Quarterly'', No. 3, Spring 2010"[https://docs.google.com/fileview?id=0B-NJflbiZN6QNWZlODg4ZDktYjBkYi00ZDJmLWE5OWUtZjhiODViM2I0YzFl&hl=en&pli=1]", June 23, 2010 ==Notes== On February 22, 2010 Mark Zaid, the Marketing Director of the CBCA, was quoted in an Associated Press article about the sale of a copy of [[Action Comics]] #1."Copy of 1938's Action Comics No. 1, featuring debut of Superman, sells for record $1 million", www.nydailynews.com, "http://www.nydailynews.com/money/2010/02/22/2010-02-22_copy_of_1938s_action_comics_no_1_featuring_debut_of_superman_sells_for_record_1_.html", February 22, 2010 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.comiccollecting.org Comic Book Collecting Association] [[Category:Comic book collecting]] [[Category:Nonprofit hobbyist organizations based in the United States]]

{{About|the deaths of characters in comic books|the personification of death in comic books|Death (comics)}} [[Image:Uncanny136.jpg|thumb|right|Cover to ''Uncanny X-Men'' #136 (August 1980, art by [[John Byrne (comics)|John Byrne]]), the penultimate issue of the "[[Dark Phoenix]]" saga. [[Jean Grey]] would sacrifice herself in the following issue, but [[Marvel Comics|Marvel]] later had the story [[Retroactive continuity|retconned]] to allow Jean to appear in the new ''[[X-Factor (comics)|X-Factor]]'' series.]] In the [[comic book]] fan community, the apparent [[death]] and subsequent return of a long-running [[Character (arts)|character]] is often called a '''comic book death'''. A comic book death is generally not taken seriously by readers and is rarely permanent or meaningful other than for story or thematic purposes.
==Context== Commenting on the impact and role of comic book character deaths, writer [[Geoff Johns]] said:<ref>IGN Geoff Johns: Inside Blackest Night</ref>
{{quote|Death in superhero comics is cyclical in its nature, and that's for a lot of reasons, whether they are story reasons, copyright reasons, or fan reasons.}}
The phenomenon of comic book death is particularly common for superhero characters. Writer [[Danny Fingeroth]] suggests that the nature of superheroes requires that they be both [[ageless]] and [[immortality|immortal]].<ref>James R. Fleming, [http://www.english.ufl.edu/imagetext/archives/v2_2/reviews/fleming.shtml Review of ''Superman on the Couch: What Superheroes Really Tell Us about Ourselves and Our Society''], ''ImageTexT: Interdisciplinary Comics Studies'', vol. 2, no. 2, Winter 2006.</ref>
A common expression regarding comic book death was once "The only people who stay dead in comics are [[Bucky Barnes|Bucky]], [[Jason Todd]], and [[Uncle Ben]],"<ref name="opinionjournal2007">[http://www.opinionjournal.com/la/?id=110009780 Captain America, RIP], para. 5, ''Wall Street Journal'', March 13, 2007</ref> referring to the seminal importance of those characters' deaths to the title character: [[Captain America]]'s [[sidekick]] (retconned dead in 1964), Batman's second [[Robin (comics)|Robin]] (dead in 1988), and [[Spider-Man]]'s uncle (dead since 1962), respectively. This long-held tenet was broken in 2005, when Jason Todd returned to life as the [[Red Hood (Jason Todd)|Red Hood]] and Bucky was reported to have survived the accident that seemingly killed him, brought back in 2005 as the [[Winter Soldier (comics)|Winter Soldier]], remaining in the shadows for decades. Barnes apparently died again in 2011 after a short tenure as Captain America,<ref>{{Cite comic|writer=[[Fraction, Matt]]|penciller=[[Immonen, Stuart]]|inker=von Grawbadger, Wade|story=Chapter 3: The Hammer That Fell On Yancy Street|title=Fear Itself|issue=3|date=August 2011|publisher=Marvel Comics}}</ref> only to be revived by [[Nick Fury]]'s Infinity Formula.<ref>''Fear Itself'' #7.1 (2011), Marvel Comics.</ref>
Because death in comics is so often temporary, readers rarely take the death of a character seriously—when a character dies, the reader feels very little sense of loss, and simply left wondering how long it will be before they return to life.<ref>https://www.empireonline.com/movies/features/comic-book-deaths/</ref><ref>https://www.cbr.com/the-most-memorable-shocking-comic-book-deaths/</ref><ref>https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/logan-how-handled-death-comic-books-981835</ref><ref>https://books.google.se/books?id=raV6qalYZKwC&pg=PA194</ref>
==Notable examples== Although several comic book deaths are well-known, two of the best-known are the 1980 "death" of [[Jean Grey]] in Marvel's "[[The Dark Phoenix Saga|Dark Phoenix Saga]]" and that of [[Superman]] in [[DC Comics|DC]]'s highly publicized 1993 "[[The Death of Superman|Death of Superman]]" storyline. There is one major distinction between the two, however—whereas it was never intended that Superman's death be permanent, but rather that he would return to life at the conclusion of the story,<ref>{{cite web| url = http://goodcomics.comicbookresources.com/2007/03/29/comic-book-urban-legends-revealed-96/| title = Comic Book Urban Legends Revealed # 96| author = Brian Cronin| date = March 29, 2007| publisher = Comic Book Resources}}</ref> Jean's passing was intended to be permanent, as the editor [[Jim Shooter]] felt that would be the only satisfactory outcome given that she had committed [[mass murder]].<ref>"The Dark Phoenix Tapes", ''Phoenix: The Untold Story'' #1 (April 1984)</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ginocchio|first=Mark|title=10 Amazing Storylines Derailed by Editorial Politics|url=http://whatculture.com/comics/10-amazing-comic-storylines-derailed-editorial-politics.php/8|work=What Culture|accessdate=13 May 2014}}</ref> Despite this, the story was [[Retroactive continuity|retconned]] a few years later to facilitate Jean's return.
In 2007, the death of [[Captain America]] made real-world headlines<ref name="opinionjournal2007"/><ref>http://www.newsweek.com/comics-captain-america-1941-2007-95787</ref><ref>http://abcnews.go.com/US/story?id=2934283</ref><ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/08/books/08capt.html</ref><ref>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/mar/08/usa.arts</ref><ref>https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=18520433</ref> when he met his apparent end, but Steve Rogers returned in ''[[Captain America: Reborn]]'' in late 2009.<ref>http://edition.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/06/15/captain.america/index.html</ref><ref>http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/music-arts/captain-america-steve-rogers-coming-back-life-years-marvel-comics-killed-article-1.376815</ref>
==In universe acknowledgement== Comic book characters themselves have made comments about the frequency of resurrections. [[Professor X]] has commented "in mutant heaven there are no pearly gates, but instead revolving doors."<ref>''X-Factor'' #70 page 17, panel 1</ref> When [[Siryn]] was made aware of [[Banshee (comics)|her father]]'s death, she refused to [[Mourning|mourn]] him, giddily claiming that since her father has died as an [[X-Men|X-Man]], he was likely going to be soon resurrected, shocking her friends.<ref>[[David, Peter]] (w), [[Olivetti, Ariel]] (a). "Two Meetings, One In Person, One Not", ''[[X-Factor (comics)|X-Factor]]'' (vol 3) #7 (July 2006). Marvel Comics.</ref> Her father is later restored to life but is recruited by the [[Apocalypse Twins]] as part of their new [[Horsemen of Apocalypse]].<ref>''Uncanny Avengers'' #9 (June 2013). Marvel Comics.</ref> The obituary writer of the in-universe newspaper the ''[[Daily Bugle]]'' once bemoaned to reporter [[Ben Urich]] about how many retractions he has had to write after each resurrection of a superhero or [[supervillain]].<ref>''Spider-Man Unlimited'' vol.1 #18. Marvel Comics.</ref>
==See also== *[[Soap opera]], radio drama and television genre also known for such character deaths <!--And this is explicitly mentioned there-->
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathIsCheap Death Is Cheap] at the [[TV Tropes]]
{{Superhero fiction}} {{Comics}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Comic Book Death}} [[Category:Continuity (fiction)]] [[Category:Comics terminology]] [[Category:Narratology]] [[Category:Superhero fiction]] [[Category:Death in fiction]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} {{Use British English|date=July 2012}} {{italic title}} '''''Cupid and Death''''' is a mid-seventeenth-century [[masque]], written by the [[Literature in English#Caroline and Cromwellian literature|Caroline]] era dramatist [[James Shirley]], and performed on 26 March [[1653 in literature|1653]] before the Portuguese ambassador to Great Britain. The work and its performance provide a point of contradiction to the standard view that the England of [[Oliver Cromwell]] and the [[English Interregnum|Interregnum]] was uniformly hostile to stage drama.<ref>A History Of Western Music by Donald Jay Grout (First Published 1962 (UK) by J.M. Dent & Sons Ltd, London) - Chapter 10: The Mature Baroque: Vocal Music - p318 ''"Masques continued to be given privately throughout the period of the Civil war (1642 - 49), the Commonwealth (1649 - 60) and the early years of the Restoration of Charles II (reg. 1660 - 85). The most elaborate of these private entertainments was Cupid and Death (1653)..."''</ref>
==Background== After the [[closure of the theatres in 1642]] at the start of the [[English Civil War]], Shirley earned a living as a schoolteacher. As part of his new occupation, he wrote dramas — morality plays and masques — for his students to perform. The final works of his career, including ''[[Honoria and Mammon]]'' and ''[[The Contention of Ajax and Ulysses]]'' (both published in 1659), were works for student performers. ''Cupid and Death'' is another work in this category, though its resemblances with the great masques of the late [[House of Stuart|Stuart]] Court have been noted by critics — it "is much more like a Court Masque than any of Shirley's other school Masques".<ref>Edward Dent, quoted in Logan and Smith, p. 160.</ref> Perhaps this aspect of the work made it seem appropriate for the Portuguese ambassador, the Count of Peneguiaõ. Shirley's past Royalist connections with the Stuart Court, and even his [[Roman Catholicism]], clearly (if surprisingly) did not stand as insuperable obstacles to a public staging of the work.<ref>Clare, pp. 153-4.</ref>
==Publication== ''Cupid and Death'' was first published in [[book size|quarto]] in 1653, by the booksellers John Crook and John Baker. It was reprinted in [[1659 in literature|1659]]. The full musical score for the masque, by [[Matthew Locke (composer)|Matthew Locke]] and [[Christopher Gibbons]], has survived, and was published together with Shirley's text in a modern edition in 1951.<ref>By Edward J. Dent, in ''Musica Britanica,'' Vol. 2 (1951).</ref>
==Sources== The drama depends on a traditional tale, found in [[Aesop]] and many subsequent versions. For his source, Shirley employed a [[1651 in literature|1651]] translation of Aesop by [[John Ogilby]], with whom he'd worked at the [[Werburgh Street Theatre]] in the later 1630s. Shirley wrote [[commendatory verse]]s for Ogilby's volume.
==Plot== In the tale and in Shirley's retelling, Death and Cupid accidentally exchange their arrows and cause chaos as a result. Cupid shoots potential lovers and inadvertently kills them. Death shoots at elderly people whose time of passing has come, and strikes them ardent instead; he shoots duellists about to fight, and they drop their swords to embrace and dance and sing. The "serious" portion of the masque features the kind of personifications standard in the masque form: Nature, Folly, Madness, and Despair. As usual in masques of Shirley's era, the work contains a comic anti-masque, with a tavern Host and a Chamberlain, and a dance of "[[Satyr]]s and Apes." (The poor Chamberlain is struck by Death with Cupid's arrow, and falls in love with an ape.) The god [[Mercury (mythology)|Mercury]] eventually intervenes to set things right; Cupid is banished from the courts of princes to common people's cottages (a suitably sober moral for the [[Puritan]] regime then in power). The slain lovers are shown rejoicing in [[Elysium]].
"''Cupid and Death'' resembles Caroline masque in its use of staging, music, dance, singing and dialogue. Yet it differs in that the masquers take part in the action and they do not dance with the audience at the end...The balance between spoken prose dialogue, recitative and song carries the performance away from masque and towards [[opera]], a form [[William Davenant|Davenant]] planned to introduce to the London stage as early as 1639."<ref>Corns, p. 276.</ref>
''Cupid and Death'' was performed at [[Rutland Boughton]]'s Glastonbury Festival in 1919,<ref>Rose, p. 29.</ref> by the Consorte of Musicke (notably [[Anthony Rooley]] and [[Emma Kirkby]]) in 1985, and by the [[Halastó Kórus]] (directed by [[Göttinger Pál]]) in Budapest in 2008.
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==Sources== * Clare, Janet. ''Drama of the English Republic, 1649–60.'' Manchester, Manchester University Press, 2006. * Corns, Thomas N. ''A History of Seventeenth-Century English Literature.'' London, Blackwell, 2007. * Logan, Terence P., and Denzell S. Smith, eds. ''The Later Jacobean and Caroline Dramatists: A Survey and Bibliography of Recent Studies in English Renaissance Drama.'' Lincoln, NE, University of Nebraska Press, 1978. * Rose, Martial. ''Forever Juliet,'' Dereham, Norfolk, Larks Press, 2003.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cupid and Death}} [[Category:English Renaissance plays]] [[Category:1653 plays]] [[Category:Masques]]

revision.comment: added [[Category:1959 establishments in the Netherlands]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
[[File:Efsilandrover.JPG|thumb|300px|right|Efsi Matchbox sized Land Rover 'Red Cross'.]] '''Efsi''' was a [[Dutch people|Dutch]] company making [[Die-cast toy|diecast]] cars and trucks starting in 1959 under the '''Bestbox''' name. The company could be considered the [[Matchbox Toys]] of the Netherlands, but its origins and purpose as a government sponsored employer was far less commercial than other toy manufacturers. Efsi was based in Heerlen, the [[Netherlands]], which is located in southern [[Limburg (Netherlands)|Limburg province]].
==History== In 1959 (some sources say 1962), Bestbox started making simple diecast cars in [[Limburg (Netherlands)|Limburg province]] (Bickford 2009). The Dutch Wiki site reports that in the 1960s, the coal mines in Limburg closed. Some significant post-mining industries where workers relocated were automobile producers DAF and Nedcar in Born. After the closure, [[DSM (company)| DSM]] (The Dutch State Mines) tried providing new employment to out-of-work or disabled miners in different shops or factories. These 'WIM' workshops (Workshop for Disabled Miners) were backed by a national Fund for Social Institutions (FSI).
One of the activities was to continue the production of Best-box models. Later the name was changed to EFSI, apparently a phonetic pronunciation of FSI (EFSI Dutch Wiki page; see also EFSI Made in Holland, 2010–2011). The Bestbox name was discontinued in 1971, perhaps because of the similarity to the name (and competition) of [[Matchbox (brand)|Matchbox]] toys (Breithaupt 2001). Though similar to Matchbox, and popular locally, Efsi toys do not seem to have been too well known outside the Netherlands (Rixon 2005, p. 85). Most Efsi products were marked "Made in Holland" (as opposed to 'Made in the Netherlands') on the base.
==Typical vehicles== ===Early offerings=== [[File:Efsi - B.R.M. F1.jpg|thumb|300px|left|B.R.M. Formula 1 race car. This car, in the F1 series was the first to be made by Efsi. Previously they had been sold under the "Bestbox" label - a name reminiscent of "Matchbox".]] Among EFSI's first vehicles were a set of 1960s [[Formula One cars]] including [[Ferrari]], [[Brabham]], [[Honda]], [[Lotus Cars|Lotus]], and [[Maserati|Cooper Maserati]] (Breithaupt 2001; Rixon 2005, p. 85). These were first marketed under the Best Box name and had realistic engines, thick black tires and realistic, solid appearing, deep-set wheels. Several other vehicles were also marketed under the Best Box label, like a Citroen Dyan sedan. Another popular line were a very [[Matchbox (brand)|Matchbox]]-like series of diecast bodied [[Ford Model T]] vehicles in various forms including coupe, sedan, pickup, delivery van, delivery van in fire engine livery (with ladder), tanker, and wrecker truck. Some Model T versions had diecast bases, but plastic bodies. Overall, these were simple but attractive models, produced since the Best Box days, then later cast with the Efsi name up to about 1980 or beyond. The Model T delivery van was made in several liveries like Harrod's, Cadbury, and George Travis wholesale confectioner. Even later, many Efsi vehicles were closely duplicated by Spain's [[Auto Pilen]] (Bras 2012a; Bras 2012b; Breithaupt 2001). [[File:Bestbox2512citroendyane.JPG|thumb|300px|An early Best Box Citroen Dyane sedan. Note the simple unadorned plastic wheels. Note the strangely shaped headlights.]] Other cars, like a [[Jaguar XKE|Jaguar XKE convertible]], [[BMW]] coupe, and a [[Citroën DS]] ambulance were also made. Many EFSI cars were a bit smaller than those made by [[Matchbox (brand)|Matchbox]] and some dies seemed very close to Matchbox - like the [[Mercedes-Benz 280]] convertible and a Mercedes-Benz flat bed truck. One earlier [[Ford Transit]] van casting appears similar to one made by Zylmex around 1990, so EFSI appears to have participated in the common practice of buying tooling and also selling it to companies in other countries.
===HO trucks=== Many Efsi dies were made by a company in [[Portugal]], though models themselves were made in the Netherlands (Efsi-toys 2006). In the 1980s, EFSI became known for its HO scale truck and bus lines. Early trucks were Dutch [[DAF trucks | DAFs]] but a Mercedes-Benz cab (long and short wheelbase) and a [[Commer]] van were also common (Bickford 2009; Rixon 2005, p. 97). Varied liveries were seen, often of Dutch or mainland European products like [[Philips]], [[KLM]] airlines, [[Miele]] appliances, Intertrans Freight Logistics, and Libeltex nonwoven materials (EFSI Made in Holland, 2010–2011; Johnson 1998, pp. 65–66; Rixon 2005, p. 97). Other international companies like Exxon Escorenes, Pirelli, Hurlimann Beer, Chiquita Bananas, and Safeway Foods were also done. One truck, a FIAT van with sliding side door was often seen with automobile ads (FIAT or Citroen) or with Police or 'Gendarmerie', according to language. Just as often, though, trucks were produced clean, without any livery at all. One bus, a [[VDL Bova | Bova Futura]], was made in at least 15 different liveries.
Early trucks were produced with a basic unadorned black wheel design, while later ones incorporated a triangular chrome wheel that looked a lot like a Majorette design. Packaging in the 1980s was simple as trucks were held in flimsy plastic containers with an EFSI identification sticker on the lower side of the container. Later, more design and color was incorporated on a cardboard blister, but, still, the presentation was simpler than more developed diecast companies - no printing was usually seen on the back of the blister card. One interesting aspect of packaging was the eight sided STOP sign in red seen on the blister packages for EFSI Toys. The sign, which says "code" right next to it, seems to be a warning that the toy is unsafe for children under a certain age. Most EFSI toys were stamped 'Holland' or 'Made in Holland'. Blister packs for smaller trucks and cars were variously marked as Efsi RevWheels, Efsi Toppers, or Efsi Plus (Bras 2012a).
==Holland Oto== Around 1988, apparently when the disabled miner program was discontinued, the company name was changed to '''Holland Oto''', which is still in operation, making contemporary models of trucks, buses, and agricultural vehicles (Bickford 2009, Holland-Oto Miniaturen 2010). Today, Holland-Oto is headquartered in [[Weert]], just southeast of [[Eindhoven]], but north of the Heerlen home of the former Efsi establishment in Limburg. While earlier Efsi packaging was either white or yellow or some combination of the two, the Holland Oto vehicles were generally the same products, but now in a blue and orange package (Bras 2012a).
Holland Oto had connections with Dutch AHC, and thus today has connections to the JOAL and [[Auto Pilen|Pilen]] enterprises in Spain (Breithaupt 2001). For example, in 1980, Pilen S.A. introduced new vehicles. These were the former Model Ts rebadged and some of the typical Efsi HO trucks - though re-engineered by Pilen with that company's considerable talent for diecast refinement (Bras 2012b). Besides Joal, today Holland-Oto is affiliated with or owns Universal Hobbies, Motorart diecast cars and construction vehicles, HiSpeed diecast classic vehicles, and Kids' Globe Farming toys (Holland-Oto Miniaturen 2010).
== See also == * [[Siku Toys]]
==References== * Bickford, Keith. 2009. Bestbox/Efsi (Holland). Bickford's Diecast Oddities. Presented by the Bickford Diecast Research Center. [http://www.kbickford.com/AlphaB.html] * Bras, Jorge. 2012a. Efsi Toys. Photobucket picture collection. [http://s239.photobucket.com/albums/ff200/JorgeBras/efsi%20toys/] * Bras Jorge. 2012b. Pilen Catalogo 1980. Photobucket member profile. [http://s239.photobucket.com/profile/JorgeBras] * Breithaupt, Doug. 2001. Dutch Treat: The EFSI/Bestbox Story. Toy Collector webpage. [http://www.breithaupts.com/totc214.htm] * EFSI Made in Holland. 2010-2011. Webstring forum. Forum Auto. Caradisiac.com. [http://www.forum-auto.com/automobile-pratique/modelisme-modeles-reduits/sujet5415-35.htm] * Efsi-toys. 2006. Onze produkten ("Our Production). Website of Efsi-toys, a public Dutch site. [http://www.efsi-toys.nl/?Onze_produkten] * Holland-Oto Miniaturen. 2010. Company website. [http://www.hollandoto.nl/default.aspx?page=200&switchToLang=EN] * Johnson, Dana. 1998. ''Collector's Guide to Diecast Toys & Scale Models'', second edition. Padukah, Kentucky: Collector Books, A Division of Schroeder Publishing. * Rixon, Peter. 2005. ''Miller's Collecting Diecast Vehicles''. London: Miller's, a division of Mitchell Beazley.
[[Category:Die-cast toys]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1959]] [[Category:Model manufacturers]] [[Category:Toy brands]] [[Category:Toy cars and trucks]] [[Category:1960s toys]] [[Category:Toy companies of the Netherlands]] [[Category:1959 establishments in the Netherlands]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox award | name = Ernie Awards | description = comments deemed misogynistic | venue = NSW Parliament House | year = 1993 }} The '''Ernie Awards''' are [[Australia]]n awards for comments deemed misogynistic.
It is named after former [[Australian Workers' Union]] secretary Ernie Ecob, who was known for his misogynistic remarks. One of his best-known remarks was "Women aren't welcome in the shearing sheds. They're only after the sex," which is why there is a sheep on top of the Gold Ernie.<ref name="Mondo">[http://www.abc.net.au/thingo/txt/s1180534.htm Meredith Bergmann of the Ernie Awards] [[Mondo Thingo]]</ref> The inaugural awards night was in celebration of him resigning from the [[Labor Council of New South Wales]].<ref name="WO87">[http://workers.labor.net.au/87/a_guestreporter_alison.html What’s Wrong With The Ernies] Workers Online, [[Labor Council of New South Wales]]</ref>
A dinner is held for 300 women each year<ref name="Mondo"/> and the winner is determined by the person who receives the most booing when their sexist statement or action is read out.<ref name="SheikFeizWins">[http://www.theage.com.au/news/National/Sheikh-wins-gong-for-sexist-comments/2005/08/12/1123353483833.html Sheikh wins gong for sexist comments] [[The Age]], 12 August 2005</ref>
A variety of categories have featured, such as the Gold Ernie, the Warney (for sport, named after [[Shane Warne]]), the Media Ernie, the Political Ernie, the Judicial Ernie, the Anon (for boys behaving better, formerly called the Gareth after [[Gareth Evans (politician)|Gareth Evans]]<ref name="WO152"> [http://workers.labor.net.au/152/c_tradeshall_ernie.html The Importance of Being Ernie] Workers Online, [[Labor Council of New South Wales]]</ref>), the Elaine (for females making comments unhelpful to the [[Sisterhood (feminism)|sisterhood]], named after [[Elaine Nile]]<ref name="WO152"/>) and the Trump (for repeat offenders).<ref name="Mondo"/> The categories of offenders have changed over the years, according to [[Meredith Burgmann]].<ref name="SheilasMockersOckers">[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/nov/11/australia.gender Sheilas put the mockers on ockers] [[The Observer]], 11 November 2007</ref>
A collection of comments have been compiled in "One Thousand Terrible Things Australian Men Have Said About Women" by [[Meredith Burgmann]] and [[Yvette Andrews]].<ref name="SheilasMockersOckers"/>
==Winners==
===Gold Ernie===
* 1993: [[Joe de Bruyn]], National Secretary, [[Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association]]: "All childcare subsidies should be removed and reallocated to women who stayed home to mind their children." * 1994: [[Terry Griffiths (Australian politician)|Terry Griffiths]], former New South Wales Liberal minister (in response to allegations of sexually harassing his staff): "I honestly believe that my personal behaviour was in a family mode. They're like my own kids. I'm a toucher...I have a habit of touching people in that regard. I'm old fashioned." * 1995: Justice John Gallop, [[Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court]] (upon imposing a bond upon a man convicted of raping a 12-year-old girl): "Our jails would be full if we locked up everyone who did this." * 1996: Magistrate [[Ron Gething]], [[Magistrates Court of Western Australia]] (upon finding a man not guilty of stalking a woman for seven years): "I don't think he was intimidating her, he was just being persistent. He was like a little puppy dog wagging its tail." * 1997: [[Michael Knight (Australian politician)|Michael Knight]], New South Wales state Minister for the Olympics (on why there were originally no women on the board of the [[Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games]]): "Appointments are made on merit, not sex." * 1998: Judge Nigel Clarke, [[District Court of Western Australia]] (upon giving a two-year suspended sentence to a man for sexually abusing his daughter): "Indulgence is a pleasurable, curiosity-satisfying activity by an intelligent precocious girl." * 1999: "Magistrate #1" (in a case reviewed by the Judicial Commission): "Women cause a lot of problems by nagging, bitching and emotionally hurting men. Men cannot bitch back for hormonal reasons, and often have no recourse but violence." * 2000: Nick Bideau, ex-coach and partner of [[Cathy Freeman]]: "I never turned away from Cathy...no matter how fat she was in 1997, and even in 1998." * 2001: [[John Howard]], Prime Minister: for saying that there was "no appropriate woman" for [[Governor-General of Australia|Governor-General]]. * 2002: Archbishop [[George Pell]], Catholic Archbishop of Sydney: "Abortion is a worse moral scandal than priests sexually abusing young people." * 2003: Stellar Call Centre: for docking the pay of a pregnant woman for taking too many toilet breaks. * 2004: [[Tooheys]]: for an advertisement stating "Boys, if you win you can have our sisters". * 2005: Sheikh [[Feiz Mohammad]], Islamic cleric: "A victim of rape every minute somewhere in the world. Why? No one to blame but herself. She displayed her beauty to the entire world...strapless, backless, sleeveless, nothing but satanic skirts, slit skirts, translucent blouses, miniskirts, tight jeans...to tease man and appeal to his carnal nature." * 2006: [[P&O Cruises]]: for the advertising slogans "More Girls. More Sun. More Fun. There's nothing else a guy needs to know!" and "Seamen Wanted!" * 2007: [[Bill Heffernan]]. New South Wales Liberal Senator: for saying that [[Julia Gillard]] was not qualified to lead the country because she is "deliberately barren", and later justifying it with "I won't walk away from that...so rude, crude and attractive as it was...if you're a leader, you've got to understand your community." * 2008: John Molony: for calling on "beauty-disadvantaged women" to consider moving to the remote Australian mining town of [[Mount Isa]] in north-west Queensland where he is mayor. * 2009: Pastor [[Danny Nalliah]]: for blaming the [[Black Saturday bushfires]] on Victoria's abortion laws.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pastor Danny Nalliah wins top gong at Ernie Awards|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/lifestyle/the-other-side/pastor-danny-nalliah-wins-top-gong-at-ernie-awards/story-e6frfhk6-1225781393701|publisher=Herald Sun|date=1 October 2009}}</ref> * 2010: Students of [[St Paul's College, University of Sydney|St. Paul's College, Sydney]]: for their "Define Statutory" group on Facebook.<ref name="smh10">{{cite news|title=Abbott stars at sexist awards night|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/abbott-stars-at-sexist-awards-night-20100917-15eyc.html|publisher=Sydney Morning Herald|date=17 September 2010}}</ref> * 2011: [[Herald Sun]] journalist [[Andrew Bolt]]: for saying 'Can the ADF afford this social engineering, in which gender becomes a qualification - and a fault line? What will this do to the tight mateship so critical to a fighting unit? Does a woman turn her male colleagues from warriors to escort?' <ref>[http://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/celebrity/andrew-bolt-receives-ernie-award-for-2011-20111018-1ltr1.html Andrew Bolt receives 2011 Ernie award]</ref> * 2012: [[2GB]] radio broadcaster [[Alan Jones (radio broadcaster)|Alan Jones]]: for saying 'Women are destroying the joint, [[Christine Nixon]] in Melbourne, [[Clover Moore]] here, honestly there is no chaff bag big enough for these people.' <ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-09-27/jones-wins-ernie-for-sexist-comments/4283948 Jones wins Ernie for sexist comments]</ref> * 2013: [[Wesley College, University of Sydney]] students for distributing [[stubby holder]]s bearing the words “It’s not rape if it’s my birthday.”<ref name="2013 Ernie Award Winners">[http://ernies.com.au/news/2013-ernie-award-winners/ 2013 Ernie Award Winners]</ref> * 2014: [[Christopher Pyne]], for claiming that increases in uni fees won't disproportionately affect women because "women are well-represented amongst the teaching and nursing students. They will not be able to earn the high incomes that dentists and lawyers will earn".<ref name="2014 Ernie Award Winners">[http://www.dailylife.com.au/news-and-views/news-features/christoper-pyne-wins-ernie-award-2014-for-his-comments-on-the-impact-of-uni-fees-on-women-20140925-3gjsu.html 2014 Ernie Award Winners]</ref> * 2015: [[Football Federation Australia]], for paying the [[Australia women's national soccer team|Matildas]] an annual salary of $21,000 per year, which is below the minimum wage. The women receive $500 for each international game, while their male counterparts in the [[Socceroos]] receive $6,000.<ref name="2015 Ernie Award Winners">[http://www.dailylife.com.au/news-and-views/news-features/football-federation-australia-takes-out-the-2015-gold-ernie-for-matildas-pay-gap-20150924-gjumib.html 2015 Ernie Award Winners]</ref> *2016: Barrister Ben Mallick, for defending a taxi driver accused of sexual assault saying, "the attack would not have happened if the woman had sat in the back seat" and the [[Department of Education (New South Wales)|NSW Department of Education]], for its policy that experienced teachers who take five years off to raise children should return to work on a graduate salary.<ref name="2016 Ernie Award Winners">http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-09-23/sexist-remarks-of-the-year-awarded-at-the-ernies/7870748 2016 Ernie Award Winners]</ref> * 2017: [[Port Stephens Council|Port Stephens]] mayor Bruce MacKenzie, for pleading guilty to assaulting his partner but still wanting a domestic violence shelter to be named after him.<ref name="2017 Ernie Award Winners">http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-09-22/ernie-awards-2017-mark-latham-andrew-bolt/8973752 2016 Ernie Award Winners]</ref>

Julia Gillard’s got to watch out.' * 2013: [[Wesley College, University of Sydney]] students for distributing stubby holders bearing the words “It’s not rape if it’s my birthday.”<ref name="2013 Ernie Award Winners"/> * 2014: [[Wicked Campers]], for including slogans such as "Fat girls are harder to kidnap", "In every princess, there's a little slut who wants to try it just once" and "Life sucks if your girlfriend doesn't".<ref name="2014 Ernie Award Winners"/> * 2015: [[Soho House (club)|Soho Club]], for running an advertisement appearing to carry connotations of sexual assault a week after the owner's son, Luke Lazarus, was convicted of rape.<ref name="2015 Ernie Award Winners"/> * 2016: The [[Department of Education (New South Wales)|NSW Department of Education]], for its policy that experienced teachers who take five years off to raise children should return to work on a graduate salary.<ref name="2016 Ernie Award Winners"/> * 2017: [[Ford Motor Company]], for dismissing complaints on the [[Ford Focus]] losing power to an issue with the way women drove.

They will not be able to earn the high incomes that dentists and lawyers will earn".<ref name="2014 Ernie Award Winners"/> * 2015: [[Tony Abbott]], for saying that his greatest achievement as [[Minister for Women (Australia)|Minister for Women]] was the repeal of the carbon tax.<ref name="2015 Ernie Award Winners"/> * 2016: [[Mark Latham]], for saying that domestic violence is a "coping mechanism" for men and saying domestic violence campaigner [[Rosie Batty]] was "demonising men" and making men who hit women "feel worse about themselves". * 2017: [[Port Stephens Council|Port Stephens]] mayor Bruce MacKenzie, for pleading guilty to assaulting his partner but still wanting a domestic violence shelter to be named after him

Even the cartoon character Peppa Pig pushes a weird feminist line that would be closer to the hearts of Labor's Handbag Hit Squad than the pre-school audience it is aimed at".<ref name="2014 Ernie Award Winners"/> * 2015: ''[[The Australian]]'', for in their obituary of [[Colleen McCollough]], describing the late author as "plain of feature and certainly overweight".<ref name="2015 Ernie Award Winners"/> * 2016: [[Andrew Bolt]], for saying it was difficult to debate [[Linda Burney]] because she was "gorgeous" and a woman. * 2017: [[Andrew Bolt]], for remarking on a [[Australian Human Rights Commission|Human Rights Commission]] report which found that 51% of university students were sexually harassed last year, “Yes, we should be shocked and visibly upset... that the Commission perpetrated such a hoax. * 1994: Justices Bland and Bollen * 1995: Justice [[John Gallop]] * 1996: Magistrate [[Ron Gething]] * 1997: Judge Nigel Clarke * 1998: Judge Nigel Clarke * 1999: Magistrate #1: in response to a survey about domestic violence and apprehended violence orders, saying "hallelujah, women cause a lot of problems by nagging, bitching, and emotionally hurting men. Men cannot bitch back for hormonal reasons and often have no recourse but violence".<ref name="AM1999"/> * 2000: Justice Kennedy * 2001: Magistrate [[Steven Scarlett]] * 2002: [[High Court of Australia]] * 2003: Justice [[Roddy Meagher]] * 2004: Paul Reynolds: for saying to his client "just let me feel those puppies then"<ref name="TonyWinner"/> (referring to her breasts)<ref name="Barristersuspended">[http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/04/25/1082831435141.html Barrister suspended after asking for sex] [[The Age]], 26 April 2004</ref> * 2005: John Dorris and [[Ian Harrison (judge)|Ian Harrison]] * 2006: Chris Papadopoulos: for saying that a rape was "at the very bottom of the scale of seriousness" and brief.<ref name="Well-erned"/> * 2008: [[Roland Day]] * 2011: Clayton Utz for saying why there were only 20% women partners: "Certainly they are all females but each of them are extremely competent lawyers." * 2012: Senior Constable Cary Coolican, for saying "Many sexual assault victims were too drunk or stoned to remember the details of the attacks… we would be encouraging people to make responsible choices regarding who they drink with and the quantity that is consumed. Some decisions may result in risky behaviour and unsafe actions." * 2013: Professor Paul Wilson: “My findings were remarkably similar to studies in California and Scandinavia which suggest child victims of adult sex offenders are generally willing or active participants, and that they not infrequently initiate the sexual relationship.”<ref name="2013 Ernie Award Winners"/> * 2014: Philip Stricklan QC, for suggesting that former MP Jodie McKay's recall of a conversation might not be accurate because she was in "an emotional state".<ref name="2014 Ernie Award Winners"/> * 2015: Detective Inspector Michael Hughes, for commenting after the murder of [[Masa Vuketic]] that women should protect themselves from daylight attacks by not going outside unaccompanied.<ref name="2015 Ernie Award Winners"/> * 2016: Barrister Ben Mallick, for defending a taxi driver accused of sexual assault saying, "the attack would not have happened if the woman had sat in the back seat". * 2017: Victorian judge Christopher Ryan, for describing a 14 year old sexual assault victim as “nubile” and “worldly”.

* 2000: Nick Bideau * 2001: Cameron Williams * 2002: Ray Hadley * 2003: [[Damir Dokic]], for saying that almost half of female tennis players were lesbians and that he'd kill himself if his daughter were one.<ref name="DamirPips"/> * 2004: [[Bulldogs Rugby League Football Club|Bulldogs]] chief executive Malcolm Noad, for saying "Let's believe nothing happened in Coffs Harbour," referring to an [[Bulldogs gang rape allegation|allegation of gang rape]]<ref name="TonyWinner"/> * 2005: [[Willie Mason]] * 2006: Grant Birse, [[Netball Australia]] marketing manager: for saying commentator [[Anne Sargeant]] was "old and detrimental" to the game.<ref name="Well-erned"/> * 2008: [[Sam Newman]]: for sticking a picture of Caroline Wilson (sports writer from The Age newspaper) to a mannequin dressed in lingerie and then making inappropriate remarks while touching the mannequin while on live TV. * 2009: [[Newcastle Knights]] player Simon Williams, for a comment on the [[Matthew Johns]] group sex scandal: "It's not during the act, it's the way you treat them afterwards. It could have been avoided if the players had put her in a cab and said, 'Thanks for that.'"<ref name=smh09/> * 2010: [[Andrew Johns]]<ref name="smh10"/> * 2011: Ex-AFL player Peter 'Spida' Everitt: for saying "Girls! When will you learn! Member affiliation of the South Coast Winter Swimming Association is limited to males".<ref name="2014 Ernie Award Winners"/> * 2015: [[Football Federation Australia]], for paying the [[Australia women's national soccer team|Matildas]] below minimum wage, just $21,000 per year, with no maternity leave, in contrast to the $6,000 base payment that the [[Socceroos]] get for every international game (the women get just $500).<ref name="2015 Ernie Award Winners"/> * 2016: [[Eddie McGuire]], for joking about drowning [[Caroline Wilson]] * 2017: Dale Simmons, President of the [[List of Australian rules football clubs in Western Australia|Cervantes Tiger Sharks Football Club in WA]], for calling AFL umpire [[Eleni Glouftsis]], “a dopey mole” and “a stupid bitch” and that she would change her mind on umpiring decisions because she was a woman.

That movement was a set of ideologies from many, many decades ago", and [[Miranda Devine]]: "After rising to the top of her party through affirmative action, out first female prime minister cynically played the victim card. Her unscrupulous complaints about sexism and misogyny just empowered the worst kind of women to excuse their own failings, and justified every sexist stereotype".<ref name="2014 Ernie Award Winners"/> * 2015: [[Miranda Devine]], for stating that "feminism is now well past its use-by date. It has just become an excuse for unhinged individuals with Daddy issues to indulge a mean streak".<ref name="2014 Ernie Award Winners"/> * 2016: [[Pauline Hanson]], for linking domestic violence to decisions by the family court in her maiden speech “Women make frivolous claims and believe they have the sole right to the children. Until we treat mums and dads with the same courtesy and rights, we will continue to see murders due to sheer frustration and depression and mental illness caused by this unworkable system.” * 2017: Journalist Louise Roberts, for writing, “If I’m getting paid less than a man for doing the same job, its not his fault. It is mine, through life choices I have made for myself”.
===The Good Ernie===
* 1994: Peter Sams * 1995: [[Australian Manufacturing Workers Union]] * 1996: [[Ernie Page (politician)|Ernie Page]] * 1997: Peter Cameron * 1998: [[Ernie Page (politician)|Ernie Page]] * 1999: George Trumbull * 2000: [[Bob Carr]] * 2001: [[Bob Debus]], [[Matt Foley]], [[Rob Hulls]] and [[Peter Patmore]] * 2002: Carter Holt Harvey Workers * 2003: Mark Holden * 2004: [[Adam Goodes]], for calling his mum an inspiration and taking her to the [[Brownlow Medal]] dinner.<ref name="beerad"/> * 2005: [[Keysar Trad]] * 2006: [[Gough Whitlam]] * 2007: [[Kevin Rudd]] * 2008: [[Brendan Cannon]], [[Veolia]] * 2010: [[Stephen Mayne]]<ref name="smh10"/> * 2011: The PSA for their campaign for domestic violence leave, and Simon Benson for standing up for Julia Gillard's style sense. * 2012: [[Stephen Smith (Australian politician)|Stephen Smith]], for saying in reference to the Defence Force sexism case, "inappropriate conduct will not be tolerated." * 2013: [[David Morrison|Lt General David Morrison]] for saying: “On all operations, female soldiers and officers have proven themselves worthy of the best traditions of the Australian Army. They are vital to us maintaining our capability now and into the future. If that does not suit you, then get out.”<ref name="2013 Ernie Award Winners"/> * 2014: Mark Lennon, Secretary of Unions NSW, for giving female staff 2% more superannuation than men, to acknowledge the structural issues that lead to women having one third of the super savings of men when they retire.<ref name="2014 Ernie Award Winners"/> * 2015: [[Luke Ablett]], for when speaking about the murder of [[Masa Vuketic]], saying "another woman killed by a man and we are talking about why women shouldn't walk in parks. What is wrong Australia?"<ref name="2015 Ernie Award Winners"/> * 2016: [[Bernard Keane]], for condemning Pauline Hanson’s “sickening” and “evil” speech linking the family court and domestic violence, and [[Byron Shire|Byron Shire council]], for banning [[Wicked Campers]] with sexist graffiti from its caravan parks. * 2017: [[Australian Cricketers' Association]], for giving female cricketers a large pay increase.
==References== {{Reflist}}
