revision.text:
{{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Evolution Day |type = historical |image = Origin of Species title page.jpg |caption = The title page of the first (1859) edition of
[[On the Origin of Species]] by [[Charles Darwin]]. |observedby = [[Humanism|Humanists]] and others |significance = The anniversary of the initial publication of Darwin's Origin of Species, which introduced the concepts of [[evolution]] and [[natural selection]] to the public. |date = 24 November |scheduling = same day each year |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual |relatedto = [[Darwin Day]] }} '''Evolution Day''' is a celebration to commemorate the anniversary of the initial publication of ''[[On the Origin of Species]]'' by [[Charles Darwin]] on 24 November 1859. {{cite web |url=http://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=100322 |title=Make a special date for assembly - 1997 |date=6 December 1996 |website=[[TES (magazine)]] |accessdate=28 November 2014}} "Schools trying to link religious, moral and spiritual education into the wider framework of group assemblies will find here a calendar listing the main [[religious festival]]s of the six [[major religious groups|main faiths]], the [[International observance|United Nation's designated days of concern]], profile-raising days of the main British charities, anniversaries of major figures whose lives embodied important values and days of special interest to those dealing with children [… November] 24 Evolution Day (Humanist - publication of Origin of Species)" {{cite web |url=http://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=82274 |title=Dates to remember in 1999 |date=1 January 1999 |website=TES (magazine) |accessdate=28 November 2014}} "Evolution Day: anniversary of publication of "The Origin of Species" by Charles Darwin (1859)" {{cite web |url=http://blogs.biomedcentral.com/bmcblog/2011/11/24/evolution-day/ |title=Evolution Day |author=Elizabeth Bal |date=24 November 2011 |website=[[BioMed Central]] |accessdate=28 November 2014}} {{cite web |url=http://time.com/3602107/darwin-evolution-day/ |title=On Evolution Day, Remember That Darwin Knew He’d Meet Resistance |author=[[Jeffrey Kluger]] |date=24 November 2014 |website=[[Time (magazine)]] |accessdate=28 November 2014}} Such celebrations have been held for over a century, but the specific term "Evolution Day" for the anniversary appears to be a [[neologism]] which was coined prior to 1997. By highlighting Darwin's contributions to science, the day's events are used to educate about [[evolutionary biology]]. {{cite web |url=https://www.tes.co.uk/article.aspx?storycode=6138989 |title=Next week at school - 21-27 November 2011 |date=18 November 2011 |website=TES (magazine) |accessdate=29 November 2014}} "THURSDAY [24 November 2011] Evolution Day (1859) Charles Darwin published his [[Creation–evolution controversy|controversial]] book On the Origin of the Species, which has been fiercely debated since. Teach seven and eight- year-olds about Darwin with a resource from the [[Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew]]." It is similar to the better-known [[Darwin Day]], held on the anniversary of his birth (12 February 1809). {{cite web |url=http://www.wissenrockt.de/2011/02/13/darwin-tag-kult-oder-kultur-16466/ |title=Darwin-Tag: Kult oder Kultur? |author=Arik Platzek |date=13 February 2011 |website=wissenrockt.de (Das Magazin für junge [[:de:Humanismus|Humanistinnen und Humanisten]]) |accessdate=1 December 2014}} Compared to Darwin Day, "der „Evolution Day“ am 24. November fand bisher nicht solche Aufmerksamkeit." It is unrelated to the [[secularization]] campaign by the [[Giordano Bruno Foundation]] to have the [[Public holidays in Germany|German public holiday]] of [[Ascension Day]] renamed to "Evolutionstag" (Evolution Day).{{cite web |url=http://blogs.nature.com/news/2009/02/songs_about_science_xv_you_can.html |title=Songs about Science XV: You can’t fool the children of evolution |author=Daniel Cressey |date=27 February 2009 |publisher=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |accessdate=1 December 2014}} ==Commemorations== 1909, the 50th anniversary of the publication of ''On The Origin of Species'' and the 100th anniversary of Darwin's birth, saw several major events celebrating both. At [[Cambridge]], more than 400 scientists and dignitaries from 167 countries met in a widely reported event of public interest to honour Darwin's contributions and discuss the latest discoveries and ideas related to evolution, {{Cite web |author=[[John van Wyhe]] | title = 1909: The first Darwin centenary | url = http://darwin-online.org.uk/1909.html | publisher = [[The Complete Works of Charles Darwin Online]] | accessdate = 7 June 2011}} the [[New York Academy of Sciences]] held a celebration at the [[American Museum of Natural History]], {{cite web | title = The Darwin Celebration | date= May 1909 | url=http://www.naturalhistorymag.com/editors_pick/1909_03_pick.html | accessdate = 17 September 2007 }} and the [[Royal Society of New Zealand]] held an event with "a very large attendance." {{cite web | title = ''Transactions and Proceedings of the Royal Society of New Zealand 1868–1961'' | date= 1909 | url= http://rsnz.natlib.govt.nz/volume/rsnz_42/rsnz_42_02_007190.html | accessdate = 17 September 2007 }} The [[Darwin Centennial Celebration (1959)]] had a major, well publicised event from 24–28 November at the [[University of Chicago]]. In 2009, the [[BBC]] aired [[BBC Darwin Season]], a series of television and radio programs, to celebrate Darwin's bicentenary and the 150th anniversary of the publication of ''the Origin''. ==See also== * [[Evolution Sunday]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{cite web |url=http://suffolkhands.org.uk/2006/11/358/ |title=Evolution Day |author=Margaret |date=24 November 2006 |website=Suffolk Humanists and Secularists |accessdate=28 November 2014}} * {{cite web |url=http://nbmpub.com/blog/2013/11/24/science-happy-evolution-day/ |title=Science: Happy Evolution Day! |author=Margreet de Heer |date=24 November 2013 |publisher=[[NBM Publishing]] |accessdate=28 November 2014}} {{Science commemorative events}} {{Holiday-stub}} [[Category:Charles Darwin celebrations]] [[Category:November observances]] [[Category:Unofficial observances]]

revision.text:
{{About|the novel|its film adaptation|Fifty Shades of Grey (film)|the novel series|Fifty Shades trilogy}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} {{EngvarB|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox book | name = Fifty Shades of Grey | image = 50ShadesofGreyCoverArt.jpg | caption = 2012 paperback cover | author = [[E. L. James]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | series = [[Fifty Shades trilogy|''Fifty Shades'' trilogy]] | subject = | genre = [[Erotic romance novels|Erotic romance]] | published = 20 June 2011 ([[Vintage Books]]) | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]], [[paperback]]) | pages = 514 | isbn = 978-1-61213-028-6 | oclc = 780307033 | followed_by = [[Fifty Shades Darker]] }} '''''Fifty Shades of Grey''''' is a 2011 [[Erotic romance novels|erotic romance novel]] by British author [[E. L. James]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.avclub.com/holy-crow-fifty-shades-of-grey-is-crazy-similar-to-its-1798276528|title=Holy crow! Fifty Shades Of Grey is crazy similar to its Twilight origin story|last=Eakin|first=Marah|work=News|access-date=2017-10-08|language=en-US}}</ref> It is the first instalment<!-- Do not change this to "installment", it is correct in British English --> in the [[Fifty Shades trilogy|''Fifty Shades'' trilogy]] that traces the deepening relationship between a college graduate, Anastasia Steele, and a young business magnate, Christian Grey. It is notable for its explicitly erotic scenes featuring elements of sexual practices involving [[Bondage (sexual)|bondage]]/[[Discipline (BDSM)|discipline]], [[Dominance and submission|dominance/submission]], and [[Sadomasochism|sadism/masochism]] ([[BDSM]]). Originally [[Self-publishing|self-published]] as an [[ebook]] and a [[print-on-demand]], publishing rights were acquired by [[Vintage Books]] in March 2012.
''Fifty Shades of Grey'' has topped best-seller lists around the world, selling over 125 million copies worldwide by June 2015. It has been translated into 52 languages, and set a record in the United Kingdom as the fastest-selling paperback of all time. Critical reception of the book, however, has tended towards the negative, with the quality of its prose generally seen as poor. [[Universal Pictures]] and [[Focus Features]] produced a [[Fifty Shades of Grey (film)|film adaptation]], which was released on 13 February 2015<ref name=Variety>{{cite news|title=Universal Shifts '50 Shades' Release Date to February 2015|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/universal-shifts-50-shades-release-date-to-february-2015-1200826341/ |work=Variety|accessdate=18 November 2013}}</ref> and also received generally unfavourable reviews.
The second and third volumes of the trilogy, ''[[Fifty Shades Darker]]'' and ''[[Fifty Shades Freed]]'', were published in 2012. ''[[Grey: Fifty Shades of Grey as Told by Christian]]'', a version of ''Fifty Shades of Grey'' being told from Christian's point of view, was published in June 2015.
==Plot== Anastasia "Ana" Steele is a 21-year-old college senior attending [[Washington State University Vancouver|Washington State University]] in [[Vancouver, Washington]]. Her best friend is Katherine "Kate" Kavanagh, who writes for the college newspaper. Due to an illness, Kate is unable to interview 27-year-old Christian Grey, a successful and wealthy [[Seattle]] entrepreneur, and asks Ana to take her place. Ana finds Christian attractive as well as intimidating. As a result, she stumbles through the interview and leaves Christian's office believing it went poorly. Ana does not expect to meet Christian again, but he appears at the hardware store where she works. While he purchases various items including cable ties, masking tape, and rope, Ana informs Christian that Kate would like some photographs to illustrate her article about him. Christian gives Ana his phone number. Later, Kate urges Ana to call Christian and arrange a photo shoot with their photographer friend, José Rodriguez.
The next day José, Kate, and Ana arrive for the photo shoot at the [[Heathman Hotel]], where Christian is staying. Christian asks Ana out for coffee and asks if she is dating anyone, specifically José. Ana replies that she is not dating anyone. During the conversation, Ana learns that Christian is also single, but he says he is not romantic. Ana is intrigued but believes she is not attractive enough for Christian. Later, Ana receives a package from Christian containing first edition copies of ''[[Tess of the d'Urbervilles]]'', which stuns her. Later that night, Ana goes out drinking with her friends and ends up [[drunk dialing|drunk dialling]] Christian, who informs her that he will be coming to pick her up because of her inebriated state. Ana goes outside to get some fresh air, and José attempts to kiss her, but he is stopped by Christian's arrival. Ana leaves with Christian, but not before she discovers that Kate has been flirting with Christian's brother, Elliot. Later, Ana wakes to find herself in Christian's hotel room, where he scolds her for not taking proper care of herself. Christian then reveals that he would like to have sex with her. He initially says that Ana will first have to fill in paperwork, but later goes back on this statement after making out with her in the elevator.
Ana goes on a date with Christian, on which he takes her in his helicopter, ''Charlie Tango'', to his apartment. Once there, Christian insists that she sign a [[non-disclosure agreement]] forbidding her from discussing anything they do together, which Ana agrees to sign. He also mentions other paperwork, but first takes her to his playroom full of [[BDSM]] toys and gear. There, Christian informs her that the second contract will be one of [[dominance and submission]], and there will be no romantic relationship, only a sexual one. The contract even forbids Ana from touching Christian or making eye contact with him. At this point, Christian realises that Ana is a [[Virginity|virgin]] and takes her virginity without making her sign the contract. The following morning, Ana and Christian again have sex. His mother arrives moments after their sexual encounter and is surprised by the meeting, having previously thought Christian was [[homosexual]], because he was never seen with a woman. Christian later takes Ana out to eat, and he reveals that he lost his virginity at age 15 to one of his mother's friends, Elena Lincoln, and that his previous dominant/submissive relationships failed due to incompatibility. Christian also reveals that in his first dominant/submissive relationship he was the submissive. Christian and Ana plan to meet again, and he takes Ana home, where she discovers several job offers and admits to Kate that she and Christian had sex.
Over the next few days, Ana receives several packages from Christian. These include a laptop to enable her to research the BDSM lifestyle in consideration of the contract; to communicate with him, since she has never previously owned a computer; and to receive a more detailed version of the dominant/submissive contract. She and Christian email each other, with Ana teasing him and refusing to honour parts of the contract, such as only eating foods from a specific list. Ana later meets with Christian to discuss the contract and becomes overwhelmed by the potential BDSM arrangement and the potential of having a sexual relationship with Christian that is not romantic in nature. Because of these feelings, Ana runs away from Christian and does not see him again until her college graduation, where he is a guest speaker. During this time, Ana agrees to sign the dominant/submissive contract. Ana and Christian once again meet to further discuss the contract, and they go over Ana's [[Limits (BDSM)|hard and soft limits]]. Christian spanks Ana for the first time, and the experience leaves her both enticed and slightly confused. This confusion is exacerbated by Christian's lavish gifts and the fact that he brings her to meet his family. The two continue with the arrangement without Ana's having yet signed the contract. After successfully landing a job with Seattle Independent Publishing (SIP), Ana further bristles under the restrictions of the non-disclosure agreement and her complex relationship with Christian. The tension between Ana and Christian eventually comes to a head after Ana asks Christian to punish her in order to show her how extreme a BDSM relationship with him could be. Christian fulfils Ana's request, beating her with a belt, and Ana realises they are incompatible. Devastated, she breaks up with Christian and returns to the apartment she shares with Kate.
==Background and publication== [[File:E. L. James (cropped).jpg|thumbnail|E. L. James in 2012]] The ''Fifty Shades'' trilogy was developed from a [[Twilight (novel series)|''Twilight'']] [[fan fiction]] series originally titled ''Master of the Universe'' and published episodically on fan-fiction websites under the pen name "Snowqueen's Icedragon". The piece featured characters named after [[Stephenie Meyer]]'s characters in ''Twilight'', [[Edward Cullen]] and [[Bella Swan]]. After comments concerning the sexual nature of the material, James removed the story from the fan-fiction websites and published it on her own website, FiftyShades.com. Later she rewrote ''Master of the Universe'' as an original piece, with the principal characters renamed Christian Grey and Anastasia Steele and removed it from her website before publication.<ref>{{cite web|work= Media bistro |url=http://www.adweek.com/galleycat/fifty-shades-of-grey-wayback-machine/50128?red=as|title=The Lost History of ''Fifty Shades of Grey''|author=Boog, Jason|date=21 November 2012}}</ref> Meyer commented on the series, saying "that's really not my genre, not my thing... Good on her—she's doing well. That's great!"<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1685954/fifty-shades-of-grey-stephenie-meyer.jhtml|title= ''Fifty Shades of Grey'': Stephenie Meyer Speaks Out|publisher=MTV|date=29 May 2012}}</ref>
This reworked and extended version of ''Master of the Universe'' was split into three parts. The first, titled ''Fifty Shades of Grey'', was released as an e-book and a [[print on demand]] paperback in May 2011 by The Writers' Coffee Shop, a virtual publisher based in Australia.<ref>[http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/03/17/50-shades-of-grey-a-self-published-e-book-is-the-future-of-publishing.html#url=/articles/2012/03/17/50-shades-of-grey-a-self-published-e-book-is-the-future-of-publishing.html '50 Shades of Grey,' a Self-Published E-Book, Is the Future of Publishing]. Lizzie Shurnick. The Daily Beast. 17 March 2012. Retrieved 8 March 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/ronald-h-balson/bestseller-success-storie_b_4064574.html ''Bestseller Success Stories that Started Out as Self-Published Books.''] Ronald H. Balsom. 8 October 2013.</ref> The second volume, ''[[Fifty Shades Darker]]'', was released in September 2011; and the third, ''[[Fifty Shades Freed]]'', followed in January 2012. The Writers' Coffee Shop had a restricted marketing budget and relied largely on book blogs for early publicity, but sales of the novel were boosted by word-of-mouth recommendation. The book's erotic nature and perceived demographic of its fan base as being composed largely of married women over thirty led to the book being dubbed "Mommy Porn" by some news agencies.<ref>{{cite news|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/10/business/media/an-erotic-novel-50-shades-of-grey-goes-viral-with-women.html?_r=2 | title= Discreetly Digital, Erotic Novel Sets American Women Abuzz| work= [[The New York Times]]| date= 20 March 2012| first=Julie| last=Bosman}}</ref><ref name=Forbes>{{cite news| first =Jenna | last = Goudreau|url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/jennagoudreau/2012/03/19/will-fifty-shades-of-grey-make-mommy-porn-the-next-big-thing/|title= Will ''Fifty Shades of Grey'' Make 'Mommy Porn' The Next Big Thing?| work= Forbes |date= 19 March 2012| accessdate= 7 May 2012}}</ref> The book has also reportedly been popular among teenage girls and college women.<ref name= Forbes /><ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/lifestyle/books/fifty-shades-of-grey-author-el-james-reveals-reallife-secrets-to-her-readers-16180814.html|title=''Fifty Shades of Grey'' author EL James reveals real-life secrets to her readers | work =[[The Belfast Telegraph]]|date=4 July 2012|accessdate=8 July 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first=Doree | last=Lewak |authorlink=Doree Lewak | url = http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/the_hot_sex_text_zx2AW5DO7h40whfZSHG1kO | title = The hot sex text | work =[[New York Post]] |date=11 July 2012}}</ref> By the release of the final volume in January 2012, news networks in the United States had begun to report on the ''Fifty Shades'' trilogy as an example of [[viral marketing]] and of the rise in popularity of female erotica, attributing its success to the discreet nature of [[E-book reader|e-reading devices]].<ref name="Fox">{{cite news|url= http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2012/03/14/erotic-novel-50-shades-grey-unites-women-unnerves-some-men/| title= Erotic novel ''50 Shades of Grey'' unites gals, unnerves some guys|publisher=Fox News|date=14 March 2012|accessdate=7 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Meredith|last=Bennett-Smith|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Books/chapter-and-verse/2012/0315/50-Shades-of-Grey-What-is-the-appeal|work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|title=''50 Shades of Grey'': What is the appeal?|date=15 March 2012|accessdate=7 May 2012}}</ref> Due to the heightened interest in the series, the license to the ''Fifty Shades'' trilogy was picked up by [[Vintage Books]] for re-release in a new and revised edition in April 2012.<ref>Julie Bosman. ''Fifty Shades of Gray Hits a Sales Milestone''. ''The New York Times''. 27 February 2014. page C3.</ref><ref>[http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/fifty-shades-grey-sales-hit-683852 "Fifty Shades of Grey" Sales Hit 100 Million]. Andy Lewis. ''The Hollywood Reporter''. 16 February 2014.</ref> The attention that the series has garnered has also helped to spark a renewed interest in [[erotic literature]]. Many other erotic works quickly became [[Best Sellers (New York Times)|best-sellers]] following ''Fifty Shades''{{'}} success, while other popular works, such as [[Anne Rice]]'s ''[[The Sleeping Beauty Quartet|The Sleeping Beauty]]'' trilogy, have been reissued (this time without pseudonyms) to meet the higher demand.<ref name="USA Today">{{cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/books/news/story/2012-08-29/erotica-trend-fifty-shades-of-grey/57416594/1|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130412043721/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/books/news/story/2012-08-29/erotica-trend-fifty-shades-of-grey/57416594/1|dead-url=yes|archive-date=12 April 2013|title=Publishing world is turned on by 'Fifty Shades of Grey'|work=[[USA Today]]|date=29 August 2012|accessdate=15 March 2013}}</ref>
On 1 August 2012, [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] UK announced that it had sold more copies of ''Fifty Shades of Grey'' than it had the entire ''[[Harry Potter]]'' series combined, making E. L. James its best-selling author, replacing [[J. K. Rowling]], though worldwide the ''Harry Potter'' series sold more than 450 million copies compared with ''Fifty Shades of Grey''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s sales of 60 million copies.<ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/336759/Fifty-Shades-of-Grey-becomes-the-bestselling-book-of-all-time- | title = ''Fifty Shades of Grey'' becomes the bestselling book of all time | place = UK | first = Charlotte | last = Meredith | newspaper = [[Daily Express]]|date=1 August 2012 }}</ref>
==Reception== ''Fifty Shades of Grey'' has topped best-seller lists around the world, including those of the United Kingdom and the United States.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-17332129 |location=UK|title=EL James' ''Fifty Shades of Grey'' tops ''New York Times'' list|publisher=BBC|accessdate=31 May 2012|date=11 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-17769140 |title=Erotic book ''Fifty Shades of Grey'' becomes UK bestseller|publisher=BBC|location=UK|accessdate=31 May 2012|date=19 April 2012}}</ref> The series had sold over 125 million copies worldwide by June 2015 and has been translated into 52 languages,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/biz/news/fifty-shades-spinoff-grey-stolen-from-publisher-1201516843/ |title='Fifty Shades' Spinoff 'Grey' Stolen From Publisher (Report)|author=Alex Stedman|work=Variety|accessdate=9 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.eonline.com/news/480515/fifty-shades-of-grey-release-date-pushed-back-to-february-13-2015-just-in-time-for-valentine-s-day |title=Fifty Shades of Grey Release Date Pushed Back to February 13, 2015—Just in Time for Valentine's Day!|date=13 November 2013|work=E! Online|accessdate=9 September 2015}}</ref> and set a record in the United Kingdom as the fastest-selling paperback of all time.<ref>{{cite news|title=''Fifty Shades of Grey'' outstrips ''Harry Potter'' to become fastest selling paperback of all time|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2160862/Fifty-Shades-Of-Grey-book-outstrips-Harry-Potter-fastest-selling-paperback-time.html#ixzz1y9SHlzQU |work=Daily Mail|accessdate=18 June 2012|location=London|first=Paul|last=Bentley|date=18 June 2012}}</ref>
===Critical response=== It has received mixed to negative reviews, with most critics noting poor literary qualities of the work. [[Salman Rushdie]] said about the book: "I've never read anything so badly written that got published. It made ''Twilight'' look like ''[[War and Peace]]''."<ref>{{cite news|last=Irvine|first=Chris|title=Sir Salman Rushdie: 'Fifty Shades of Grey makes Twilight look like War and Peace'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/booknews/9596577/Sir-Salman-Rushdie-Fifty-Shades-of-Grey-makes-Twilight-look-like-War-and-Peace.html|accessdate=30 April 2013|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=9 October 2012|location=London}}</ref> [[Maureen Dowd]] described the book in ''The New York Times'' as being written "like a [[Brontë family|Bronte]] devoid of talent," and said it was "dull and poorly written."<ref>{{cite news|last=Dowd|first=Maureen|title=She's Fit to Be Tied|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/01/opinion/sunday/dowd-shes-fit-to-be-tied.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=30 April 2013|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=31 March 2012}}</ref> Jesse Kornbluth of ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' said: "As a reading experience, ''Fifty Shades'' ... is a sad joke, puny of plot".<ref>{{cite news|last=Kornbluth|first=Jesse|title='Fifty Shades Of Grey': Is The Hottest-Selling Book In America Really Just 'S&M For Dummies?'|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jesse-kornbluth/fifty-shades-of-grey-review_b_1338594.html|accessdate=30 April 2013|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=12 March 2012}}</ref>
[[Princeton University|Princeton]] professor April Alliston wrote, "Though no literary masterpiece, ''Fifty Shades'' is more than parasitic fan fiction based on the recent ''Twilight'' vampire series."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/03/29/opinion/alliston-greenfield-50-shades/index.html?iref=obnetwork|title= 'Mommy porn' novel has retro message|work=CNN|date=29 March 2012}}</ref> ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' writer Lisa Schwarzbaum gave the book a "B+" rating and praised it for being "in a class by itself."<ref>{{cite news|last=Schwarzbaum|first=Lisa|title=Fifty Shades of Grey|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20584416_20578460,00.html|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=24 June 2012|date=21 March 2012}}</ref> British author [[Jenny Colgan]] in ''[[The Guardian]]'' wrote "It is jolly, eminently readable and as sweet and safe as BDSM (bondage, discipline, sadism and masochism) erotica can be without contravening the [[Trade Descriptions Act 1968|trade descriptions act]]" and also praised the book for being "more enjoyable" than other "literary erotic books".<ref>{{cite news|last=Colgan|first=Jenny|title=Fifty Shades of Grey|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/apr/13/fifty-shades-grey-el-james-review|work=The Guardian|accessdate=24 June 2012|location=London|date=13 April 2012}}</ref> ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' noted that the book was "the definition of a page-turner", noting that the book was both "troubling and intriguing".<ref>{{cite news|last=Barnett|first=Laura|title=Mommy porn?: Fifty Shades of Grey by EL James: review|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/bookreviews/9201010/Mommy-porn-Fifty-Shades-of-Grey-by-EL-James-review.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=13 April 2012|location=London}}</ref> A reviewer for the ''[[Ledger-Enquirer]]'' described the book as guilty fun and escapism, and that it "also touches on one aspect of female existence [female submission]. And acknowledging that fact – maybe even appreciating it – shouldn't be a cause for guilt."<ref>{{cite web|last=Sorich|first=Sonya|title=''Fifty Shades of Grey'': The undressed review|url=http://www.ledger-enquirer.com/2012/04/11/2008386/fifty-shades-of-grey-the-undressed.html|work=[[Ledger-Enquirer]]|date=11 April 2012}}</ref> ''[[The New Zealand Herald]]'' stated that the book "will win no prizes for its prose" and that "there are some exceedingly awful descriptions," although it was also an easy read; "(If you only) can suspend your disbelief and your desire to – if you'll pardon the expression – slap the heroine for having so little self respect, you might enjoy it."<ref>{{cite news|last=Sheehy|first=Christine|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/opinion/news/article.cfm?c_id=466&objectid=10798532|title= The 'mommy porn' seducing women|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|date=13 April 2012}}</ref> ''[[The Columbus Dispatch]]'' stated that, "Despite the clunky prose, James does cause one to turn the page."<ref>{{cite web|last=Osterheldt |first=Jenee|title=Book Review – ''Fifty Shades of Grey'': Sultry subject spells success|url=http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/life_and_entertainment/2012/03/26/sultry-subject-spells-success.html|work=[[The Columbus Dispatch]]|date=26 March 2012}}</ref> ''Metro News Canada'' wrote that "suffering through 500 pages of this heroine's inner dialogue was torturous, and not in the intended, sexy kind of way".<ref>{{cite web|last=Napier|first=Jessica|title=''Fifty Shades of Grey'' as dull as a razor blade commercial|url=http://metronews.ca/voices/she-says/107119/fifty-shades-of-grey-as-dull-as-a-razor-blade-commercial/|work=Metro News Canada|date=16 April 2012|access-date=7 September 2015}}</ref> Jessica Reaves, of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', wrote that the "book's source material isn't great literature", noting that the novel is "sprinkled liberally and repeatedly with asinine phrases", and described it as "depressing".<ref>{{cite news|last=Reaves|first=Jessica|title=Fifty shades of retrograde|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2012-04-14/entertainment/ct-prj-0415-50-shades-grey-20120413_1_american-women-shades-execution/|accessdate=25 April 2012|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=14 April 2012}}</ref>
The book garnered some accolades. In December 2012, it won both "Popular Fiction" and "Book of the Year" categories in the UK [[Specsavers National Book Awards|National Book Awards]].<ref name=flood2012>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/dec/05/el-james-national-books-award |title=EL James comes out on top at National Book awards |work=[[The Guardian]] |author=Flood, Alison |date=5 December 2012 |accessdate=5 December 2012 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/dec/26/fifty-shades-grey-most-popular-book |title=Fifty Shades of Grey voted the most popular book of 2012 |work=[[The Guardian]] |author=Flood, Alison |date=26 December 2012 |accessdate=26 December 2012 |location=London}}</ref> In that same month, ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' named E. L. James the 'Publishing Person of the Year', a decision whose criticism in the ''[[LA Times]]'' and the ''[[New York Daily News]]'' was referred to by and summarised in ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Books/chapter-and-verse/2012/1203/E-L-James-as-Publishing-Person-of-the-Year-draws-outcry-from-literary-world |title=E L James as 'Publishing Person of the Year' draws outcry from literary world |work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] |author= Driscoll, Molly |date=3 December 2012 |accessdate=5 December 2012}}</ref> Earlier, in April 2012, when [[E. L. James]] was listed as one of [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']] magazine's "100 Most Influential People in the World",<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/completelist/0,29569,2111975,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130825095030/http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/completelist/0%2C29569%2C2111975%2C00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=25 August 2013 |title=The 100 Most Influential People in the World: 2012 |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=10 August 2013 |df= }}</ref> Richard Lawson of ''[[The Atlantic Wire]]'' criticised her inclusion due to the trilogy's fan fiction beginnings.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lawson |first=Richard |title=Five Things Wrong with This Year's 'Time 100' |url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/entertainment/2012/04/five-things-wrong-years-time-100/51298/ |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6B5MIN3AA?url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/entertainment/2012/04/five-things-wrong-years-time-100/51298/ |archivedate=1 October 2012 |work=[[The Atlantic|The Atlantic Wire]] |date=18 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
===Controversy===
''Fifty Shades of Grey'' has attracted criticism due to its depictions of [[BDSM]], with some BDSM participants stating that the book confuses BDSM with abuse and presents it as a pathology to be overcome, as well as showing incorrect and possibly dangerous BDSM techniques.<ref>Velvet, Lady. (14 February 2015) [http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/fifty-shades-grey-a-dominatrixs-773577 'Fifty Shades of Grey': A Dominatrix's View (Guest Column)]. Hollywood Reporter. Retrieved on 27 February 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/02/16/fifty-shades-of-grey-isnt-bdsm_n_6684808.html 'Fifty Shades Of Grey' Isn't A Movie About BDSM, And That's A Problem]. Huffingtonpost.com (16 February 2015). Retrieved on 27 February 2015.</ref>
Coinciding with the release of the book and its surprising popularity, injuries related to BDSM and [[sex toy]] use spiked dramatically. In 2012, the year after the book was published, injuries requiring Emergency Room visits increased by over 50% from 2010 (the year before the book was published). This is speculated to be due to people unfamiliar with both the proper use of these toys and the safe practice of [[Bondage (BDSM)|bondage]] and other "kinky" sexual fetishes attempting what they had read in the book.<ref>{{Cite news | title= Sex Toy Injuries Surged after 'Fifty Shades of Grey's was Published | first1= Christopher | last1= Ingraham | newspaper= The Washington Post | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/wonkblog/wp/2015/02/10/sex-toy-injuries-surged-after-fifty-shades-of-grey-was-published/}} 10 February</ref>
There has also been criticism against the fact that BDSM is part of the book. Archbishop Dennis Schnurr of Cincinnati said in an early February 2015 letter, "The story line is presented as a romance; however, the underlying theme is that bondage, dominance, and sadomasochism are normal and pleasurable."<ref>[http://www.catholicherald.co.uk/news/2015/02/12/fifty-shades-of-grey-is-an-assault-on-marriage-say-bishops/ Fifty Shades of Grey is an ‘assault on marriage’, say bishops]. CatholicHerald.co.uk (12 February 2015). Retrieved on 27 February 2015.</ref> The [[Feminism|feminist]] [[Opposition to pornography|anti-pornography]] organisation [[Stop Porn Culture]] called for a boycott of the movie based on the book because of its sex scenes involving bondage and violence.<ref>[http://www.azcentral.com/story/news/12-news/2015/02/13/12-news-bishop-50-shades-of-grey-is-a-sin/23389421/ Bishop: Seeing '50 Shades of Grey' is a sin]. Azcentral.com (13 February 2015). Retrieved on 27 February 2015.</ref> By contrast, Timothy Laurie and Jessica Kean argue that "film fleshes out an otherwise legalistic concept like 'consent' into a living, breathing, and at times, uncomfortable interpersonal experience," and "dramatises the dangers of unequal negotiation and the practical complexity of identifying one's limits and having them respected."<ref>{{Cite news | title= Why consenting adults should see 50 Shades of Grey - and take their teens | first1= Timothy | last1= Laurie | first2= Jessica | last2= Kean | newspaper= The Sydney Morning Herald | year= 2015 | url= https://www.academia.edu/10818672}} 19 February</ref>
Several critics and scientists have expressed concern that the nature of the main couple's relationship is not [[BDSM]] at all, but rather is characteristic of an abusive relationship. In 2013, social scientist Professor Amy E. Bonomi published a study wherein the books were read by multiple professionals and assessed for characteristics of [[intimate partner violence]], or IPV, using the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC's]] standards for emotional abuse and sexual violence. The study found that nearly every interaction between Ana and Christian was emotionally abusive in nature, including stalking, intimidation, and isolation. The study group also observed pervasive sexual violence within the CDC's definition, including Christian's use of alcohol to circumvent Ana's ability to consent, and that Ana exhibits classic signs of an abused woman, including constant perceived threat, stressful managing, and altered identity.<ref name="pmid23931257">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|last2=Altenburger|first2=Lauren E.|last3=Walton|first3=Nicole L.|date=September 2013|title="Double crap!" Abuse and harmed identity in Fifty Shades of Grey|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1089/jwh.2013.4344|journal=[[J. Womens Health|Journal of Women's Health]]|publisher=Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.|volume=22|issue=9|pages=733–744|doi=10.1089/jwh.2013.4344|pmid=23931257|access-date=|postscript=.|ref=harv|via=|last1=Bonomi|first1=Amy E.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last1= Bonomi | first1 = Amy E. | title = Is Fifty Shades triumphant for women? Or further entrapping them? | work = [[The Huffington Post]] | publisher = [[AOL]] | date = 12 August 2013 | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/amy-e-bonomi/is-fifty-shades-triumphan_b_3743022.html }}</ref>
A second study in 2014 was conducted to examine the health of women who had read the series, compared with a control group that had never read any part of the novels. The results showed a correlation between having read at least the first book and exhibiting signs of an [[eating disorder]], having romantic partners that were emotionally abusive and/or engaged in stalking behaviour, engaging in [[binge drinking]] in the last month, and having 5 or more sexual partners before age 24. The authors could not conclude whether women already experiencing these "problems" were drawn to the series, or if the series influenced these behaviours to occur after reading by creating underlying context.<ref name="pmid25144515">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|last2=Nemeth|first2=Julianna M.|last3=Altenburger|first3=Lauren E.|last4=Anderson|first4=Melissa L.|last5=Snyder|first5=Anastasia|last6=Dotto|first6=Irma|date=August 2014|title=Fiction or not? Fifty Shades is associated with health risks in adolescent and young adult females|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1089/jwh.2014.4782|journal=[[J. Womens Health|Journal of Women's Health]]|publisher=Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.|volume=23|issue=9|pages=720–728|doi=10.1089/jwh.2014.4782|pmid=25144515|access-date=|postscript=.|ref=harv|via=|last1=Bonomi|first1=Amy E.}}</ref> The study's lead researcher contends that the books romanticise dangerous behaviour and "perpetuate dangerous abuse standards."<ref name="Newsweek_13">{{cite journal|title=Fifty Shades: Exploring the Sexual Revolution|work=Newsweek Special Issue / Topix Media Lab Special #13|location=New York, NY|publisher=Topix Media Lab|year=2015|page=Page 13}}</ref> The study was limited in that only women up to age 24 were studied, and no distinction was made among the reader sample between women who enjoyed the series and those that had a strong negative opinion of it, having only read it out of curiosity due to the media hype or other obligation.<ref name="scie_Read">{{cite web | title = Reading 'Fifty Shades' linked to unhealthy behaviors | author = | work = ScienceDaily | accessdate = 22 August 2014 | url = https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2014/08/140821115922.htm | language = | quote = }}</ref>
At the beginning of the media hype, [[Dr. Drew]] and sexologist Logan Levkoff discussed on ''[[Today (U.S. TV program)|The Today Show]]''<ref>{{YouTube | id =Tw0F_tor4q4|title= Logan Levkoff on ''The Today Show'' – ''Fifty Shades of Grey''}}</ref> whether the book perpetuated [[violence against women]]; Levkoff said that while that is an important subject, this trilogy had nothing to do with it – this was a book about a consensual relationship. Dr. Drew commented that the book was "horribly written" in addition to being "disturbing" but stated that "if the book enhances women's real-life sex lives and intimacy, so be it."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wtop.com/267/2874733/Erotic-best-seller-disturbing-violent|title=Dr. Drew: ''50 Shades of Grey'' pathological, poorly written |publisher=[[WTOP-FM]]|date=22 May 2012}}</ref>
===Censorship=== In March 2012, branches of the public library in [[Brevard County, Florida]], removed copies of ''Fifty Shades of Grey'' from their shelves, with an official stating that it did not meet the selection criteria for the library and that reviews for the book had been poor. A representative for the library stated that it was due to the book's sexual content and that other libraries had declined to purchase copies for their branches.<ref name="LJBan">{{cite web|last=Schwartz|first=Meredith|url=http://lj.libraryjournal.com/2012/05/managing-libraries/florida-county-pulls-fifty-shades-of-grey-from-shelves/|title=Florida County Pulls ''Fifty Shades of Grey'' From Shelves|work=[[Library Journal]]|date=11 May 2012}}</ref> Deborah Caldwell-Stone of the [[American Library Association]] commented that "If the only reason you don't select a book is that you disapprove of its content, but there is demand for it, there's a question of whether you're being fair. In a public library there is usually very little that would prevent a book from being on the shelf if there is a demand for the information."<ref name="LJBan" /> Brevard County public libraries later made their copies available to their patrons due to public demand.<ref>{{cite web|last=Clarke|first=Suzan|title=Florida County Library Lifts Ban on ''50 Shades of Grey''|url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/headlines/2012/05/florida-county-library-lifts-ban-on-50-shades-of-grey/|work=[[ABC News]]|date=30 May 2012}}</ref>
In [[Macaé]], Brazil, Judge Raphael Queiroz Campos ruled in January 2013 that bookstores throughout the city must either remove the series entirely from their shelves or ensure that the books are wrapped and placed out of the reach of minors.<ref>{{cite news|title=BRAZIL JUDGE ORDERS '50 SHADES OF GREY' SEALED|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/brazil-judge-orders-50-shades-grey-removed|work=Associated Press|accessdate=18 January 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223011759/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/brazil-judge-orders-50-shades-grey-removed|archivedate=23 February 2015}}</ref> The judge stated that he was prompted to make such an order after seeing children reading them,<ref>{{cite news|title=Brazil judge orders '50 Shades of Grey' removed|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2013/01/18/brazil-judge-50-shades-of-grey/1846111/|work=USA Today|accessdate=1 March 2013|date=18 January 2013}}</ref> basing his decision on a law stating that "magazines and publications whose content is improper or inadequate for children and adolescents can only be sold if sealed and with warnings regarding their content".<ref>{{cite web|title=Brazilian bondage browsers tied down by court order|url=http://www.globallegalpost.com/global-view/brazilian-bondage-browsers-tied-down-by-court-order-77557903/#.UTDl6zBwpWc|publisher=Global Legal Post|accessdate=1 March 2013}}</ref>
In February 2015, the Malaysian [[Ministry of Home Affairs (Malaysia)|Home Ministry]] banned the ''Fifty Shades of Grey'' books shortly after banning its film adaptation after permitting them for three years in local bookstores, citing morality-related reasons.<ref>{{cite news|title=After movie, Malaysia also bans ‘Fifty Shades’ books|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/after-movie-malaysia-also-bans-fifty-shades-books#zWYoaRucdCDy56qw.97|work=Malay Mail|accessdate=10 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/after-movie-malaysia-also-bans-fifty-shades-books#zWYoaRucdCDy56qw.97|archivedate=27 February 2015}}</ref>
==Media==
===Film adaptation=== {{Main|Fifty Shades of Grey (film)}} {{Multiple image | direction = horizontal | footer = [[Jamie Dornan]] and [[Dakota Johnson]] were cast in the roles of Christian Grey and Anastasia Steele, respectively. | image1 =Jamie_Dornan_January_2013.jpg<!--Jamie Dornan 2014.jpg--> | width1 = 125 | image2 = Dakota Johnson 2014 (cropped).jpg | width2 = 121 }} A film adaptation of the book was produced by [[Focus Features]],<ref>{{cite web |last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/03/universal-pictures-and-focus-features-win-50-shades-of-grey/|title=Universal Pictures and Focus Features win ''Fifty Shades of Grey''|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[PMC (company)|PMC]]|date=26 March 2012|accessdate=7 May 2012}}</ref> [[Michael De Luca|Michael De Luca Productions]], and [[Trigger Street Productions]],<ref>{{cite news | last = Miller | first = Julie | title = Fifty Shades of Grey Film Gets Oscar-Nominated Producers, Christian Grey–Casting Inspiration | url = http://www.vanityfair.com/online/oscars/2012/07/fifty-shades-of-grey-producers-composite-sketch | accessdate = 12 August 2013 | newspaper = Vanity Fair (online) | date = 10 July 2012}}</ref> with [[Universal Studios|Universal Pictures]] and [[Focus Features]] securing the rights to the trilogy in March 2012.<ref>{{cite web |last=Fleming |first=Mike |url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/03/universal-pictures-and-focus-features-win-50-shades-of-grey/|title=Universal Pictures and Focus Features win ''Fifty Shades of Grey''|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]. [[PMC (company)|PMC]]|date=26 March 2012|accessdate=7 May 2012}}</ref> Universal is also the film's distributor. [[Charlie Hunnam]] was originally cast in the role of Christian Grey alongside [[Dakota Johnson]] in the role of Anastasia Steele,<ref>{{cite web|title=Fifty Shades Of Grey Movie Casts Dakota Johnson In a Lead Role|url=http://uk.omg.yahoo.com/news/fifty-shades-grey-movie-casts-charlie-hunnam-dakota-162136644.html|publisher=EntertainmentWise (Yahoo! UK)|accessdate=8 September 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150105002544/https://uk.celebrity.yahoo.com/news/fifty-shades-grey-movie-casts-charlie-hunnam-dakota-162136644.html|archivedate=5 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Rice|first=Lynette|title='Fifty Shades of Grey' casts Dakota Johnson and Charlie Hunnam|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2013/09/02/dakota-johnson-nabs-fifty-shades-of-grey-role/|publisher=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=3 September 2013|date=2 September 2013}}</ref> but Hunnam gave up the part in October 2013,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/charlie-hunnam-quitting-fifty-shades-of-grey-was-heartbreaking-2014217|title=Charlie Hunnam: Quitting Fifty Shades of Grey Was "Heartbreaking" - Us Weekly|date=21 July 2014|work=usmagazine.com|accessdate=27 January 2015}}</ref> with [[Jamie Dornan]] announced for the role on 23 October.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://variety.com/2013/film/news/jaimie-dornan-christian-grey-fifty-shades-of-grey-1200748632/ | title =Jamie Dornan Will Play Christian Grey in 'Fifty Shades of Grey' | date= 23 October 2013 | accessdate= 24 October 2013 | first= Justin | last=Kroll | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}}</ref>
The film was released on 13 February 2015,<ref name=Variety/> and although popular at the box office, critical reactions were mixed to negative.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/fifty-shades-of-grey|title=Fifty Shades of Grey Reviews|work=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=13 February 2015}}</ref>
===Film soundtrack=== {{Main|Fifty Shades of Grey: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack}} E. L. James announced the [[Soundtrack album|film's soundtrack]] would be released on 10 February 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.eljamesauthor.com/?p=1044|title=Movie Tie-in Edition Now Available & Soundtrack Coming Soon!|last=James|first=E L|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=12 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/fifty-shades-of-grey-soundtrack-features-beyonce-the-rolling-stones-frank-sinatra-sia-and-more-20150112|title='Fifty Shades Of Grey' Soundtrack Features Beyoncé, The Rolling Stones, Frank Sinatra, Sia, And More|last=Kozak|first=Oktay Ege|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=12 January 2015|publisher=Indie Wire}}</ref> Prior to the soundtrack's release, the first single, "[[Earned It]]", by [[The Weeknd]], was released on 24 December 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2014/12/24/the-weeknd-fifty-shades-of-grey-earned-it/|title=Hear The Weeknd's 'Earned It' from 'Fifty Shades of Grey'|last=Zuckerman|first=Esther|date=24 December 2014|accessdate=12 January 2015|publisher=Entertainment Weekly}}</ref> On 7 January 2015, the second single, "[[Love Me like You Do]]" by [[Ellie Goulding]] was released.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6429567/ellie-goulding-fifty-shades-of-grey-song|title=Listen To Ellie Goulding's Sexy New Song From 'Fifty Shades of Grey' Soundtrack|last=Strecker|first=Erin|date=7 January 2015|accessdate=12 January 2015|publisher=Billboard}}</ref> Australian singer [[Sia (musician)|Sia]] released the soundtrack's third single, "Salted Wound", on 27 January 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/fifty-shades-grey-original/id956689788 |title=Fifty Shades of Grey (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack) |last=Artists |first=Various |date=27 January 2015 |accessdate=27 January 2015 |publisher=Apple |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209161808/https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/fifty-shades-grey-original/id956689788 |archivedate=9 February 2015 |df= }}</ref>
===Classical album=== An album of songs selected by E. L. James was released on 11 September 2012 by [[EMI Classics]] under the title ''Fifty Shades of Grey: The Classical Album'', and reached number four on the US ''Billboard'' classical music albums chart in October 2012.<ref>[http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/480560/fifty-shades-of-grey-classical-album-coming-in-august "''Fifty Shades of Grey'' Classical Album Coming in August"], Billboard.com, 7 August 2012</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Billboard Charts Top 5 Classical Music Albums|url=http://www.classicalite.com/articles/707/20121023/billboard-charts-top-5-classical-music-albums-fifty-shades-of-grey-e-l-james-andrea-bocelli-lang-lang.htm|publisher=Classicalite|accessdate=16 November 2012}}</ref> A ''[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer|Seattle P-I]]'' reviewer favourably wrote that the album would appeal both to fans of the series and to "those who have no intention of reading any of the Grey Shades".<ref>{{cite news|title=Music Review: Fifty Shades of Grey: The Classical Album|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/lifestyle/blogcritics/article/Music-Review-Various-Artists-Fifty-Shades-of-3867791.php|publisher=Seattle PI|accessdate=16 November 2012|first1=Jack|last1=Goodstein|date=15 September 2012}}</ref>
===Parodies=== The ''Fifty Shades of Grey'' trilogy has inspired many parodies in print,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/pictures/18-things-you-dont-know-about-fifty-shades-of-grey/4/ |title=18 things you don't know about ''Fifty Shades of Grey'': The Parody Books Keep Coming |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->| date=17 February 2015 |website=CBS News |publisher= |accessdate= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2015/04/22/in_the_wake_of_50_shades_of_grey_whats_even_better_than_sex_ridiculous_sex/ |title=In the wake of ''50 Shades of Grey,'' what's even better than sex? Ridiculous sex |author=Rachel Kramer Bussel| date=22 April 2015 |website=Salon.com |publisher= |accessdate= }}</ref> in film, online, and on stage. In November 2012, Universal Studios attempted to prevent the release of ''Fifty Shades of Grey: A XXX Adaptation'', a pornographic film based on the novel, citing copyright and trademark infringement. Smash Pictures, the porn producer, later responded to the lawsuit with a counterclaim that "much or all" of the ''Fifty Shades'' material was placed in the [[public domain]] in its original ''Twilight''-based form,<ref name="SPLReply">{{cite news|last=Gardner|first=Eriq|title='Fifty Shades' Porn Parody Countersuit Claims Books Are In Public Domain (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/fifty-shades-porn-parody-countersuit-425897|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=4 March 2013}}</ref> but later capitulated and stopped production of their film.<ref>{{cite web|last=Romano|first=Aja|title="Fifty Shades" porn parody lost its lawsuit, but everyone wins|url=http://www.dailydot.com/culture/fifty-shades-porn-parody-lawsuit-benefits/|publisher=Daily Dot|date=12 March 2013}}</ref>
====In print==== [[Amazon.com]] lists over 50 book [[parodies]], e.g.: * [[Fifty Shades of Oy Vey: A Parody|''Fifty Shades of Oy Vey'']] (2013)<ref>{{cite book |last=Jamesbergstein |first=E.L. |date=2013 |title=Fifty Shades of Oy Vey: A Parody |url=https://www.amazon.com/E.L.-Jamesbergstein/e/B00FWZ28PS |location= |publisher= |isbn= |accessdate= }}</ref> by E. L. Jamesbergstein * ''[[Fifty Shames of Earl Grey]]'' (2012)<ref>{{cite book |last1=Merkin |first1=Fanny |last2=Shaffer |first2=Andrew |date=2012 |title=Fifty Shames of Earl Grey: A Parody |isbn=0-306-82199-0 |location= |publisher= |accessdate= }}</ref> by Fanny Merkin (a.k.a. [[Andrew Shaffer]])
====In film==== * ''[[Fifty Shades of Black]]'' (2016)
====Online==== *Parodying the [[fan fiction]] origins of ''Fifty Shades of Grey'', Ivy league MBA students have created ''Erotic FinFiction'', a blog containing steamy entries written in business jargon.<ref>{{cite news |last= Edwards |first=Peter |date=17 December 2013 |title=Business students steam up spreadsheets with 'Fifty Shades of Grey' treatment|url=https://www.thestar.com/business/2013/12/17/business_students_steam_up_spreadsheets_with_fifty_shades_of_grey_treatment.html |newspaper=The Star |location=Toronto |publisher= |accessdate= }}</ref>
====On stage==== Stage productions include: *''50 Shades! The Musical Parody''<ref>{{cite news|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/15/theater/50-shades-the-musical-parodies-that-erotic-best-seller.html?_r=0| title= If a Book Annoys You, Ridicule It in Song: '50 Shades! The Musical' Parodies That Erotic Best Seller|author=Webster, Andy|date=14 March 2014}}</ref> *''Cuff Me: The Fifty Shades of Grey Musical Parody''<ref>{{cite book|title=Cuff Me: The Fifty Shades of Grey Musical Parody|url= http://www.broadway.com/shows/cuff-me-fifty-shades-grey-musical-parody/|publisher=Broadway.com|accessdate=2015-12-12}}</ref> * ''[[Spank! The Fifty Shades Parody]]''
==See also== {{Portalbar|United Kingdom|2010s|Novels|Pornography}} * ''[[Maestra (book)|Maestra]]'', a 2016 novel frequently compared to ''Fifty Shades of Grey'' * [[BDSM in culture and media]] * [[Sadism and masochism in fiction]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.eljamesauthor.com/books/fifty-shades-of-grey Official author page]
{{Fifty Shades of Grey}} [[Category:Works based on Twilight]] [[Category:2011 British novels]] [[Category:BDSM literature]] [[Category:British erotic novels]] [[Category:British novels adapted into films]] [[Category:British romance novels]] [[Category:Novels set in Seattle]] [[Category:Women's erotica and pornography]] [[Category:Works based on Twilight series]] [[Category:Self-published books]] [[Category:Fifty Shades]] [[Category:Obscenity controversies in literature]]

{{Infobox Magazine | title = Flagship Magazine | image_file = | image_size = 200px | image_caption = | editor = Carol Mulholland | editor_title = Editor | staff_writer = | frequency = bi-monthly | circulation = | category = [[Game]]s | company = | publisher = | founded = 1983 | finaldate = 2010 | country = United Kingdom | language = [[English language|English]] | website = http://www.flagshipmagazine.co.uk | issn = 1743-6788 }} '''''Flagship Magazine''''' was an independent magazine for gamers.<ref>British Library International Standard Serial Number 1743-6788</ref> Published in the UK, it started in 1983 for [[Play-by-mail game]] (PBM) players.<ref name="Flagship Issue 1">Flagship Issue 1</ref> In 2002 it extended its coverage to include [[boardgame]]s, [[role-playing game]]s, web games and [[massively multiplayer online game]]s, along with [[collectible card game]]s and [[Personal computer game|computer games]].<ref>Flagship Issue 100</ref>
The magazine came out bimonthly with game reviews, diaries, news columns and an emphasis on reader feedback.
Founded in 1983 by [[Nick Palmer]] and Chris Harvey,<ref name="Flagship Issue 1"/> ''Flagship'' was edited by Carol Mulholland from issue 70. Shortly after publishing issue 130 in 2010 Carol Mulholland suffered a serious illness and the magazine ceased publication.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.flagshipmagazine.co.uk Official website]

revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox video game | title = Florence | image = File:Florence Preview Image.jpg | alt = A cartoon pale girl with black hair looks to the left. "Florence: an interactive story about love and life" is on the lefthand side. There is a yellow background. | caption = Preview title image for ''Florence''. | developer = Mountains | publisher = [[Annapurna Interactive]] | director = Ken Wong | designer = | composer = [[Kevin Penkin]] | engine = [[Unity (game engine)|Unity]] | released = {{Unbulleted list|'''iOS'''|February 14, 2018|'''Android'''|March 14, 2018}} | genre = [[Interactive novel]], [[Minigames]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] | platforms = {{Plainlist| *[[Android (operating system)|Android]] *[[iOS]]}} }}
'''''Florence''''' is an [[interactive story]] and [[video game]] developed by the Australian studio Mountains and published by [[Annapurna Interactive]]. The game was released on February 14, 2018 ([[Valentine's Day]]) for [[iOS]] and on March 14, 2018 for [[Android (operating system)|Android]]. In ''Florence'', the player follows the story of 25-year-old Florence Yeoh as she lives her daily routine and meets Krish, a [[cellist]] she sees in the park. The game features little written dialogue and tells Florence's story through a series of brief chapters. The game uses basic puzzles to reinforce pieces of Florence's life as players progress through her story.
Lead designer Ken Wong wanted to create games that eschewed [[violent video games|violence]] and was inspired by his work on ''[[Monument Valley (video game)|Monument Valley]]'' to have a more narrative-focused experience that included puzzles. The game received favorable reviews that praised the game's art-style, music, and narrative structure.
==Gameplay== [[File:Florence Screenshot.jpg|thumb|right|''Florence'' shows the awkwardness of a first date through a puzzle minigame. As Florence becomes more comfortable talking with Krish, the puzzles become easier.<ref name="sydney" />]] ''Florence'' is divided into 20 chapters, each featuring a different portion of Florence Yeoh's life.<ref name="rollingstone" /> The chapters are separated into six acts, which represent different portions of Florence's growth and change. The game plays out linearly, requiring input from the player in the form of short [[minigame]]s which help mimic or reveal Florence's thoughts and actions.<ref name="rollingstone">{{cite web |title='Florence' Is a Short, Bittersweet and Relatable Tale About First Love |author=Fogel, Stefanie |date=February 19, 2018 |work=[[Rolling Stone]] |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/glixel/features/florence-interview-w516887 |accessdate=March 18, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180320105545/https://www.rollingstone.com/glixel/features/florence-interview-w516887 |archivedate=March 20, 2018 |df= }}</ref><ref name="destructoid" /> These games include: Florence brushing her teeth, Florence following the sound of a cello to find Krish, Krish cleaning his room before Florence visits, and Florence packing up her things when Krish moves in—and giving Krish's things back to him when he moves out—among others. A single play-through of ''Florence'' takes approximately 30 minutes.<ref name="rollingstone" />
==Plot== The game follows Florence Yeoh, a 25-year-old woman who lives alone and is settled into a monotonous routine of working at her job and mindlessly interacting with social media on her commute.<ref name="eurogamer" /> One morning, her phone dies and she follows the sound of a cello and sees Krish, a [[street performance|street performer]], for the first time.<ref name="eurogamer" /> Krish befriends her and they go out on some dates.<ref name="eurogamer" /><ref name="gameofthemonth" /> They kiss for the first time and begin to take their relationship more seriously. Krish moves in with Florence and is pushed by her to follow his dreams of being a great cellist. As a thank you, Krish gives Florence a painting set and Florence fantasizes about following her passion of being an artist.<ref name="destructoid" />
The couple have their first fight six months later at a grocery store.<ref name="thevergereview" /> After a year, the two have fallen into a routine and begin to drift apart.<ref name="eurogamer" /> After another fight, Krish moves out. Florence decides to quit her job and follow her painting passion, where she finds success.<ref name="destructoid" />
==Development== [[File:Ken wong - game developers conference cropped.jpg|thumb|left|125px|Ken Wong, the lead designer for ''Florence'', wanted to create a game that eschewed video game violence.<ref name="vergepreview" />]]
After his success with ''[[Monument Valley (video game)|Monument Valley]]'', game designer Ken Wong felt that he had done what he could at his development studio, [[Ustwo]], and wanted to create his own studio.<ref name="MCV">{{cite web |title=Florence: How game design can tell love stories |author=Dealessandri, Marie |date=March 14, 2018 |publisher=''[[The Market for Computer & Video Games]]'' |url=https://www.mcvuk.com/business/florence-how-game-design-can-tell-love-stories |accessdate=April 12, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180416142102/https://www.mcvuk.com/business/florence-how-game-design-can-tell-love-stories |archivedate=April 16, 2018 |df= }}</ref> He chose to move back to his native Australia after seeing the game development scene in [[Melbourne]] grow.<ref name="MCV" /> Wong founded a new company, Mountains, in Melbourne.<ref name="MCV" /><ref name="engadget">{{cite web |title='Florence' turns falling in love into a video game |author=Conditt, Jessica |date=February 14, 2018 |publisher=''[[Engadget]]'' |url=https://www.engadget.com/2018/02/14/florence-game-ios-love-ken-wong-interview-mobile/ |accessdate=March 18, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180315083843/https://www.engadget.com/2018/02/14/florence-game-ios-love-ken-wong-interview-mobile/ |archivedate=March 15, 2018 |df= }}</ref>
After hiring staff, Mountains had no direction on what kind of game they wanted to create.<ref name="MCV" /> Wong's approach was to first hire the team and then come up with a solid game.<ref name="MCV" /> The staff discussed how film and books regularly explored love and human emotions, but that it was missing from game design and it would be a "good challenge."<ref name="MCV" /> They opted to move forward and create ''Florence''.<ref name="MCV" /> It was the first game Wong had worked on since ''Monument Valley''.<ref name="cnbc">{{cite web |title=The designer of 'Monument Valley' has a new game where users explore relationships, without prizes or big thrills |author=Findling, Deborah |date=February 11, 2018 |publisher=[[CNBC]] |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/02/09/designer-of-monument-valley-has-a-new-game-where-users-explore-relationships.html |accessdate=March 18, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180330012652/https://www.cnbc.com/2018/02/09/designer-of-monument-valley-has-a-new-game-where-users-explore-relationships.html |archivedate=March 30, 2018 |df= }}</ref>
Wong and the rest of the team wanted to create a game that eschewed [[video game violence|violence]].<ref name="vergepreview">{{cite web |title=Florence is a game about love from the designer behind Monument Valley |author=Webster, Andrew |date=October 24, 2017 |publisher=''[[The Verge]]'' |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/10/24/16533918/florence-iphone-game-announce-ken-wong-interview |accessdate=March 18, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180315201400/https://www.theverge.com/2017/10/24/16533918/florence-iphone-game-announce-ken-wong-interview |archivedate=March 15, 2018 |df= }}</ref> Wong said, "I wanted to explore what kind of stories and what kind of dynamics we can get without resorting to violence."<ref name="vergepreview" /> Mountains decided to make the game on mobile so it could be as accessible as possible.<ref name="vergepreview" /> The team's goal was to create a game where players focus on exploring emotions instead of achieving goals.<ref name="cnbc" /> In contrast to Wong's previous game, ''Monument Valley'', Wong wanted to create an experience that was similar to a comic book or silent movie with a focus on narrative.<ref name="vergepreview" /> Wong and the team were inspired by film in creating ''Florence'', and specifically cited ''[[500 Days of Summer]]'', ''[[Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind]]'', and ''[[Titanic (1997 film)|Titanic]]''.<ref name="vergepreview" /><ref name="polygonpreview">{{cite web |title=Monument Valley lead’s next game, Florence, is like Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind |author=Frank, Allegra |date=October 24, 2017 |publisher=''[[Polygon]]'' |url=https://www.polygon.com/2017/10/24/16534386/florence-game-ios-android-release-date-preview-annapurna-interactive |accessdate=April 12, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180413043348/https://www.polygon.com/2017/10/24/16534386/florence-game-ios-android-release-date-preview-annapurna-interactive |archivedate=April 13, 2018 |df= }}</ref>
The developers wanted to make the game a linear experience early on in the process because of a concern that people with more life experience would make the "correct" choices and avoid the moral of the game.<ref name="apptrigger">{{cite web |title=Interview: Ken Wong, and breaking with what a game ‘should be’ in Florence |author=Valentine, Rebekah |date=February 2018 |publisher=''App Trigger'' |url=https://apptrigger.com/2018/02/12/ken-wong-game-florence/ |accessdate=March 29, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180330013023/https://apptrigger.com/2018/02/12/ken-wong-game-florence/ |archivedate=March 30, 2018 |df= }}</ref> Mountains was inspired by the way people consume other media for the emotional connections they bring, and wanted to bring that feeling to video games.<ref name="cnbc" /> The team decided to use music as a substitute for dialogue throughout the game, with the cello representing Krish while the piano follows Florence.<ref name="radar">{{cite web |title=Fall in love with Florence, the new game from Monument Valley's designer |author=Weber, Rachel |date=February 14, 2018 |publisher=''[[Games Radar]]'' |url=https://www.gamesradar.com/fall-in-love-with-florence-the-new-game-from-monument-valleys-designer/ |accessdate=March 18, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180328102420/https://www.gamesradar.com/fall-in-love-with-florence-the-new-game-from-monument-valleys-designer/ |archivedate=March 28, 2018 |df= }}</ref> Mountains used musical themes for the characters after accidentally creating them during development of the "Groceries" chapter, where Krish and Florence have their first fight.<ref name="apptrigger" /> Wong chose the name Florence as she was designed to be a [[Chinese Australian]] whose parents picked an "old fashioned name" for their daughter when they immigrated.<ref name="radar" />
==Reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = 82/100<ref name="mc">{{cite web | url = http://www.metacritic.com/game/ios/florence | title = Florence for iPhone/iPad Reviews | website = [[Metacritic]] | publisher = [[CBS Interactive]] | accessdate = June 6, 2018 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180416142102/http://www.metacritic.com/game/ios/florence | archivedate = April 16, 2018 | df = }}</ref> | Destruct = 8/10<ref name="destructoid">{{cite web |title=Review: Florence |author=Andriessen, CJ |date=February 27, 2018 |publisher=''[[Destructoid]]'' |url=https://www.destructoid.com/review-florence-491831.phtml |accessdate=March 18, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180416142102/https://www.destructoid.com/review-florence-491831.phtml |archivedate=April 16, 2018 |df= }}</ref> | Edge = 8/10<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Florence |magazine=[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]] |publisher=[[Future plc]] |issue=318 |date=May 2018|page=120}}</ref> | rev1 = [[IGN|IGN Japan]] | rev1Score = 96/100<ref name="ignjapan">{{cite web |title=Florence Review |author=Krabbe, Esra |date=February 16, 2018 |publisher=[[IGN|IGN Japan]] |url=http://jp.ign.com/florence/22094/review/florence |language=Japanese |accessdate=March 18, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180312030037/http://jp.ign.com/florence/22094/review/florence |archivedate=March 12, 2018 |df= }}</ref> | rev2 = ''The Guardian'' | rev2Score = {{rating|4|5}}<ref name="guardian">{{cite web |title=Florence review – powerfully relatable snapshots of first love |author=Webber, Jordan Erica |date=February 23, 2018 |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/games/2018/feb/23/florence-review-graphic-novel-style-game |accessdate=March 18, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180318001743/https://www.theguardian.com/games/2018/feb/23/florence-review-graphic-novel-style-game |archivedate=March 18, 2018 |df= }}</ref> | rev3 = ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]''<ref name="sydney">{{cite web |title=Florence review: wordless love story is brief and breathtaking |author=Biggs, Tim |date=March 14, 2018 |publisher=''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' |url=https://www.smh.com.au/technology/florence-review-wordless-love-story-is-brief-and-breathtaking-20180314-p4z4b8.html |accessdate=March 18, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180319023707/https://www.smh.com.au/technology/florence-review-wordless-love-story-is-brief-and-breathtaking-20180314-p4z4b8.html |archivedate=March 19, 2018 |df= }}</ref> |rev3Score = 90/100<ref name="mc" /> | rev4 = ''[[TouchArcade]]'' | rev4Score = {{rating|4.5|5}}<ref name="toucharcade">{{cite web |url=https://toucharcade.com/2018/02/13/florence-review/ |title='Florence' Review – A Brief Fling |last=Hodapp |first=Eli |publisher=[[TouchArcade]] |date=February 13, 2018 |accessdate=April 12, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180324135416/http://toucharcade.com/2018/02/13/florence-review/ |archivedate=March 24, 2018 |df= }}</ref> }}
''Florence'' was announced on October 24, 2017.<ref name="PCAuthority" /> A demo shown publicly at [[PAX (event)|PAX Australia 2017]] focused on the first 15 minutes of the game.<ref name="PCAuthority">{{cite web |title=Hands-on Preview: Florence |author=Cole, Alayna |date=November 6, 2017 |publisher=''[[nextmedia|PC Authority]]'' |url=https://www.pcauthority.com.au/feature/hands-on-preview-florence-476960 |accessdate=March 18, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180413043700/https://www.pcauthority.com.au/feature/hands-on-preview-florence-476960 |archivedate=April 13, 2018 |df= }}</ref> The game received positive marks from Australian video game journalists.<ref name="PCAuthority" /><ref name="kotakuAU">{{cite web |title=What We Liked From PAX Australia 2017 |author=Walker, Alex |date=October 31, 2017 |publisher=''[[Kotaku]]'' |url=https://www.kotaku.com.au/2017/10/what-we-liked-from-pax-australia-2017/ |accessdate=April 12, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180413124507/https://www.kotaku.com.au/2017/10/what-we-liked-from-pax-australia-2017/ |archivedate=April 13, 2018 |df= }}</ref> ''[[Kotaku|Kotaku Australia]]''{{'s}} Rae Johnston called ''Florence'' her "stand-out game" and felt that the game's minigames succeeded in making her invested in the characters.<ref name="kotakuAU" /> ''[[nextmedia|PC Authority]]''{{'s}} Alayna Cole praised the game for standing out with a story about love and diversity, describing it as feeling "like a rarity" in modern video game culture.<ref name="PCAuthority" />
''Florence'' was well received by critics. CJ Andriessen of ''[[Destructoid]]'' described the game as "a truly beautiful product" and felt that the game was one of the most imaginative storytelling devices he had ever seen.<ref name="destructoid" /> Tim Biggs of ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' felt that the [[minigames]] made ''Florence'' "truly special" and that it was "breathtaking and emotionally affirming".<ref name="sydney" /> Jordan Erica Webber of ''[[The Guardian]]'' praised ''Florence''{{'}}s ability to capture "what it's like to fall in love for the first time."<ref name="guardian" /> ''[[Eurogamer]]''{{'s}} Christian Donlan noted that the game's puzzle format to life doesn't "quite work" but still loved the journey the game provided.<ref name="eurogamer">{{cite web |title=Florence is so much more than a love story |author=Donlan, Christian |date=February 19, 2018 |publisher=''[[Eurogamer]]'' |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-02-19-florence-is-so-much-more-than-a-love-story |accessdate=March 29, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180330075741/https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-02-19-florence-is-so-much-more-than-a-love-story |archivedate=March 30, 2018 |df= }}</ref> ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]''{{'s}} Patrick Shanley praised Wong and his team for nailing the "getting to know you" aspect of dating.<ref name="hollywoodreporter">{{cite web |title=This Mobile Game Captures What First Love Is Like |author=Shanley, Patrick |date=February 12, 2018 |publisher=''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/florence-mobile-game-captures-what-first-love-is-like-1083994 |accessdate=March 29, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180330012651/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/florence-mobile-game-captures-what-first-love-is-like-1083994 |archivedate=March 30, 2018 |df= }}</ref> [[IGN|IGN Japan]]'s Esra Krabbe called it a "universal work of art" and praised it as a game that anyone could play.<ref name="ignjapan" /> ''The Guardian''{{'s}} Simon Parkin listed ''Florence'' as his "Game of the Month" and noted that the game never felt trite and was well executed.<ref name="gameofthemonth">{{cite web |title=Florence review – girl meets boy meets iPhone game |author=Parkin, Simon |date=March 3, 2018 |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/games/2018/mar/03/florence-iphone-video-game-review-simon-parkin |accessdate=April 12, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180324082540/https://www.theguardian.com/games/2018/mar/03/florence-iphone-video-game-review-simon-parkin |archivedate=March 24, 2018 |df= }}</ref>
Many reviewers compared the game to the ''[[WarioWare]]'' series.<ref name="polygonreview">{{cite web |title=The breathtaking Florence captures falling in love better than almost any game |author=Frank, Allegra |date=February 15, 2018 |publisher=''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]'' |url=https://www.polygon.com/2018/2/15/17014258/florence-game-review-ios-best-games-2018 |accessdate=April 12, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180413043602/https://www.polygon.com/2018/2/15/17014258/florence-game-review-ios-best-games-2018 |archivedate=April 13, 2018 |df= }}</ref><ref name="thevergereview">{{cite web |title=With just a few taps, Florence shows you how it feels to fall in love |author=Webster, Andrew |date=February 14, 2018 |publisher=''[[The Verge]]'' |url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/2/14/17007592/florence-iphone-ipad-review-monument-valley |accessdate=April 12, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180413043119/https://www.theverge.com/2018/2/14/17007592/florence-iphone-ipad-review-monument-valley |archivedate=April 13, 2018 |df= }}</ref> ''[[The Verge]]''{{'s}} Andrew Webster compared the game to a "webcomic crossed with ''Warioware''," and ''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]''{{'s}} Allegra Frank praised the game's minigames as making the emotional component of the game resonate with the player.<ref name="thevergereview" /><ref name="polygonreview" /> Destructoid's Andriessen echoed Frank on the effectiveness of the minigames and felt that the game was a "beautiful product".<ref name="destructoid" />
Criticism focused on some story elements, specifically its ending.<ref name="destructoid" /><ref name="eurogamer" /><ref name="polygonreview" /> ''Destructoid''{{'s}} Andriessen stated that the game left him with a "pessimistic opinion" about love and noted that "it's the narcissistic pursuit of their real passion, art, that wins out in the end."<ref name="destructoid" /> ''Eurogamer''{{'s}} Donlan felt that the ending traded "one easy cliché for another", although concluding that the ending's disappointment may have been the point.<ref name="eurogamer" />
===Accolades===
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year !! Award !! Category !! Result !! Ref |- | style="text-align:center;" rowspan="4" | 2018 | [[Golden Joystick Awards]] | Mobile Game of the Year | {{Nom}} | style="text-align:center;" | <ref>{{cite news |title=Golden Joysticks 2018 nominees announced, voting open now |author=Hoggins, Tom |date=September 24, 2018 |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/gaming/news/golden-joysticks-2018-nominees-announced-voting-open-now/ |accessdate=November 16, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Golden Joystick Awards 2018 winners: God of War wins big but Fortnite gets Victory Royale |author=Sheridan, Connor |date=November 16, 2018 |publisher=''[[GamesRadar+]]'' |url=https://www.gamesradar.com/golden-joystick-awards-2018-winners/ |accessdate=November 17, 2018}}</ref> |- | rowspan="3" | [[The Game Awards 2018]] | Games for Impact | {{Pending}} | rowspan="3" style="text-align:center;" | <ref>{{cite web |title=The Game Awards 2018 nominees led by God of War, Red Dead Redemption 2 |author=McWhertor, Michael |date=November 13, 2018 |publisher=''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]'' |url=https://www.polygon.com/2018/11/13/18092186/game-awards-2018-nominees-show-date-start-time |accessdate=November 16, 2018}}</ref> |- | Best Mobile Game | {{Pending}} |- | Best Debut Indie Game | {{Pending}} |}

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} [[Image:O violeiro, 1899.jpg|thumb|right|250px|
''Violeiro'' playing, by Almeida Júnior.
The [[viola caipira]] is a [[Brazil]]ian folk instrument.
]] A '''folk instrument''' is a [[musical instrument]] that developed among common people and usually does not have a known [[inventor]]. It can be made from [[wood]], [[metal]] or other material. Such an instrument is played in performances of [[Traditional music|folk music]]. ==Overview== The instruments can be percussion instruments, or different types of [[flute]]s or [[trumpet]]s, or string instruments that are plucked, hammered or use a form of [[Bow (music)|bow]]. Some instruments are referred to as folk instruments because they commonly appear in folk music, even though they do not meet the criteria defining a folk instrument; an example is the [[harmonica]].
