{{Infobox network | name = The National Broadcasting Services of Thailand (Radio Thailand) | logo = [[File:Radio Thailand World Service logo.gif|150px]] | country = [[Thailand]] | network_type = [[Radio network]] | available = [[Thailand]], [[Laos]], [[Myanmar]], [[Malaysia]], and [[International]] (World Service) | owner = [[National Broadcasting Services of Thailand]] | key_people = | launch_date = 1938 | past_names = | website = {{URL|http://nbt.prd.go.th/home.html}} }} '''The National Broadcasting Services of Thailand''' (also known as '''Radio Thailand''') is the public radio station in [[Thailand]], owned by the [[National Broadcasting Services of Thailand]]. The station has six FM national radio, 65 FM provincial radio, 4 AM national radio, 46 AM provincial radio and World Service. Some Radio Thailand provincial radio stations can be received in neighbor countries of Thailand like Malaysia, Laos and Myanmar. ==FM stations== * FM 88.0 MHz – Wave FM (foreign languages) * FM 92.5 MHz – National radio network * FM 93.5 MHz – Happy Time HD1 (private leases) * FM 95.5 MHz – Virgin Hitz (private leases) * FM 97.0 MHz – Quality News Station * FM 105.0 MHz – Happy Family Radio (for children, youth and families) and 65 FM provincial radio stations ==AM stations== * AM 819 kHz – Radio networks for the transmission of voice * AM 837 kHz - Radio networks of wisdom to the listener * AM 891 kHz - National radio network * AM 918 kHz - ASEAN language radio * AM 1467 kHz - Educational radio and 46 AM provincial radio stations ==AM and FM Stations== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Callsign !! Frequency !! Power !! Transmitter location |- | National network AM || AM 891 kHz || 1000 kW || 236 Vibhavadi Rangsit Road {ถ.วิภาวดีรังสิต}
Khet Din Daeng {เขตดินแดง}
BANGKOK 10400 {กรุงเทพฯ} |- | National network FM || FM 92.5 MHz || 10 kW || Bangkok |} ===Broadcast hours=== 04:55-24:00 (daily) ==Shortwave radio== * [[Radio Thailand World Service]] – Broadcasts in Thai, Khmer, Malay, English, Burmese and Chinese languages for International ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://nbt.prd.go.th/home.html/ Radio Thailand Official Portal] {{coord missing|Thailand}} [[Category:Radio in Thailand]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1938]] [[Category:1938 establishments in Siam]] [[Category:Radio stations in Thailand]]

revision.comment: Improved article to match Manual of Style, References after punctuation per [[WP:CITEFOOT]] and [[WP:PAIC]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]] (12151)
revision.text:
'''Televisión Serrana''' (TVS), is a community-based television and video collective operating in [[Sierra Maestra]] in Cuba. TVS was founded by Daniel Diez Castillo in 1993 and is located in the small town of San Pablo de Yao, in the [[Buey Arriba]] territory. This small community inhabits 32, 000 people and most are coffee growers and/or producers. The focus of TVS is to acknowledge and give voice to the farmers in the [[mountain ranges]]. TVS is preserving the culture of this small community and “connecting them to the broader cultural life of Cuba <ref>Americas Media Initiative. http://americasmediainitiative.org/?page_id=55. Retrieved May 4, 2011</ref>
TVS promotes awareness of the lives of those living in the Sierra Maestra through the form of [[art]]. TVS uses art to speak about the community's needs, beliefs, identity and to find “solutions to problems”<ref>Americas Media Initiative. http://americasmediainitiative.org/?page_id=55. Retrieved May 4, 2011</ref> in the region. TVS received national recognition on January 15, 1993 when institutions came together to sponsor and support TVS. [[UNESCO]] provided additional funding and support. The [[Cuban government]] supplied staff and training for employers and volunteers through the [[Cuban Institute of Radio and Television|ICRT]].<ref>TV Serrana. http://www.tvserrana.icrt.cu/index.php/qsomos. Retrieved May 4, 2011.</ref>
== Mission == Televisión Serrana was founded to "rescue the culture of ''[[Tenant farmer|campesino]]'' communities" and to foster communication between communities, particularly those in the mountainous region of the Sierra Maestra.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Stock|first1=Anne Marie|title=On Location in Cuba: Street Filmmaking During Times of Transition|publisher=The University of North Carolina Press|isbn=9780807832691}}</ref> Through the exchange of information, TVS hopes to identify solutions to common problems between these communities. Furthermore, TVS aims to affirm the [[identity (philosophy)|identity]] of the people of the Sierra Maestra during a time of increased [[globalism]].
{{wide image|Mountains of San Pablo de Yao.jpg|600px|alt=Taken at Television Serrana|The Sierra Maestra as seen from Televisión Serrana .}}
== History ==
The project of TV Serrana began in 1993 by Daniel Diez Castillo. Castillo was a television producer in [[Havana]], [[Cuba]] from The Cuban National Broadcasting Channel (ICRT). When Castillo left Havana, Cuba was in the “Periodo Especial” or [[Special Period]]. This was the economic crisis that followed after the fall of the Soviet Union. Castillo went east towards the region of the Sierra Maestra. The Sierra Maestra is known for its amazing mountains and the men who came across it. [[Fidel Castro]], [[Che Guevara]] and many other rebels organized themselves to fight against [[Fulgencio Batista]]. Due to the mountainous terrain, the Sierra Maestra became isolated from other parts of [[Cuba]]. Before Castillo came along, the rest of Cuba portrayed Sierra Maestra as the "producers of staples; nothing was said about their dreams, their conflicts, their culture" <ref>Dagron,Alfonso Gumicio(2001). "Making Waves: Stories of Participatory Communication for Social Change</ref> . Daniel Diez Castillo then wanted to film the real Sierra Maestra, his goal was to “make a collective form of cinema, to produce movies and documentaries narrating the history and identity of people living that area, to create a form of partaken communication far from the capital” <ref>DigiMag. "Television Serrana, Mountain Network". http://www.digicult.it/digimag/article.asp?id=586. Retrieved May 17, 2011.</ref> . TV Serrana was first funded by [[UNESCO]], but after time they were able to self-fund its own programs.
==Tools and Main Features of Television Serrana== Tools used for Television Serrana are simple, it includes: "[[VHS]], Super VHS and Beta nonprofessional cameras and editing equipment".<ref>Dagron,Alfonso Gumicio(2001). "Making Waves: Stories of Participatory Communication for Social Change</ref> The crew of TVS consists of “three cameramen, three directors, two editors, two producers, two sound assistants and three drivers <ref>Dagron,Alfonso Gumicio(2001). "Making Waves: Stories of Participatory Communication for Social Change</ref> who also set up the lighting when needed. One main feature used in TVS are video letters. A video letter is a reportage that captures the people of Sierra Maestra’s experiences, lives and dreams through their own perspective. Video letters are not edited by the media, but they show the true reality and struggles of the people. Video letters are also important because they are seen by others and are used for responding. They create communication between boundaries and is a great factor in Television Serrana.
==Services Provided== The program aims to promote self-sustaining activities, TV Serrana provides programs and opportunities to the people living within the villages. A majority of the training workshops were given through El Centro de Estudios para la Comunicación Comunitaria (CECC), created in 1996. TV Serrana along with the help of supporting institutions provides training and services through seminars that help locals with communication and community building skills through the use of media. These programs offer lessons to villagers "willing to use video in their communities as a tool for participatory development and democratic communication".<ref>Dagron,Alfonso Gumicio(2001). "Making Waves: Stories of Participatory Communication for Social Change</ref> Other services accessible through TVS is the ability to transfer and copy video-cassettes from and to Beta VHS and [[S-VHS]] which allow people within the communities to share their stories.
==Constraints== Television Serrana has been a growing success, but there were difficulties in the beginning. One of the problems of TVS was the lack of experience many of the crew members had. Most had to take training sessions on how to work media products and running programs within the community. As mentioned before, the trainees had to learn how to do video letters and how to transfer and copy video-cassettes to and from Beta VHS. The greatest of constraints for the project was gaining the trust and confidence needed by the local communities. Many of the villagers were skeptical of the programs intentions, which created difficulties to gain the support from locals. The people of [[Sierra Maestra]] felt the newcomers were intruding onto their land, interrupting their daily lives and thought the intentions of the crew were to give the locals a bad image. The crew had to show the people that they came with positive objectives and wanted to help the communities.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Media in Cuba}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Television Serrana}} [[Category:Television in Cuba]] [[Category:Documentary film production companies]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox play | name = The Second Shepherds' Play | image = Second Shepherds Play 01620035.jpg | image_size = 275px | image_alt = A production photo from a 2005 production of The Second Shepherds' Play by London's Players of St Peter. | caption = The shepherds realise that the babe in the cradle is actually a sheep. Players of St Peter, London (2005). | writer = The Wakefield Master | characters = {{plainlist| * Coll, ''First Shepherd'' * Gyb, ''Second Shepherd'' * Daw, ''Third Shepherd'' * Mak * Gill, ''Mak's wife'' * The Angel * [[Mary, mother of Jesus]] * [[Jesus Christ|Christ-child]]}} | setting = Medieval England and Bethlehem
1st Century AD | date of premiere = Unknown (possibly c. 1500) | country of Origin = [[England]] | original language = [[Middle English]] | genre = [[Mystery Play]] | series = [[Wakefield Cycle]] }} '''''The Second Shepherds' Play''''' (also known as '''''The Second Shepherds' Pageant''''') is a famous medieval [[mystery play]] which is contained in the manuscript HM1, the unique manuscript of the [[Wakefield Cycle]]. These plays are also referred to as the Towneley Plays, on account of the manuscript residing at Towneley Hall. The plays within the manuscript roughly follow the chronology of the Bible and so were believed to be a cycle, which is now considered not to be the case.{{cite book|last=Black|first=Joseph|title=The Broadview Anthology of British Literature, Concise Edition, Volume A, Second Edition|year=2012|publisher=Broadview Press|location=Canada|display-authors=etal}} This play gained its name because in the manuscript it immediately follows another [[Nativity of Jesus|nativity]] play involving the [[shepherd]]s. In fact, it has been hypothesized that the second play is a revision of the first.{{cite book|last=Robinson|first=J. W.|title=Studies in Fifteenth-century Stagecraft|year=1991|publisher=Western Michigan University Medieval Institute|location=Kalamazoo|isbn=0918720389}} It appears that the two shepherd plays were not intended to be performed together since many of the themes and ideas of the first play carry over to the second one.{{cite journal|last=Abate|first=Michelle Ann|title=Oversight as Insight: Reading ''The Second Shepherds' Play'' as ''The Second Shepherd's Play''|journal=Early Theatre|year=2005|url=http://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?id=GALE%7CA228909188&v=2.1&u=iuclassb&it=r&p=LitRC&sw=w|accessdate=17 July 2012|publisher=Literature Resource Center}} In both plays it becomes clear that Christ is coming to Earth to redeem the world from its sins. Although the underlying tone of ''The Second Shepherd's Play'' is serious, many of the antics that occur among the shepherds are extremely farcical in nature. ==Plot== The biblical portion of the play, a retelling of the Visitation of the Shepherds, comes only after a longer, invented story that mirrors it, in which the shepherds, before visiting the holy baby outside in a manger, must first rescue one of their sheep that has been hidden in a cradle indoors by a comically evil sheep-stealing couple. Once they have discovered and punished the thieves, the storyline switches to the familiar one of the three shepherds being told of the birth of [[Christ]] by an [[angel]], and going to [[Bethlehem]] to offer the true Child gifts. At the start of the play, Coll, the first shepherd ("primus pastor") arrives in a field, invoking God in anachronistic terms (referring, as the shepherds will do throughout the play, to the life and death of Christ even though at this point of the play Christ has not yet been born) complaining about the (typically English) cold weather and about his poverty and the arrogance of local gentry. He begins by saying, "Lord, what these weders are cold! And I am ill happyed" which translates as "Lord [God], the weather is cold and I am ill prepared/clothed." Gib, the second shepherd, arrives without seeing Coll and complains first about the weather and then about the plight of married men, himself included, with bawdy speculation about the lives of men with more than one wife and advice to "young men of wooing" to "Be well war of weding" (wary of marriage). He paints a portrait of his wife as a loud, heavy-drinking, alternately abusive and sentimentally pious, whale-sized woman. "By him that died for us all, I would I had run til I had lost her!" at which point he is startled by Coll. They confer about where Daw, a third, young, lazy and mischievous, shepherd, has gotten to, at which point Daw arrives complaining about employers, hunger, and about recent floods which he compares to [[Noah]]'s flood. Mak, a local good-for-nothing and well-known thief, arrives and pretends to be a yeoman from a lord. Although they recognize him from the start, he insults and threatens them by saying that he will have them flogged. When they threaten him, he pretends not to have known who they were. Mak tries to gain sympathy from the shepherds by explaining how his wife is a lazy drunk who gives birth to too many children. Invoking Christ and Pontius Pilate, Mak agrees to camp with the shepherds, and feigns to lie down among them. However, once they have fallen asleep he casts a spell to make sure they will not wake up and then sneaks off to steal one of their sheep. He heads back to his cottage and trades insults with Gill, his wife, who firmly believes that Mak will be hanged for the theft and comes up with a plan for hiding the sheep – she will put it in an empty cradle and pretend that it is her newborn child, and that she is loudly, painfully in labor with its twin, so that the shepherds will quickly give up any search. Mak sneaks back among the shepherds and pretends to awaken along with them. They head off to take account of their sheep while Mak heads home to prepare. With despair at their catastrophic ill fortune, the shepherds realize a sheep is missing and go to search Mak's house. They are initially fooled by Mak and Gill's ruse despite Gill going so far as to say that if she's lying she'll eat the child in her cradle (as she indeed plans to). The shepherds leave defeated, but realize that they have failed to bring any gifts to the "baby", and go back. When they remove the swaddling clothes they recognize their sheep, but decide not to kill Mak but instead roll him in canvas and throw him up and down, punishing him until they are exhausted. When they have left Mak's cottage, the biblical story proper begins – the Angel appears and tells them to go to "Bedlam" ([[Bethlehem]]) to see the Christ child. They wonder at the event, chastising each other for their collective delay, and then go to the manger where [[Mary (Mother of Jesus)]] welcomes them and receives their praise for her mildness. They each address the Child in turn, beginning by praising His authority and His creation of all things in tones of reverence and awe, but each comically shifting mid-speech to cooing, gushing baby talk, since they are addressing an adorable baby, who Coll, Gib, and Daw respectively give "a bob of cherries," a bird, and a ball ("Have and play thee withal, and go to the tennis!") The shepherds rejoice at their salvation, all thoughts of hardship and complaint vanished, and leave singing in unison.{{cite book|last=Wakefield Master|title=''"The Second Shepherd's Play." in'' Early English Drama: An Anthology|year=2010|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|isbn=0824054652|edition=Rev.|editor=John C. Coldewey|pages=343–63.}} ==Authorship== The name "Wakefield Master" is a title given by [[Charles Mills Gayley]] to an unknown author of at least five of the plays that are found in the Wakefield Mystery Plays. In 1903, Gayley and Alwin Thaler published an anthology of criticism and dramatic selections entitled ''Representative English Comedies.'' It had long been believed that the Towneley Play was a mediocre work that showed extensive borrowing from other sources but containing vibrant and exciting material, apparently by one author, who was responsible for four or five complete pageants and extensive revisions. Gayley refers to this person as the "master" (with a lowercase m) in the book. Then, in a 1907 article, Gayley amended this to "The Wakefield Master", the name which is still frequently used ([[Wakefield Mystery Plays|Wakefield Cycle Authorship]]). Of the 32 plays found in the manuscript, tradition has attributed ''The Second Shepherd's Play'' to the "Wakefield Master", along with ''Noah'', ''The First Shepherd's Play'', ''Herod the Great'', and ''The Buffeting of Christ.'' A sixth play, ''The Killing of Abel'' is also thought to have been heavily influenced by him if not exclusively written by him, along with ''The Last Judgment,'' of which he contributed to at least half. Many of the other plays in the manuscript have a few stanzas that were most likely written by him as well.{{cite book|last=Purdon|first=Liam O.|title=The Wakefield Master's Dramatic Art: A Drama of Spiritual Understanding|year=2003|publisher=University Press of Florida|location=Gainesville|isbn=0813026032}} Although nothing is known about the author, or the origins of the plays, it is agreed by several scholars that they date sometime between 1400-1450. Because of his influence in most of the Wakefield plays, it is possible he was brought into Wakefield with the purpose of editing and reworking the several plays that were already written, and did such a successful job that he was kept on to write several other plays afterwards. The plays he wrote might have replaced plays that were taken from York and it is believed that he is a contemporary to the "York Master", another unnamed playwright who produced several other influential plays during the same era. Some question the existence of one "Wakefield Master", and propose that multiple authors could have written in the Wakefield Stanza. However, scholars and literary critics find it useful to hypothesize a single talent behind them, due to the unique poetic qualities of the works ascribed to him. The plays of the "Wakefield Master" are identified by their unique stanza form, which is nine lines rhyming a b c c c b with internal rhymes in the first four lines.{{cite book|title=''"Introduction." in'' Early English Drama: An Anthology|year=2010|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|isbn=0824054652|edition=Rev.|editor=Coldewey, John C.|pages=1–8}} {{quote|''We that walk in the nights, our cattle to keep,'' ''We see sudden sights, when other men sleep.'' ''Yet methink my heart lights—I see shrews peep.'' ''Ye are two all-wights! I will give my sheep'' ''A turn.'' ''But full ill have I meant;'' ''As I walk on this bent,'' ''I may lightly repent'' ''My toes if I spurn.''}} This stanza format is the primary evidence critics use to identify what has been written by him. Along with his unique stanzas, the "Wakefield Master's" plays are also characterized by their emphasis on characterization that delves into the rural contemporary life of the characters. Using modern day technology which included plows, mills, and forges, as well as colloquial speech amongst the dialogue between the characters, the stories exemplified early traits of realism that would have made the stories more relevant for the audience of that time period. The author also used contrasting dialects in ''The Second Shepherd's Play'', in the part where Mak pretends to be a yeoman. The regular dialect is Northern-midlands, with Mak's deceptive dialect being from the south. Two different studies (Trusler, and Cawley) on the main dialect certified that these plays did come from Wakefield.{{cite journal|last=Irace|first=Kathleen|title=Mak's Sothren Tothe: A Philological and Critical Study of the Dialect Joke in the Second Shepherd's Play|journal=Comitatus: A Journal of Medieval and Renaissance Studies|date=1990|volume=21|issue=1|pages=38–39|url=https://escholarship.org/uc/item/0tb597k2|accessdate=9 February 2015}} ==Stage== Depending on the area of the performances, the plays were performed in the middle of the street, on [[pageant wagon]]s in the streets of great cities (this was inconvenient for the actors because the small stage size made stage movement difficult), in the halls of [[nobility]], or [[in the round]] in amphitheatres, as suggested by current archaeology in Cornwall and the southwest of England. All medieval stage production was temporary and expected to be removed upon the completion of the performances. Actors, predominantly male, typically wore long, dark robes. Medieval plays, such as the Wakefield cycle or the Digby Magdalene, featured lively interplay between two distinct areas—the wider spaces in front of the raised staging areas, and the elevated areas themselves (called, respectively, the platea and the locus). Also typical was to have the actors would move between these locations in order to suggest scene changes, rather than remain stationary and have the scene change around them as is typically done in modern theater.{{cite journal|last=Vaughan|first=Míċeál F.|title=The Three Advents in the Secunda Pastorum|journal=Speculum|date=Jul 1980|volume=55|issue=3|pages=484–504|jstor=2847237|publisher=Medieval Academy of America|doi=10.2307/2847237}} The staging of this play likely required two sets. It is suggested that the first stage is composed of Mak's house. In Mak's house, many of the farcical actions occur (for example, this is the location of where the sheep was "born"). The other stage is where the holy manger and the religious iconography would occur. This is more than likely where the angel appears and where the Shepherds go to visit Mary. These two different stages would allow the audience to easily see the parallels between farcical and serious. ==Criticism and interpretation== Although Albert C. Baugh complained of the combination of low farce and high religious intent in the play,{{cite book|last=Malone|first=Kemp|title=Literary History of England: Vol 1, The Middle Ages|year=1969|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=0203392736|pages=281|edition=2nd|author2=Albert C. Baugh |editor=Albert C. Baugh}} the unity is a distinctive feature of the play, where the Mak-subplot has been shown to have numerous analogues in world folklore.{{cite journal|last=Cosbey|first=Robert C.|title=The Mak Story and Its Folklore Analogues|journal=Speculum|date=Jul 1945|volume=20|issue=3|pages=310–17|jstor=2854613|publisher=Medieval Academy of America|doi=10.2307/2854613}} Wallace H. Johnson theorized that the union of a complete and independent farce with a complete and independent Nativity play resulted from the accumulation of years of horseplay and ad-libbing in rehearsal.{{cite journal|last=Johnson|first=Wallace H.|title=The Origin of ''The Second Shepherds' Play'': A New Theory|journal=Quarterly Journal of Speech|year=1966|volume=52|issue=1|pages=47|doi=10.1080/00335636609382757}} Some have seen the folk-origins of the story as contributing to an extended reflection on class-struggle and solidarity in light of immediate and eternal realities{{cite journal|last=Davis|first=Adam Brooke|title=Folklore and the ''Second Shepherds' Play'': A Study in Discursive Archive and Cultural Politics|journal=Allegorica|year=1992|volume=13|pages=3–20}} {{cite journal|last=Feinstein|first=Sandy|title=Shrews and Sheep in ''The Second Shepherds' Play''|journal=Pacific Coast Philology|volume=36|pages= 64–80|year=2001|doi=10.2307/3595470}} while others have emphasized the theological dimension, in which 15th century England is mystically conflated with first-century Judaea and the Nativity with the Apocalypse. Maynard Mack explains that this play is often categorized as simple and containing little artistic merit. What begins to emerge in Mack's article is that he feels that the play is not only sophisticated, but the comedic aspects are there to enhance the rest of the text. He explains that in examining the text as two separate entities, a viewer would be doing the text a great injustice; rather, one should view them as a collection whole in order to understand the importance of exaggeration and the idea of a terrible beauty.{{cite journal|last=Maynard|first=Mack, Jr.|title=''The Second Shepherds' Play'': A Reconsideration|journal=PMLA|date=Jan 1978|volume=93|issue=1|pages=78–85|jstor=461821|publisher=Modern Language Association|doi=10.2307/461821}} ==See also== * [[Easter drama]] * ''[[God Spede the Plough]]'' * [[Liturgical drama]] * [[Medieval theatre]] * [[Passion play]] * [[Wakefield Mystery Plays]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * The 1985 Cottesloe Theatre performance of the pageant, adapted into Modern English as ''[[The Mysteries]]'', in three files on YouTube: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O8yiULNjUDg 12:46 to end]; [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jk7HSLE9Qz8 whole track], and [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mj4v1acoDek 00:00 to 1:46 and 8:00 to 11:17]. * [http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/19481 ''"Everyman," with Other Interludes, Including Eight Miracle Plays.''] Full text versions of text of ''The Second Shepherd's Play'' at [[Project Gutenberg]]. * [http://www.luminarium.org/medlit/playtexts.htm "Middle English Play Texts."] Full text resources from the ''Luminarium: Anthology of English Literature.'' * [http://www.folger.edu/template.cfm?cid=2615 "''The Second Shepherds' Play'' and Early English Theater."] A three-part series on the Mystery Plays with Richard Paul of the Folger Shakespeare Library. {{DEFAULTSORT:Second Shepherds' Play}} [[Category:Medieval literature]] [[Category:Folk plays]] [[Category:Medieval drama]] [[Category:Christian plays]] [[Category:Plays set in the 1st century]] [[Category:15th-century Christian texts]] [[Category:15th-century plays]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox video game | title = Wolfenstein: The Old Blood | image = Wolfenstein The Old Blood cover.jpg | alt = The game's cover art. The text "wolfenstein" is in the top right, with the text "THE OLD BLOOD" written underneath it. Behind the text is a man, preparing to use a pipe to hit an enemy. | caption = | developer = [[MachineGames]] | publisher = [[Bethesda Softworks]] | director = Jonathan Heckley | producer = John Jennings | designer = Arcade Berg{{cite web |last=Lahti |first=Evan |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/how-to-make-nazis-fun-to-fight-and-other-wolfenstein-questions/ |title=How to make Nazis fun to fight, and other Wolfenstein questions |website=[[PC Gamer]] | publisher=[[Future plc]] |date=4 May 2015 |accessdate=9 May 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150509175830/http://www.pcgamer.com/how-to-make-nazis-fun-to-fight-and-other-wolfenstein-questions/ |archivedate=9 May 2015 |deadurl=no}} | programmer = Anton Ragnarsson
Markus Buretorp | artist = Axel Torvenius
Tor Frick | writer = Tommy Tordsson Björk | composer = [[Mick Gordon (composer)|Mick Gordon]] | engine = [[id Tech 5]] | series = ''[[Wolfenstein (series)|Wolfenstein]]'' | platforms = {{Unbulleted list|[[Microsoft Windows]]|[[PlayStation 4]]|[[Xbox One]]}} | released = {{Video game release|WW|5 May 2015 {{small|(digital)}}|AU|14 May 2015|EU|15 May 2015|NA|21 July 2015 (PS4, XONE)}} | genre = [[First-person shooter]], [[Action-adventure game|action-adventure]], [[Stealth game|stealth]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] }} '''''Wolfenstein: The Old Blood''''' is an [[Action-adventure game|action-adventure]] [[first-person shooter]] video game developed by [[MachineGames]] and published by [[Bethesda Softworks]]. It was released on 5 May 2015 for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 4]], and [[Xbox One]]. The game is a stand-alone title in the [[Wolfenstein (series)|''Wolfenstein'' series]] and a [[prequel]] to 2014's ''[[Wolfenstein: The New Order]]'', set in an alternate-history 1946. The [[Single-player video game|single-player]] story follows war veteran [[William "B.J." Blazkowicz]] and his efforts to discover the locations of a [[Nazism|Nazi]] compound. Development began in 2014, soon after the release of ''The New Order''. The game is played from a [[First-person (video games)|first-person perspective]] and its levels are navigated on foot. The story is arranged in chapters which players complete in order to progress, separated into two interconnected campaigns. The game features a variety of weapons, including pistols, shotguns, and explosives, most of which can be [[dual wield]]ed. A [[cover system]] is also present; players lean in and out of cover instead of the more common system where players lock into cover. ''Wolfenstein: The Old Blood'' received generally positive reviews. Many critics praised the game's intense firefights, intriguing locations, and the balance between [[stealth game|stealth]] and action. Many critics disliked the game's story, however, with most reviewers saying that it was the weakest part of the game and a step back compared to ''The New Order''{{'}}s story, which was highly complimented. ==Gameplay== [[File:Wolfenstein The Old Blood gameplay.jpg|thumb|left|''Wolfenstein: The Old Blood'' gameplay. Like ''The New Order'', players assault AI-programmed hostiles such as this Panzerhund.]] ''Wolfenstein: The Old Blood'' changes little from the basic gameplay of ''The New Order''. As such, it is an [[Action-adventure game|action-adventure]] [[shooter game]] played from a [[First person (video games)|first-person perspective]]. To progress through the story, players take on enemies while navigating throughout levels.{{cite news |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/lifestyle/staying-in/video-games/wolfenstein-new-order-5-things-3574854 |title=Wolfenstein The New Order: 5 things you need to know about the latest instalment |last=Munbodh |first=Emma |newspaper=[[Daily Mirror|The Mirror]] |publisher=[[Trinity Mirror|Trinity Mirror plc]] |date=20 May 2014 |accessdate=25 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6S295IJ9q |archivedate=23 August 2014 |deadurl=no}} The game utilizes a health system in which players' health is divided into separate sections, "health" and "armor", that regenerate. If an entire section is lost, players must find and use a health pack or body armor piece, to replenish the missing health.{{cite web |url=https://www.techradar.com/au/news/gaming/5-things-you-need-to-know-about-wolfenstein-the-new-order-1249610 |title=5 things you need to know about Wolfenstein: The New Order |last=Langley |first=Hugh |website=[[TechRadar]] |publisher=[[Future plc]] |date=20 May 2014 |accessdate=25 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6S2C5SM7u |archivedate=23 August 2014 |deadurl=no}} Players use [[Melee#Use in gaming|melee]] attacks, firearms and explosives to fight enemies, and may run, jump and occasionally swim to navigate through the locations. Melee attacks can be used to silently take down enemies without being detected. Alternatively, players can [[ambush]] enemies, which will result in an intense [[Shootout|firefight]] between the two parties. Enemy types vary; standard [[Nazism|Nazi]] human soldiers, which vary in strength, robot-like characters known as Supersoldaten (Super Soldiers), giant mechanical dogs known as Panzerhunds, [[zombie]]-like Nazi soldiers and civilians known as Shamblers, and vicious dogs are some of the enemies players will encounter.{{cite web |url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/wolfenstein-the-new-order-offers-a-choice-quiet-stealth-or-bloody-mayhem/1100-6419290/ |title=Wolfenstein: The New Order offers a choice – Quiet stealth or bloody mayhem |last=Makuch |first=Eddie |website=[[GameSpot]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |date=29 April 2014 |accessdate=25 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6S2C9g5FP |archivedate=23 August 2014 |deadurl=no}} In combat, a [[cover system]] can be used as assistance against enemies. Players have the ability to lean around, over, and under cover, which can be used as a [[Positional advantage|tactical advantage]] during shootouts and [[Stealth game|stealth]] levels.{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/erikkain/2014/05/21/5-reasons-why-wolfenstein-the-new-order-is-shooter-of-the-year-so-far/ |title=5 Reasons Why 'Wolfenstein: The New Order' Is Shooter Of The Year (So Far) |last=Kain |first=Erik |website=[[Forbes]] |publisher=Forbes Media, LLC |date=21 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6S2CEpxgH |archivedate=23 August 2014 |deadurl=no}} Players have access to a weapon inventory, which allows the player to carry as many weapons as they find. With some of these weapons, players have the ability to [[dual wield]], giving them an advantage over enemies by dealing twice as much damage. ''The Old Blood'' adds various weapons that were not featured in ''The New Order'', such as a steel pipe. The steel pipe is one of the biggest additions to the game; it consists of two small steel pipes which can be connected together to make a larger pipe. Both pipe states can be used as a melee attacks (each with their own animations) and in specific circumstances. The two small pipes, called "Pipes" in the weapon inventory, can be used to climb rock walls, and the large pipe, called "Pipe" in the inventory, is used to break open weak environmental surfaces. The game gives players a wide variety of weapon options—they can be found on the ground, retrieved from dead enemies, or removed from their stationary position and carried around.{{cite web |url=https://venturebeat.com/2014/05/20/wolfenstein-the-new-order-battles-evil-nazis-but-cant-fight-off-middling-reviews/ |title=Wolfenstein: The New Order battles evil Nazis but can't fight off middling reviews |last=Takahashi |first=Dean |website=[[VentureBeat]] |date=20 May 2014 |accessdate=25 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6S2ChpvT4 |archivedate=23 August 2014 |deadurl=no}} Weapon ammunition must be manually retrieved from the ground or from dead enemies.{{cite web |url=https://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/223752/Game_Design_Deep_Dive_Ammo_Collection_in_Wolfenstein_The_New_Order.php |title=Game Design Deep Dive: Ammo Collection in Wolfenstein: The New Order |last=Gustafsson |first=Jerk |website=[[Gamasutra]] |publisher=[[UBM plc]] |date=21 August 2014 |accessdate=23 August 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6S2LUiN75 |archivedate=23 August 2014 |deadurl=no}} As with ''The New Order'', players can complete "Perks"; each Perk has a task the player can complete. Perks encourage the player to change their play style on the fly; collecting "helmets", getting silent kills, killing specific enemies a select number of times, getting a set number of kills with a specific weapon, and getting kills via explosives are some of the objectives. Once a Perk's task is complete, the player unlocks a bonus, such as more overall health or armor, more ammunition for a certain weapon, or the ability to gain health after a silent takedown. Various collectibles are also scattered throughout the levels; concept art, character models and bios, notes, which tell small side stories of the game, and gold bars are some of the collectibles.{{cite web |url=https://www.primagames.com/games/wolfenstein-new-order/coverage/wolfenstein-old-blood-walkthrough-and-collectibles |title=Wolfenstein: The Old Blood Walkthrough and Collectibles |last=Lavoy |first=Bill |website=[[Prima Games]] |publisher=[[Random House]] |date=12 May 2015 |accessdate=27 May 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ypfx3u3B |archivedate=27 May 2015 |deadurl=no}} Other modes in the game differing from the main chapters are Challenge Arenas and Nightmare Levels. Challenge Arenas unlock as the player progresses through the story and are accessed from the main menu. Being a basic arena battle mode, players fight waves of enemies to obtain a Bronze, Silver, or Gold metal.{{cite web |url=http://gamestyle.com/review/wolfenstein-the-old-blood-review/ |title=Wolfenstein: The Old Blood Review |last=Gulliver |first=Adam |website=GameStyle |publisher=[[WordPress]] |date=11 May 2015 |accessdate=28 May 2015}} Nightmare Levels are accessed by finding and interacting with a bed that is hidden in each chapter. There's a hidden [[easter egg (media)|easter egg]] where players can play ''[[Wolfenstein 3D]]''; the player moves through pixelated hallways, mostly equipped with just a pistol, fighting Nazi soldiers. The objective is to find a key that unlocks an elevator.{{cite web |url=https://www.usgamer.net/articles/wolfenstein-the-old-blood-nightmare-guide |title=Wolfenstein: The Old Blood Nightmare Guide |last=Hawkins |first=Josh |website=[[Eurogamer|USGamer]] |publisher=Gamer Network |date=11 May 2015 |accessdate=28 May 2015}} ==Plot== ''Wolfenstein: The Old Blood'' takes place in an [[alternate history]] 1946, just prior to the prologue of ''Wolfenstein: The New Order'', with O.S.A. agents William "B.J." Blazkowicz ([[Brian Bloom]]) and Richard Wesley (taking up the codename Agent One) on a mission to infiltrate Castle Wolfenstein and obtain a top secret folder containing the location of ''[[SS-Oberst-Gruppenführer]]'' Wilhelm "Deathshead" Strasse from the castle's commander, Nazi archeologist and ''[[Standartenführer]]in'' Helga von Schabbs. Entering the castle disguised as [[Schutzstaffel]] officers, B.J. and Wesley fail to find the folder and are captured by Helga's lieutenant, ''[[Sturmbannführer]]'' Rudi Jäger, a massive and sadistic dog trainer who feeds captured prisoners to his mechanically augmented canines. While Wesley is dragged away by Rudi for interrogation, B.J. succeeds in escaping the prison cells and fighting his way through the castle. B.J. eventually locates Wesley strapped to an electric chair used by the Nazis for torture. Before B.J. can rescue Wesley, Rudi activates the chair and electrocutes him. Jager then feeds Wesley's dead body to his prized albino dog, Greta, and straps B.J. into the chair, shocking him as well. B.J. breaks free, injures Rudi, and kills Greta. Escaping the castle, B.J. travels to the nearby village of Paderborn and meets up with the local [[German resistance to Nazism|German resistance]] leader, Ludwig Kessler, as well as Kessler's assistant Annette, a young [[Jews|Jewish]] girl whom Kessler is sheltering from the Nazis. Kessler's tavern is attacked by Nazi forces led by Rudi, wearing an experimental suit of [[Powered exoskeleton|power armor]], whom B.J. defeats and kills. B.J., Kessler, and Annette flee via rowboat to the village of Wulfburg, where Helga is conducting an archeological excavation attempting to find a hidden underground vault containing occult knowledge previously possessed by [[Otto I, Holy Roman Emperor|King Otto I]]. After meeting up with O.S.A. operative Pippa (codenamed Agent Two), B.J. disguises himself as a waiter and infiltrates the tavern where Helga is staying. Helga sees through B.J.'s disguise and captures him, but B.J. manages to escape during a massive earthquake caused by the Nazis opening the vault. The opening of the vault also releases a gas that causes anyone that dies within the vicinity of Wulfburg to reanimate as hostile, burning, zombies known as "shamblers". B.J. fights his way through the burning ruins of Wulfburg while fighting through the zombified Nazis and civilians who died in the earthquake. Agent Two is killed by a shambler, and B.J. has to kill her again when she reanimates as one. Attempting to return to Kessler and Annette, B.J. finds the two of them have gone into Wulfburg in an attempt to rescue Annette's companion, Katrin. B.J. finds Annette and Kessler separated by a collapsing bridge and stranded on opposite buildings, and the player is given the choice of traveling to Annette's building or Kessler's building. The person B.J. travels to will be rescued by him, while the other person will be killed by the shamblers. B.J. then travels to the Nazi excavation in pursuit of Helga, finally encountering her within King Otto's vault. There he finds the source of the zombie-creating gas, an undead giant known as 'The Monstrosity,' a creature created by King Otto's alchemists as a weapon of war, then sealed away by the king after deciding it was an abomination. Helga is initially successful in using [[Old High German]] commands to control the monster, but when she attempts to order it to eat B.J., the monster fatally wounds her instead. B.J. fights and kills The Monstrosity, then finally obtains the secret folder from a dying Helga. B.J. is extracted from Wulfburg by his friend Fergus, and the two of them embark from [[RAF Kinloss]] to assassinate Deathshead and end the war, while B.J. thinks about the nature of monsters and hopes that he can finally rest after this [[Wolfenstein: The New Order|one final mission]]. ==Development== The existence of ''Wolfenstein: The Old Blood'' was first acknowledged by [[Bethesda Softworks]] on 4 March 2015, through the release of an announcement trailer.{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/03/04/bethesda-reveals-wolfenstein-the-new-blood |title=Bethesda Reveals Wolfenstein: The Old Blood |last=Reilly |first=Luke |website=[[IGN]] |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |date=4 March 2015 |accessdate=9 March 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6WsqjBZvT |archivedate=8 March 2015 |deadurl=no}} Footage of the game was showcased at [[Penny Arcade Expo|PAX East]] on 6–7 March 2015.{{cite web |url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2015-03-06-first-gameplay-of-wolfenstein-the-old-blood |title=First gameplay of Wolfenstein: The Old Blood |last=Yin-Poole |first=Wesley |website=[[Eurogamer]] |publisher=Gamer Network |date=6 March 2015 |accessdate=9 March 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Wsr0RoUa |archivedate=8 March 2015 |deadurl=no}} Though initially announced to only be available digitally, it was later confirmed that the game would also receive a physical retail release in Europe, Australia and New Zealand.{{cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/03/20/wolfenstein-the-old-blood-physical-release-dates-announced-for-europe |title=Wolfenstein: The Old Blood Physical Release Dates Announced for Europe |last=Kubba |first=Sinan |website=[[IGN]] |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |date=20 March 2015 |accessdate=17 March 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Xqxchfq3 |archivedate=17 March 2015 |deadurl=no}} The development team initially planned to create a series of individual [[downloadable content]] (DLC) packs, but later decided to change this to a [[Stand-alone expansion pack|standalone expansion pack]]. When this decision was made, development on two of the DLC was already underway, and the team decided to merge the two DLC into one standalone game. During this process, some members of the team experimented with creating artwork of the game in the style of movie posters from the 1960s, resulting in the inspiration to make the game have a "[[B movie]] vibe", though the game also took inspiration from films such as ''[[The Dirty Dozen]]'' (1967) and ''[[Where Eagles Dare]]'' (1968).{{cite web |url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/wolfenstein_the_old_blood/b/playstation4/archive/2015/04/24/machinegames-looks-to-the-past-to-inform-the-future.aspx |title=MachineGames Looks To The Past To Inform The Future |last=Miller |first=Matt |website=[[Game Informer]] |publisher=[[GameStop]] |date=24 April 2015 |accessdate=27 April 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Y6I71Wzg |archivedate=27 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} The development team's decision to make the game a prequel was to allow players to experience the game without playing previous titles in the series.{{cite web |url=http://www.bethblog.com/2015/03/12/new-gameplay-the-old-blood/ |title=New Gameplay. The Old Blood |last=Grandstaff |first=Matt |website=[[Bethesda Softworks]] |publisher=[[ZeniMax Media]] |date=12 March 2015 |accessdate=15 March 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6X291sklC |archivedate=14 March 2015}} It also allowed the team to explore concepts that were mentioned in ''The New Order''. For the game, the team aimed to focus on gameplay. "It's something you can just play through and immediately have fun", said executive producer Jerk Gustafsson. The team also tried to create different route possibilities within the combat spaces, offering a balance between stealth and action sequences. At one point during the game, Blazkowicz encounters a group of inebriated Nazis singing in a tavern. Though the [[motion capture]] was performed by actors, the audio director requested for the voices to be performed by members of the development team; to achieve an accurate performance, members of the team learned some [[German language|German]], and became inebriated prior to recording.{{cite web |url=http://www.bethblog.com/2015/04/15/7-things-you-need-to-know-about-wolfenstein-the-old-blood/ |title=7 Things You Need to Know About Wolfenstein: The Old Blood |last=Steinman |first=Gary |website=[[Bethesda Softworks]] |publisher=[[ZeniMax Media]] |date=15 April 2015 |accessdate=17 April 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XpdlXR6N |archivedate=16 April 2015}} The team initially planned to reuse assets from ''The New Order'' in ''The Old Blood'', but ultimately altered most assets in some way. Due to the team's focus on [[History of video game consoles (eighth generation)|eighth generation]] consoles and PC, they were able to achieve some [[Rendering (computer graphics)|rendering]] updates, as well as the creation of larger and more detailed environments in the game. The game also intentionally included several references to ''[[Return to Castle Wolfenstein]]''.{{cite web |url=https://www.vg247.com/2015/04/15/wolfenstein-the-old-blood-pc-ps4-xbox-one-zombie-nazi/ |title=Content in Wolfenstein: The Old Blood tips its hat to Return to Castle Wolfenstein |last=Nunneley |first=Stephany |website=[[VG247]] |date=15 April 2015 |accessdate=21 June 2016}} ''Wolfenstein: The Old Blood'' makes use of an original score, composed by musician Mick Gordon, who also composed the [[Wolfenstein: The New Order ‒ Original Game Soundtrack|soundtrack]] for ''The New Order''. To create music with a style reflecting the game, Gordon performed with a [[string quartet]], spending time manipulating a broken [[mandolin]] and [[cello]]. He also placed some items inside a [[piano]], to create a unique sound.{{cite web |url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/what-s-new-in-wolfenstein-the-old-blood/1100-6426667/ |title=What's New in Wolfenstein: The Old Blood |author=GameSpot staff |website=[[GameSpot]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |date=16 April 2015 |accessdate=17 April 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XqgrVDts Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=23 May 2015}} | MC_XONE = 75/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox-one/wolfenstein-the-old-blood |title=Wolfenstein: The Old Blood for Xbox One Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=23 May 2015}} }} ''Wolfenstein: The Old Blood'' received "generally favorable reviews" on all platforms according to the [[Review aggregator|review aggregation]] website [[Metacritic]]. ''[[Destructoid]]'''s Chris Carter praised the game for its brevity, saying that both episodes "don't waste as much time as some missions in [''The New Order'']. Both Castle Wolfenstein and Wulfburg are expansive enough to justify an entire game." He also said that "the development team does a good job of managing the pacing between stealth and action". Carter said that Helga Von Schabbs is a character that kept him "engaged" throughout the game, that he "slightly [preferred]" ''The Old Blood'' over ''The New Order'', and that choosing to play the game is a "no-brainer". ''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]'''s [[Justin McElroy]] complimented the game's action gameplay, stating that he liked the choice of weapons, the gunplay, and the mix of stealth and action, while being critical of the game for not having the components that made ''The New Order'' great. "''The Old Blood'' suggests [[B movie|B-movie]] camp", McElroy said, "there are barely any moments where the action slows down enough to develop the type of characters and motivation that charged the big combat set pieces in [''The''] ''New Order''". Marty Sliva of [[IGN]] complimented the game's stealth puzzles, saying, "These scenes turn down the volume, but keep the tension high, as many enemies are able to tear you apart extremely quickly if you get caught." Sliva also "appreciated" the easter eggs referencing other Bethesda games, liked the firefights, which he called "satisfying", and praised the environment, which he said was "interesting". Sliva did however dislike the presence of zombies, the "weak" story, and having to manually pick up items. Sliva wrapped up his review by saying "''Wolfenstein: The Old Blood'' doubles down on blood and guts, but in doing so sacrifices some of its heart." ''[[PC Gamer|PC Gamer UK]]'''s Chris Thursten said, "what was novel a year ago isn't necessarily novel now". He was mostly positive of the game's action gunplay, calling it "excellent". He said the Challenge arenas are also a good addition that he'd like to see in future ''Wolfenstein'' games. Most negative comments were related to ''The New Order'', in Thursten's opinion, being superior to ''The Old Blood''. Thursten said ,"Nothing in ''The Old Blood'' exceeds what was achieved in ''The New Order'', and there are moments when the two are uncannily similar". [[GamesRadar+]]'s Andi Hamilton praised the game's shooting gameplay, calling it "satisfying", the "strong" pacing, the visuals, particularly the set pieces, which he called "beautiful", and the fact it's a standalone game, Hamilton said it "works". Hamilton did however call the game's story "weak" compared to ''The New Order'', and said certain stealth sections were "rough". Hamilton summarized his review by saying "''Wolfenstein: The Old Blood'' is another sterling effort from MachineGames, fast proving to be real players in the FPS genre. This add-on clearly has smaller scope than was found in ''The New Order'', keeping things much more 'down to Earth', but the core shooting experience that makes the reborn Wolfenstein such a pleasure to play remains perfectly intact. If you like shooting zombies and Nazis with extravagantly powerful weapons (and lets be honest here, who doesn’t?) this is well worth checking out."{{cite web |url=https://www.gamesradar.com/wolfenstein-old-blood-review/ |last=Hamilton |first=Andi |title=Wolfenstein: The Old Blood review |website=[[GamesRadar+]] |publisher=[[Future plc]] |date=8 May 2015 |accessdate=8 May 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150508230002/http://www.gamesradar.com/wolfenstein-old-blood-review/ |archivedate=8 May 2015 |deadurl=no}} Matt Bertz of ''[[Game Informer]]'' said: "Had ''The Old Blood'' been injected with more new blood, maybe it would have matched or surpassed the quality of ''The New Order''. But by over-relying on nostalgia to drive the experience, it's well-crafted fan service rather than an attempt to push the series in new directions. For a standalone expansion that's not an unforgivable offense, but we're excited to see what Machine Games can do with the series now that this genealogical exercise is flushed out of its system." In Japan, where the Xbox One version was ported for release on 28 May 2015,{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} followed by the PlayStation 4 version on 4 June 2015,{{citation needed|date=April 2018}} ''[[Famitsu]]'' gave it a score of two eights, one nine, and one eight for a total of 33 out of 40. Tom Hoggins of ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' gave the PS4 version four stars out of five and said, "For those that have played through ''The New Order'' and are keen for more of its beefy action, this delivers around 7 hours of it for a decent price. I’d argue ''The Old Blood'' also makes a satisfying starter to ''The New Order''’s more substantial meal if you haven’t yet had a taste. A well-priced piece of downloadable content that works equally well on either side of the main game? Clever." David Jenkins of ''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]'' gave the same console version eight out of ten and called it "A great follow-up to ''The New Order'', which cleverly reuses all of its best features and yet still finds time to add plenty of new elements of its own."{{cite news |url=https://metro.co.uk/2015/05/06/wolfenstein-the-old-blood-review-back-to-the-castle-5183748/ |title=Wolfenstein: The Old Blood review - back to the castle (PS4) |last=Jenkins |first=David |newspaper=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]] |publisher=[[DMG Media]] |date=6 May 2015 |accessdate=2 June 2018}} Justin Clark of ''[[Slant Magazine]]'' gave it three-and-a-half stars out of five and called it "a wonderful palate cleanser, something to undo long-standing wrongs before diving in to a much deeper, gratifying installment. The conundrum is that the people who already know what MachineGames is capable of with this series have seen the future, and ''The Old Blood'' doesn't provide all that compelling a reason to return to the past." Christopher Byrd of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' gave the same console version an average review and said, "The game’s B-movie vibe is evocative of the work of those skilled filmmakers who embrace the silly or even the self-consciously stupid."{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/comic-riffs/wp/2015/05/12/wolfenstein-the-old-blood-review-a-game-that-comfortably-embraces-the-silly/ |title=Wolfenstein: The Old Blood review. A game that comfortably embraces the silly (PS4) |last=Byrd |first=Christopher |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |publisher=Nash Holdings |date=12 May 2015 |accessdate=5 April 2018}} Steve Tilley of ''[[Toronto Sun]]'' similarly gave the same console version a mixed review and stated, "''The Old Blood'' is just OK. It’s a great deal for the price – as a $25 digital download via the PlayStation Store, the Xbox Games Store and Steam, it’s a rarity in an era when 25 bucks might get you a couple map packs’ worth of downloadable content – but I’ve discovered there’s such a thing as too old-school."{{cite news |url=http://torontosun.com/2015/05/06/wolfenstein-the-old-blood-review-new-order-prequel-a-little-too-old-school/wcm/a83ef544-226b-4094-8fe2-c56d63ccfe19 |title=Wolfenstein: The Old Blood review: 'New Order' prequel a little too old-school (PS4) |last=Tilley |first=Steve |newspaper=[[Toronto Sun]] |publisher=[[Postmedia Network]] |date=6 May 2015 |accessdate=5 April 2018}} Drew Toal of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' gave the same console version a mixed review and said that it "just feels a little gratuitous".{{cite web |url=https://games.avclub.com/wolfenstein-the-old-blood-backs-away-from-the-new-orde-1798279776 |title=Wolfenstein: The Old Blood backs away from The New Order’s strengths and into the past (PS4) |last=Toal |first=Drew |website=[[The A.V. Club]] |publisher=[[The Onion]] |date=20 May 2015 |accessdate=5 April 2018}} Ebenezer Samuel of ''[[New York Daily News]]'' gave the Xbox One version three stars out of five and called it "a less weighty experience overall."{{cite news |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/wolfenstein-old-blood-solide-prequel-review-article-1.2226988 |title=Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is solid prequel, but doesn’t match predecessor’s magic: Video Game Review (XONE) |last=Samuel |first=Ebenezer |newspaper=[[New York Daily News]] |publisher=[[Tronc]] |date=18 May 2015 |accessdate=5 April 2018}} {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Portal|Video games}} * {{Official website|http://www.wolfenstein.com/}} * {{IMDb title|4540758}} * {{moby game|id=/wolfenstein-the-old-blood}} {{Wolfenstein series}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wolfenstein: Old Blood, The}} [[Category:2015 video games]] [[Category:Alternate history video games]] [[Category:Bethesda Softworks games]] [[Category:First-person shooters]] [[Category:Horror video games]] [[Category:Interquel video games]] [[Category:Nazism in fiction]] [[Category:Video games about Nazi Germany]] [[Category:PlayStation 4 games]] [[Category:Single-player video games]] [[Category:Stealth video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Sweden]] [[Category:Video game expansion packs]] [[Category:Video game prequels]] [[Category:Video games featuring female antagonists]] [[Category:Video games set in Germany]] [[Category:Video games set in Scotland]] [[Category:Video games set in the 1940s]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Wolfenstein]] [[Category:World War II alternate histories]] [[Category:Xbox One games]] [[Category:Zombie video games]] [[Category:Id Tech games]]

'''World Emoji Day''' is an unofficial holiday celebrated on July 17.<ref>{{cite news|last=Mastroianni |first=Brian |title=For World Emoji Day, Twitter reveals the most popular emoji around the globe |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/world-emoji-day-twitter-reveals-the-most-popular-emoji-around-the-globe/ |accessdate=16 July 2016 |website=[[CBS News]] |date=15 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/fabulous/4472388/12-dates-you-should-have-in-pencilled-in-your-diary/|title=These are the 12 dates you should have in pencilled in your diary... from national hug day to world emoji day.|last=Newton|first=Jennifer|date=2017-09-15|work=The Sun|access-date=2017-09-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-GB}}</ref> The day is deemed a "global celebration of [[emoji]]"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://worldemojiday.com|title=World Emoji Day|website=World Emoji Day|access-date=17 July 2016}}</ref> and is celebrated with emoji events and product releases.<ref>{{cite news|last=Beall |first=Abigaill |title= 17 July is World Emoji Day |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3691923/What-emojis-say-country-Britain-favour-weary-faces-France-loves-heart-Germans-prefer-thumbs-up.html |accessdate=17 July 2016 |newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |date=16 July 2016}}</ref> Celebrated annually since 2014,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2016/07/17/twitter-reveals-canadas-favourite-emojis-in-honour-of-world-emoji-day.html|title=Twitter reveals Canada’s favourite emojis in honour of World Emoji Day {{!}} Toronto Star|website=thestar.com|access-date=2017-06-12}}</ref> [[NBC]] reported that the day was Twitter's top trending item on July 17 in 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/national-international/Why-Is-July-17-World-Emoji-Day-316145711.html|title=World Emoji Day: Why It's on July 17|work=NBC New York|access-date=2017-06-12|language=en}}</ref>
== Origins == World Emoji Day is "the brainchild of [[Jeremy Burge]]"<ref>{{cite news|last=David |first=Javier |title=World Emoji Day finds its place on a packed calendar of holidays |website=[[CNBC]] |date=17 July 2016}}</ref> according to [[CNBC]] who stated that "London-based founder of [[Emojipedia]] created it" in 2014.<ref>{{cite news|last=O'Neill Deighan |first=Emma |title=It’s World Emoji Day, how will you celebrate? |url=http://www.belfastlive.co.uk/incoming/its-world-emoji-day-how-9680218 |accessdate=21 April 2016 |website=[[Belfast Live]] |date=17 July 2015}}</ref>
The New York Times reported that Burge created this on July 17 "based on the way the calendar emoji is shown on iPhones".<ref>{{cite news|last=Varn |first=Kathryn |title=The emoji inspired by a work of art |url=https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=auto&tl=en&js=y&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&u=http%3A%2F%2Ftecnologia.uol.com.br%2Fnoticias%2Fbbc%2F2016%2F04%2F25%2Fo-emoji-inspirado-em-uma-obra-de-arte---e-outros-significados-desses-simbolos-tao-populares.htm&edit-text= |accessdate=28 April 2016 |website=[[Universo Online]] |date=25 April 2016}}</ref> For the first World Emoji Day, Burge told [[The Independent]] "there were no formal plans put in place"<ref>{{cite news|last=Griffin |first=Andrew |title=World Emoji Day: Meet the man whose life work is cataloguing emoji |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/emojipedia-emoji-jeremy-burge-world-emoji-day-what-do-emoji-mean-a7141261.html |accessdate=18 July 2016 |website=[[The Independent]] |date=17 July 2016}}</ref> other than choosing the date. [[The Washington Post]] suggested in 2018 that readers use this day to "communicate with only emoji."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/kidspost/mark-your-2018-calendar-with-these-fun-and-funny-holidays/2017/12/29/a1ca469c-e05a-11e7-8679-a9728984779c_story.html|title=Mark your 2018 calendar with these fun and funny holidays|last=Barron|first=Christina|date=2018-01-01|work=Washington Post|access-date=2018-01-03|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
[[Google]] changed the appearance of [[Unicode]] character {{unichar|1F4C5|CALENDAR}}<ref>{{cite web |url=http://emojipedia.org/calendar/ |title=Calendar Emoji |website=Emojipedia}}</ref> in 2016 to display July 17 on [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[Gmail]] and [[Google Hangouts|Hangouts]] products.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://blog.emojipedia.org/android-7-1-emoji-changelog/|title=Android 7.1 Emoji Changelog|date=2016-10-21|work=Emojipedia|access-date=2017-06-12}}</ref>
== Announcements ==
On World Emoji Day 2015, [[Pepsi]] launched PepsiMoji which included an emoji keyboard and custom World Emoji Day Pepsi cans and bottles.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fera |first=Rae Ann |title=Pepsi Celebrates World Emoji Day With More Emoji |url=http://www.fastcocreate.com/3048710/pepsi-celebrates-world-emoji-day-with-more-emoji |accessdate=30 May 2016 |website=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]}}</ref> These were originally released in Canada, and expanded to 100 markets in 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last=Nudd |first=Tim Ann |title=Pepsi Is About to Unleash Emojis on Its Bottles and Cans Globally This Summer |url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/pepsi-about-unleash-emojis-its-bottles-and-cans-globally-summer-169782 |website=[[AdWeek]]}}</ref>.
In 2016, [[Sony Pictures Animation]] used World Emoji Day to announce [[T.J. Miller|T. J. Miller]] as the first cast member for ''[[The Emoji Movie]],''<ref>{{cite web|author=Sony Pictures Animation|url=https://twitter.com/SonyAnimation/status/754775907827458048|title=Emoji Movie: Express Yourself - T.J. Miller Audition|publisher=[[Twitter]]|date=July 17, 2016}}</ref> Google released “a series of new emoji that are more inclusive of women from diverse backgrounds”<ref>{{cite news|last=Mastroianni |first=Brian |title=Powerful women welcome new female emoji |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/powerful-women-welcome-new-female-emoji/ |website=[[CBS News]]}}</ref> and [[Emojipedia]] launched the first World Emoji Awards.<ref>{{cite web|author=World Emoji Awards|url=https://twitter.com/emojiawards/status/755073813461753856|title=Winner of Best New Emoji for 2016|publisher=[[Twitter]]|date=July 18, 2016}}</ref> Other World Emoji Day announcements in 2016 came from [[Disney]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kimm|first1=Matt|title=Google Celebrates World Emoji Day With Gender Diversity|url=https://www.inverse.com/article/18399-google-women-emoji-world-emoji-day|website=Inverse}}</ref> [[General Electric]], [[Twitter]], and [[Coca-Cola]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Romano|first1=Nick|url=http://ew.com/article/2016/07/17/world-emoji-day-zootopia-emoji-video-celebrate-internet-holiday/|website=Entertainment Weekly|title=World Emoji Day: Zootopia emoji video, more celebrate Internet holiday}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=McCarthy|first1=John|url=http://www.thedrum.com/news/2016/07/17/how-brands-marked-worldemojiday-twitter|website=The Drum|title=How brands marked #WorldEmojiDay on Twitter}}</ref>
In 2017, [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] celebrated World Emoji Day by announcing its new emojis on iOS,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/17/technology/apple-new-emoji.html|title=Meet Apple’s New Emojis: Zombies, Hijabs and Sandwiches Included|last=Salam|first=Maya|date=2017-07-17|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-07-21|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/jul/17/world-emoji-day-apple-unveiling-new-symbols-bearded-person-breastfeeding-sandwich-zombies-t-rex-ios-11|title=Apple marks World Emoji Day with beards, headscarves and breastfeeding|last=Hern|first=Alex|date=2017-07-17|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-10-09|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> London's [[Royal Opera House]] presented 20 operas and ballets in emoji form,<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-40612529|title=Emojis honoured in world celebration|date=2017-07-17|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-09-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> Google announced the end of its “blob emojis”<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2017/07/17/emojipedia-founder-talks-the-past-present-and-future-of-emoji/|title=Emojipedia founder talks the past, present and future of emoji|work=Engadget|access-date=2018-04-13|language=en-US}}</ref> and winners of the World Emoji Awards<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwtv/article/Winners-of-World-Emoji-Awards-to-be-Announced-on-World-Emoji-Day-20170717|title=Winners of World Emoji Awards to be Announced on World Emoji Day|last=Desk|first=BWW News|access-date=2017-07-21|language=en}}</ref> were announced<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/EmojiAwards/status/887316180557549568|title=Congratulations to Person Facepalming! Winner of Best New Emoji.|last=Awards|first=World Emoji|date=2017-07-18|website=World Emoji Awards|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-01-03}}</ref> from the trading floor of the [[New York Stock Exchange]] and broadcast on [[Cheddar (TV channel)|Cheddar]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/news/favorite-emoji-world-day-vote-13339292|title=It's World Emoji day tomorrow and you can vote for your favourite|last=Starnes|first=Anna|date=2017-07-16|work=cambridgenews|access-date=2017-07-21}}</ref>
In 2018, [[Kim Kardashian]] released her ''Kimoji'' fragrance line on World Emoji Day,<ref>https://www.harpersbazaar.com/beauty/makeup/a22091581/kkw-fragrance-kimoji-perfume-kim-kardashian/</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/kim-kardashian-west-talks-her-first-kkw-beauty-store-opening-la-today-politics-more-1121824|title=Kim Kardashian West Talks Her First KKW Beauty Store Opening in L.A., Political Activism and More|last=Schmidt|first=Ingrid|date=|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2018-06-20|language=en}}</ref> [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] previewed new emoji designs including redheads <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-44856509|title=Bald and ginger among Apple's new emojis|date=2018-07-17|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-11-01|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://money.cnn.com/2018/07/16/technology/apple-emoji-preview/index.html|title=Redheads, lobsters and cupcakes: Apple shows off new iOS emojis|last=Kelly|first=Heather|work=CNNMoney|access-date=2018-11-01}}</ref>and replaced executive photos on its corporate leadership page with emojis,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2018/07/17/world-emoji-day-today-heres-how-why-celebrate/|title=July 17 Is World Emoji Day. Here's How (And Why) to Celebrate|work=Fortune|access-date=2018-11-01|language=en}}</ref> Google announced the return of "blob emojis" in sticker form,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blog.emojipedia.org/blowing-kiss-beats-heart-eyes-in-new-google-stats/|title=Blowing Kiss Beats Heart-Eyes in New Google Stats|date=2018-07-17|work=Emojipedia|access-date=2018-11-01|language=en}}</ref> and Facebook announced "700 million emojis are used in Facebook posts each day".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2018/07/17/world-emoji-day-today-heres-how-why-celebrate/|title=July 17 Is World Emoji Day. Here's How (And Why) to Celebrate|work=Fortune|access-date=2018-11-01|language=en}}</ref>
== Events == [[Maggie Gyllenhaal]], [[Andrew Rannells]] and [[Olivia Palermo]] attended the [[PepsiCo|Pepsi]] World Emoji Day Red Carpet event in 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://t2conline.com/pepsi-celebrates-world-emoji-day/|title=Pepsi Celebrates World Emoji Day {{!}} Times Square Chronicles|website=t2conline.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.instyle.com/holidays-occasions/celebrities-favorite-emojis-world-emoji-day|title=*Heart Eyes* and More—Celebrities Share Their Favorite Emojis Ahead of World Emoji Day|work=InStyle.com|access-date=2017-10-09|language=en}}</ref> In 2017 [[Paula Abdul]], [[Maya Rudolph]], [[Liam Aiken]], [[Jeremy Burge]] and [[Fern Mallis]] at the [[Saks Fifth Avenue]] red carpet on World Emoji Day.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://newyorkstyleguide.com/saks-fifth-avenue-x-the-emoji-movie/|title=Saks Fifth Avenue x The Emoji Movie|website=newyorkstyleguide.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/fashion/la-ig-wwd-saks-sony-the-emoji-movie-20170718-story.html|title=Saks Fifth Avenue, Sony team up for ‘The Emoji Movie’ merchandise|last=WWD|first=Lisa Lockwood {{!}}|date=2017-07-18|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-10-09|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref>
The [[Empire State Building]] was lit in "emoji yellow" for World Emoji Day in 2017<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2017/07/17/empire-state-building-world-emoji-day-yellow/|title=The Empire State Building will light up 'emoji yellow' for World Emoji Day|last=Sequin|first=Molly|website=Mashable|access-date=2017-07-21}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> and the [[New York Stock Exchange]] Closing Bell was rung by [[Jake T. Austin]] of ''[[The Emoji Movie]]'' and [[Jeremy Burge]] from Emojipedia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nyse.com/events/3249761500/Sonys-The-Emoji-Movie-NYSE-SNE-Rings-The-NYSE-Closing-Bell|title=Sony's The Emoji Movie Rings the NYSE Closing Bell|last=|first=|date=|website=www.nyse.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-07-21}}</ref> A [[Guinness World Records|Guinness World Record]] was attempted in [[Dubai]] on World Emoji Day in 2017 for the "largest gathering of people dressed as emojis".<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://whatson.ae/dubai/2017/07/dubai-attempting-another-guinness-world-record/|title=This weekend Dubai Mall is going to be filled with people dressed as Emojis. Yes, really...|date=2017-07-11|work=What's On Dubai|access-date=2017-10-09|language=en-US}}</ref>
A new musical ''[[Emojiland]]'' premiered [[Off-Broadway|off-broadway]] in New York City at The Acorn Theatre<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://dcmetrotheaterarts.com/2018/07/20/2018-new-york-musical-festival-review-emojiland-at-the-acorn-theatre-at-theatre-row/|title=2018 New York Musical Festival Review: ‘Emojiland’ at The Acorn Theatre at Theatre Row - DC Metro Theater Arts|last=Miller|first=Deb|date=2018-07-20|work=DC Metro Theater Arts|access-date=2018-11-12|language=en-US}}</ref> on World Emoji Day 2018<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/22/theater/review-new-york-musical-emojiland.html|title=‘Emojiland’ and a Graceful Elegy at the New York Musical Festival|last=Collins-Hughes|first=Laura|date=|work=|access-date=2018-11-12|language=en}}</ref> as part of the [[New York Musical Festival]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/technow/hold-onto-your-hats-emoji-fans-theres-going-to-be-an-emoji-musical-850066.html|title=Hold onto your hats emoji fans: There’s going to be an emoji musical|date=2018-06-20|access-date=2018-06-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.engadget.com/2018/07/17/emojiland-musical-existential-angst/|title=‘Emojiland’ blends musical theater and existential angst|last=Velazco|first=Chris|date=|work=Engadget|access-date=2018-11-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
== In the news ==
In 2016 [[Twitter]] noted that Australia's "emoji-loving" Foreign Minister [[Julie Bishop]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Markson |first=Sharri |author-link=Sharri Markson|title=A Julie and Hugh affair |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/media/media-diary/nine-ceo-david-gyngell-pockets-tidy-share-windfall/news-story/04e1899db5685bf8654ea2448ab69424 |accessdate=30 May 2016 |website=[[The Australian]] |date=8 June 2015}}</ref> shares her birthday with World Emoji Day.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stocks |first=Karen |title=Add a little colour to your Tweets on #WorldEmojiDay |url=https://blog.twitter.com/2015/add-a-little-colour-to-your-tweets-on-worldemojiday |accessdate=30 May 2016 |website=[[Twitter]] |date=16 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-07-17/julie-bishop-celebrates-world-emoji-day/7636054|title=Julie Bishop celebrates World Emoji Day|date=2016-07-17|website=ABC News|language=en-AU|access-date=2018-07-10}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com.au/worldemojiday-is-on-the-same-day-as-emoji-fan-julie-bishops-birthday-2015-7|title=#WorldEmojiDay is on the same day as emoji fan Julie Bishop's birthday|last=Kimmorley|first=Sarah|date=2015-07-17|work=Business Insider Australia|access-date=2018-07-10|language=en}}</ref>
In 2017 US House Speaker [[Paul Ryan]] released a video on World Emoji Day claiming he “goes crazy on emojis”<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mediaite.com/online/paul-ryan-joins-the-worldemojiday-fun-i-go-crazy-on-emojis/|title=Paul Ryan Joins the #WorldEmojiDay Fun: ‘I Go Crazy on Emojis’|website=www.mediaite.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-23}}</ref> which was widely criticized.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/paul-ryan-emoji-backfires_us_596dad1de4b0e983c05882e9|title=Paul Ryan's Attempt At Being A Relatable 'Emoji Guy' Backfires|last=Moran|first=Lee|date=2017-07-18|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2017-10-23|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://mashable.com/2017/07/17/paul-ryan-emoji-day/|title=Paul Ryan tried to be #relatable on emoji day and it did not go well at all|last=Koerber|first=Brian|work=Mashable|access-date=2017-10-23|language=en}}</ref>
In 2018, [[AdWeek]] reported that social media posts from the United States [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]], [[United States Army|Army]] and [[United States Navy|Navy]] seemed like "an odd fit for the breezy joys" of World Emoji Day,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.adweek.com/creativity/world-emoji-day-check-out-the-most-odd-and-clever-ways-its-being-celebrated/|title=World Emoji Day: Check Out the Most Odd and Clever Ways It's Being Celebrated|access-date=2018-11-01|language=en-US}}</ref> while other outlets called these "weird"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://metro.co.uk/2018/07/17/us-army-fire-weird-tribute-emoji-day-7727740/|title=US Army under fire for weird tribute to 'Emoji Day'|date=2018-07-17|work=Metro|access-date=2018-11-01|language=en-GB}}</ref> and "the most terrible bastardization of an emoji".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mashable.com/article/world-emoji-day-fails/|title=Here are the worst tweets of World Emoji Day|last=Sung|first=Morgan|work=Mashable|access-date=2018-11-01|language=en}}</ref>
